PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 25 citizens) and Crichton-Browne (from 97 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Honourable Senators to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a refusal of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Report on Higher Education: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the Chubb Report on Higher Education for the A.C.T. which proposes that the Institute of Advanced Studies be separated from the Faculties of the Australian National University and the Faculties be amalgamated with the University of Canberra. We believe that the implementation of these proposals would mean the destruction of the Australian National University's national and international high standing and firmly established reputation as a centre of excellence in research and scholarship. The dismemberment of the ANU would severely affect the ability of both the Institute and the Faculties to attract, or even retain, high quality academic staff, funding and support. It would also adversely affect the recruitment of top students. The maintenance of the Australian National University, as it is now constituted-a national university with an international, national and local role-is of vital importance to the A.C.T. and Australia.
2. We call on the Senate to reject the recommendations of the Chubb report and to support the integrity of the ANU and the existing relationship between the Institute and the Faculties.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, when the debate was adjourned, I was developing my arguments in defence of the position I had taken about a particular notice of motion that I had given last year. I did note that Senator Bishop rushed in to show her ignorance of the Standing Orders and had not even given me a chance to finish my speech and my arguments, and in doing so misrepresented me about three times. But I will deal with those misrepresentations some other time.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic problem is that those of whom I speak are so proud of the Senate and all they believe it stands for, they so revere it, that they have allowed themselves continually to overstep the mark in defending it, promoting it and manipulating it. They believe, perhaps unconsciously, that the ends as they see them justify the means. They have become too involved in their political agenda that they are insufficiently dispassionate and disinterested. They have convinced themselves that, because what they espouse is not party based, they are not being political. But they are political as much as, probably more than, any of us who are involved in the thick of party politics. They have become active players going beyond giving procedural advice to involving themselves in the process. They try to run the Senate, not just the Department of the Senate.

I suspect that they would not disagree with my assessment, believing not just that it is their right to do so but that it is their duty. To support that I need only quote from a recent article by Peter O'Keeffe, the Clerk-Assistant, Committees-he was Clerk-Assistant, Procedure, at the time-espousing this duty. In an article in the Table journal he refers to `the power . . . of the role of Clerks of Parliament'. He asserts that `they are the hinges around which the actual business of Parliament revolves. They are, in a sense, stage-managers with a risk-laden, proactive role'.

Later in the article he talks about `Australian Clerks attempting to perform their role as guardians of the procedural equity that is the touchstone of any real parliamentary assembly', and refers to Clerks being `trustees, the trust property being constitutional parliamentary government'. He says that `there are essentially only two elements of continuity in a parliament, the institution itself and the clerkship'. It strikes me that that is an invoking of a higher duty than one's actual job. It is very reminiscent to me of that former South Australian Police Commissioner who invoked his higher duty to the Crown to justify overriding his real duty.

No-one suggests that the Clerks have any duty to the Government, this one or any other. It is not their job to promote or defend this Government or any other Government. They should not do anything to support the Government; nor should they continually oppose and attack the Government. It is not their job to undermine any Government or otherwise give aid to an Opposition, other than in a correct manner concerning procedure. Neither of these would be an appropriately independent position.

However, the partisanship is against the Government and against this one in particular because it is the current one. Over time, it may well be against all governments and I do not think that that is an appropriately independent position. I support the independence of the Clerks very strongly and that is why I took the action of requesting that they observe their independence and neutrality. They are in one of those few jobs which demand absolute political propriety. The Australian Electoral Commissioner would be one of the few others.

I do not agree that in their private lives they must be absolute political neuters. Show me someone who claims not to have an ideology, to have no politics or to be absolutely unbiased and that person will inevitably be an ideological conservative. But publicly, in their official positions, they must be absolutely clean so that there can be no hint of prejudice. Unfortunately, we do not have that situation.

It is no excuse that the grand tradition of Clerks over the years has done this to other governments and that their successors will do the same. It is myself and the Government Party of which I am a member that are being attacked right now. Some of the critical statements of which I complain may well be true. Some of the criticism may be fair; some of it I might even agree with. In fact, some of it I do agree with. The Clerk might be surprised to discover that I agree with some of his criticisms, but that is not the point. The point is that it should not be the Clerk of the Senate voicing those criticisms and expressing those opinions. It is for the Opposition, or lobby groups, or academics, or media commentators, writers of letters to the editor to say those things and for all those people to say them as loudly as they like. It is not for those in the peculiarly sensitive position of Clerk to say them in an official capacity.

I acknowledge that some politicians sometimes do behave badly-but it is not for the Clerks to say so. I acknowledge that governments do not always act to make it easy for non-government members and senators to have their say-but I do not think it is for the Clerks to say so. Oppositions do not always act with total propriety and reasonableness-but again it is not for the Clerks to say so.

So it ought to be now clear, even if it was not clear all along, why I objected to the published statements I listed in that motion. It was not meant to be a complete or comprehensive list. There probably have been more objectionable writings over the years but they are amongst the more recent writings which serve to annoy many of my colleagues and to push me to take the action that I have.

I will just quote some extracts to illustrate what I take exception to. In the particular article in the House Magazine concerning reference of Bills to Senate Committees, the Clerk uses the following words:

There are some members who do not attach the same importance to scrutiny of legislation, and some who consider that the only business of Parliament is to pass the bills proposed by the Government as speedily as possible.
In my mind, that is said with disapproval and it is criticism of certain honourable senators. It might be true but it is not for the Clerk to say so. The article also talks about:

Australian governments seeking to rigidly control every stage of the legislative process, and in committing themselves to every line and punctuation mark of each government bill from the time of its introduction. This peculiar insistence on total control is supported by a morbid dread of legislative proposals being interfered with and delayed by parliamentary action. Parliamentary processes in themselves are seen as subversive and something to be avoided if at all possible. This political culture provides the greatest barrier to any changes which aim at greater scrutiny of legislation.

There is much there that I would agree with. But the Clerk is involving himself in the political process by making those sorts of comments. It is a highly gratuitous sort of commentary. That article also contains what I believe is a prejudiced and not entirely accurate view of questions surrounding the procedure for the referral of Bills to committees. I suspect I should not take time now to try to correct that record but it is another indication of the problem.

Then there is the Australian Associated Press report, of which I complained, in which the Clerk is referred to as seeing the central problem as governments wanting to push legislation through quickly with little regard for scrutiny, and non-government parties wanting greater scrutiny but with little regard for time constraints. Later the article says:
There also was a need to consider doing away with an anomaly that saw the Government with a majority on the bills committees when it did not have a majority in the Senate.
There is also reference to the fact that some government people seem to be disregarding the process. The article says:

`They think that the name of the game is to use the numbers on committee to push through whatever they want to push through and that's it' . . . Mr Evans said the major parties' control over their members was to blame. `If a rubber stamp system persists, well, nothing can be made to work' . . .

They are very political comments and, if they are not criticising and insulting certain honourable senators, I do not know what is. It also included a reference to a fawning article in praise of former Senator McGauran, about how he beat the Government with repeated snide comments about the Government and governments generally. I found it a particularly sickening piece. I can accept that, but I think it is entirely inappropriate for a supposedly independent Clerk Assistant to be publishing such material.

There are some wonderful quotations in the article-wonderful for former Senator McGauran-such as, `His later restrained and statesmanlike contributions illustrate the care and sensitive handling that a private Senator's Bill needs and the self-restraint that its sponsor must exhibit'. That is just one example of that sort of quote, which will be very useful for former Senator McGauran to put in his next campaign pamphlet, which emphasises my point that Senate Clerks should never say anything that could be used in an election context, whether it be in praise of one honourable senator or in condemnation of a group of honourable senators.

I seem to remember another article a little time ago, also by the Clerk Assistant, Committees, which was in high praise of Senator Cooney and his work on regulations and ordinances, or perhaps it was on scrutiny of Bills. I found that embarrassing at the time. I should have said something at the time-I regret I did not-but I do say it now. I disapprove of such commentary, whichever side it is about, and I trust Senator Cooney will not quote from that piece when he is next seeking preselection or election.

Let me say on a personal level that I find it awkward when I receive praise from a Clerk, say, for a committee report I have been involved in preparing, especially if that report involves criticism of the Government. It leaves me with a sense of unease, because I would rather there was not the implication of my deserving approving noises for having done something on the approved Senate agenda.

In this same article about former Senator McGauran there are other examples of this problem of the writer becoming involved in the political process. I cannot find the quote just at the moment, but it refers to the assistance given in the preparation of a Bill. Peter O'Keeffe has revealed himself in the article I referred to before, the one about Clerks and members of parliament published in the Table. He openly talks about his and other Clerks' agenda. He refers to it as the `clerkly' parliamentary agenda. He proposes free votes, the breakdown of unnecessary party discipline, crossing the floor on matters of conscience, appointment of non-party political Presiding Officers, avoidance of joint select committees, the promotion of independent parliamentary education, in-House control of essential parliamentary services, in-House administration of salaries, et cetera, and House control of its own appropriations, which is an impossible thing.

It may be that some or all of those things are perfectly appropriate things to be promoted, but not by those who are in that very sensitive position. The Clerk himself, at the Estimates Committee, gave no hint of disagreeing with any part of that amazing agenda. I happen to agree with the Clerk Assistant's criticism of the growth of the policy on managerialism; but again, I do not think that it is his place to make the criticism. It is, I suppose, just part of the power play of this place; the exercise of power is very important to some people. It is just that the people the subject of this speech and that former notice of motion of mine, who are seeking to use and expand the power they undeniably have by virtue of their positions, were never elected by anybody, and they should be very careful not to misuse their undoubted power.

This is not the time to go into other issues involving other battles. The debate about the correctness or otherwise of all sorts of actions in this place will no doubt go on. I instance the continuing dispute over the so-called continuing orders and the question of the conference marking 20 years of the Senate committee system. But before concluding, I should deal with the press statement which Senator Harradine issued on the day I gave notice of this motion. I saw Senator Harradine's press statement only when it was reproduced in the House Magazine. I would like to deal with some of the misrepresentations in that. He referred to my notice and said, `By tradition, parliamentary Clerks do not enter public controversy, certainly not with senators'. That is, I guess, what I am saying should be the position. But by the sound of things, judging by the reaction to what I did, they do, and they rely on senators not responding. It just happens that I was pushed into responding.

Senator Harradine also tried to suggest that my motion was attempting to `bring them to heel', and that I was really attacking the independence of the Senate. He accused me of wanting to prevent the full development of the Senate committee system. I would have thought that everybody around here knew that I was a supporter of the Senate committee system and the way it can operate. There may be some matters of detail about process that I have differences with other people on, but it is a bit much to extrapolate from that that somehow I want to undermine the whole system.

Senator Harradine said that when this system for the referral of Bills to committee commenced earlier this year, `Senator Coates emerged as the proponent of the view whose implementation would have hobbled the Committees and prevented them utilising their powers to the fullest'. That is just nonsense. Certainly I had a view about the process, but it is nonsense to say that I wanted to hobble the committees. Senator Harradine's statement went on:

I can well remember the first meeting of one of those Committees where Senator Coates tried to put his approach to members of the Committee during a closed meeting while I chose to remain outside in the corridor.

That is absolutely untrue. I was, as was Senator Harradine, outside in the corridor for more than half an hour waiting for that Committee to finish its private meeting as it debated its procedures. In no way did I attempt to enter the debate in that Committee and I was not in the room at the time. Somehow or other, Senator Harradine got his information wrong on that point. Then Senator Harradine went on to say:
Senator Coates' approach was to `kneecap' the Clerks by discouraging them from giving impartial advice to Senators who want to fight the powerful position of the Executive Government.
I can only repeat the point that I made earlier, that I have no problem whatsoever on the question of procedural advice. Of course that job ought to be done in that independent way.

My only regret about having raised these issues rather than continuing the silence of the years past about Clerks past is that my comments have served only to confirm the `clerkist' hierarchy's distaste, even disdain, for politicians and to confirm them in their own view of the importance of their office and the views that they espouse. So I assume that they will wear my complaints as a badge of honour. However, that comment brings home to me my opinion that it is arrogant to suggest that the Clerks are the only ones committed to democracy and correct behaviour, because I believe they are wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

Perhaps the greatest insult or hurt a person can direct to another is to impugn that person's professional integrity. Last night, and again this morning, Senator Coates, initially apologetically but later more deliberately, cast unprecedented aspersions and accusations against a number of Clerks in the Senate. This was a cowardly attack against diligent, hardworking professional officers who cannot defend themselves. SPEECH.PARA: The Clerks in this place are justly proud of the traditions and the role of this Senate as a House of review. In upholding this responsibility, this Senate has a position enshrined in the Constitution. It is unfortunate that the Clerks are faced with those who seek to destroy this upper House by techniques of trying to tag the office-holders with an insult not befitting their position.

This Senate plays an integral part in the delicate system of checks and balances which is so essential in a parliamentary democracy. I find the remarks of Senator Coates, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, a committee which is involved in the accountability process, strange, to say the least.
