During the Senate Estimates Committee A review of the Australian Taxation Office, the oral answers given by the Taxation Office were of an exceedingly high standard. They sought to fulfil an attitude of the Office's leader, Trevor Boucher, to continue applying a philosophy of the year of service. The approach of the officers present was indeed gratifying. However, because of the pressures of time, a number of questions were taken on notice. Unfortunately, the quality of those responses varied considerably. They are very uneven across-the-board.

I will refer to a number of those responses. I asked a question on notice at page A157 of the Estimates Hansard about a raid on the offices of the Beneficial Finance Corporation by the Australian Federal Police-Australian Taxation Office. I asked a simple question:
Is it true that the information obtained in the course of the joint ATO/Federal Police raids, could have been obtained under the ATO's own powers as part of the routine audit it was then conducting?
I also asked what guidelines existed to assist the Office in determining whether to call in the police during the course of a taxation audit. The answer was less than satisfactory. It said:
As a result of information obtained in the course of the tax audit, matters were referred by the Australian Taxation Office to the Director of Public Prosecutions-
That was noted in my question, but that was not an appropriate response-

who in turn sought Australian Federal Police inquiries. Having regard to the tax related nature of the inquiries, the AFP sought and obtained ATO assistance in the course of its exemption of search warrants it obtained.

Police raids in our society are indeed a chilling experience. Before calling in the police on such dramatic and draconian occasions, it behoves government instrumentalities, authorities and officers to use the full information that is available to them, internally in this case, through the conduct of a normal tax audit. Where this information is available they should pursue a normal course of action. After all we are not a police state.

I have spoken on more than one occasion of the denigration of taxpayers' rights in recent years. Such action frightens individuals. We should not have an instrument of government acting in such a high-handed manner on the one hand and on request failing to provide guidelines to the Senate when asked when there were not any such guidelines available. If not, raids in such situations are quite unsatisfactory. I think it is a further demonstration that there must be a proper legislative base for Australian Taxation Office administration, particularly under this system of self-assessment that we are increasingly moving towards.

I refer now to comments by Mr Martin Crowe, head of group taxation from the National Bank. He is echoing sentiments that are growing in intensity, throughout professional journals, in relation to taxation:

Only in a climate of certainty can business operate efficiently. Every time a ruling is issued or a decision handed down which alters the previous interpretation of the tax law, it impacts on business.
He continues:
With a great deal of trumpeting, the Australian Taxation Office . . . heralded the 1989/90 financial year as `the year of service'.

I hope that 1991 will be the year when the Government seriously addresses the need to provide a legislative tax base for self-assessment, so that we can have a high degree of certainty in taxation administration and practice.
Mr Crowe says:

. . . while statistics can be produced to show that in a significant number of cases assessments were issued earlier, objections were determined quicker and correspondence was answered sooner, little progress seems to have been made with the fundamental problems of clarifying the tax laws and providing greater certainty about their meaning.
He says also:

A major cause for adjustment on audits by revenue authorities is the uncertainty in the various revenue laws. This uncertainty allows both parties to adopt diametrically opposed positions, which can only be settled by prolonged litigation, or, in the context of an audit, by an agreed amount of tax being paid as an expeditious settlement of the whole audit.
That is a very unsatisfactory method for the conduct of tax and the payment of tax in Australia. The suggestion by Mr Crowe of the National Bank is as follows:
The redeployment of some resources away from audit towards a `relationship' environment would be akin to adopting a preventative approach to tax compliance.
I welcome that suggestion, which continues:
Such an approach should lead to less disputation and litigation, and less opportunity for taxpayer and Tax Office to take diametrically opposed views.

I await with some enthusiasm the response from the Government on this matter. I refer to the frequency of recent Tax Office announcements and press statements relating to the tax file number, which give the impression that failure to lodge the notification document for the tax file number will result in tax being deducted on dividends and interest at the maximum rate. On the other hand, I refer to a letter from a leading firm of chartered accountants which indicates that it is not necessary to lodge such a declaration where corporations pay fully franked dividends.

This is another example of the sort of uncertainty that people are having to grapple with in the area of tax compliance nowadays: the Tax Commissioner, on the one hand, giving one view; a leading firm of accountants sending circular letters giving another view. This is really quite frightening and is quite inconsistent with this whole concept of certainty in this area, where a taxpayer has to self-assess and pay the cheque without immediate verification by the Tax Office. Later the taxpayer may be subject to a tax audit down the track with very heavy penalties when in error.

In moving to another issue, I ask the Minister to notify the Senate of whether, for example, there is an obligation on the part of banks and other financial institutions paying interest to provide documentary evidence to a taxpayer where tax has been deducted from interest or other income in circumstances where the tax file number has not been quoted and the financial institution has deducted tax at 48.25 per cent from that payment.

In the past, most recipients of such interest merely received a one-line interest component on a bank statement. I believe that there should be some instruction that there is a document available to the recipients of interest which specifies the gross, the tax and the net amount on that document.

I also refer to discussions of the National Tax Liaison Group in relation to what is known as division E of the Income Tax Assessment Act, in circumstances where interest on investment is paid on a term longer than one year. Again, I ask the Minister: does the Government intend to amend the legislation, and if so, when is the amendment likely to be introduced into the Senate to clarify the position in relation to the timing of interest assessability on these particular investments?

At page A131 of the Hansard report of the same inquiry, I raised the question whether, in considering the withholding tax exemption granted under section 128 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, a distinction ought to be made between onlending by large institutional entities and on-lending by a bank. The answer, I believe, was not correct. I wish to comment on the answer, and I also seek leave, Madam Deputy President, to incorporate the answer in Hansard so that my comments can be seen in the context of that answer. I seek the leave of the Senate.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TREASURY PORTFOLIO
AGENCY: AUSTRALIAN TAXATION OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Hansard Page A131

SPEECH.PARA: QUESTION:

The question raised by Senator Watson is whether, in considering if a withholding tax exemption should be granted under section 128f, a distinction ought to be made between onlending by a large industrial entity and onlending by a bank?
ANSWER:

The implication of the question is that subparagraph 128f (4) (b) (ii) applies to onlending by a large industrial company so that to get an exemption it has to show that the funds will be used by a resident in the operations of an Australian business, or for the establishment or acquisition of an interest in such a business.
The Australian Taxation Office agrees with this view and has publicly said so in Taxation Ruling IT 2238 issued in December 1985.

Since the withholding tax exemption available through section 128f is subject to money being used for stated purposes, it is necessary for an applicant for an exemption to demonstrate an appropriate connection between the obtaining of funds and the use of those funds for prescribed purposes.
The policy underlying the use of funds requirement is that of assisting the development of Australian resources and the economy generally.

If a distinction were to be drawn between onlending by banks and onlending by other entities, it would create the possibility of widespread avoidance of interest withholding tax by interposting an Australian bank for transactions which would fail the Australian business use requirement. It could also result in Australia being used as a tax haven to avoid other countries' taxes.
The ATO is working with the banking industry to develop procedures that will enable them to obtain exemptions in appropriate cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —My main concern regarding the Taxation Office reply to the question is that the answer does not reflect the law as set out in the Income Tax Act. In particular, the answer that I have incorporated fails to explain-simply because, I think, the Tax Office cannot explain it-why subparagraph 128f(4) (b) (ii) does not apply to banks. On the face of it, this subparagraph applies to an entity that uses funds borrowed offshore in its Australian business. There is nothing in the Income Tax Act which limits this test.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of an alternative test, in subparagraph 2, it provides an additional way of satisfying the Act, where the money-borrowing entity is not itself in business at all, and acts as a conduit for the funds. In those circumstances, the end user must naturally be carrying on the relevant Australian business. The special purpose borrowing vehicle in the manufacturing group which on-lends to an operating company in the group, would be the classic example.

The point at issue here has the potential for a huge economic impact on banks in Australia. First, if the Commissioner is now saying that only bank borrowings which are on-lent to other Australian businesses will obtain the exemption from withholding tax, a large portion of domestic banking activity will simply fail to qualify. This would include, for example, home mortgage lending, temporary short term money market investments of liquid funds, and repaying interest on previous borrowings which were on-lent to an Australian company which subsequently defaulted, for example, on its interest payments.

Secondly, if this new approach is applied retrospectively-which I have been told is the intention-a number of banks will have their exemption retrospectively denied in respect of offshore borrowing, going back 18 months. This is quite an unacceptable position for anybody to be in. This is a function of the way the Tax Office is currently administering this provision. It is not good enough, in that returns are made quarterly in arrears applying for exemption certificates.

The issue of such certificates has ceased in respect of some borrowings in some centres but not in others. We have some cases of borrowings up to 18 months ago yet the Australian Taxation Office refuses to give, and has not given, a formal reason. In terms of open government, in terms of 1989-90 being the year of service, this does not measure up to the very high standards that the Taxation Office aspires to reach.

Another matter of some concern is fraud within the Australian Taxation Office. Mr Vince Mitchell gave me a very adequate response to what I had asked. There is also a second aspect-the revelations by the Independent Commission Against Corruption which were made on 11 March 1991. In that circumstance it was revealed that private or confidential information from the Taxation Office was sold to clients by a private inquiry agent. We naturally asked what processes had been instituted. A response came to that. But, not long after, we had the revelations on the front page of a Sydney newspaper, the Telegraph Mirror, on 29 April 1991, where it was alleged that tax file numbers were being sold as part of a massive fraud racket involving millions of dollars of PAYE revenue being lost.

I remember that at the time of the debate a number of my colleagues, including Senator Walters, indicated that the so-called integrity of the tax file number would give to those people who had access an unprecedented opportunity for profit. I am concerned that the allegation raised in this newspaper, which indicated that false tax file numbers were being sold in hotels for $250 each, was not mentioned when we raised the question about fraud within the Australian Taxation Office, because there was a response to that article by the Taxation Office which indicated that employees had been charged internally. There should have been a much more honest and full account given to the Senate either during that inquiry or at a later time through written answers. The situation is just not good enough.

I also call on the Government to take an early opportunity to clarify the position of investors holding worthless shares writing those shares off in circumstances other than sale where it is impossible to execute a sale by reason of a company being insolvent, unable to trade and in the hands of a liquidator. Surely it is not beyond the powers of the Government, if it has the desire and the will, to assist ordinary people who have lost money as a result of poor investments, as a result of fraudulent decisions, as a result of entrepreneurial activity which hoodwinked honest investors, to write off the cost of that investment as a deduction against capital gains instead of having to trade them through an active stock exchange market where normal transfers are possible.

In the circumstances that I am outlining it is impossible to effect the transfer, with the company being in liquidation, until that corporation is actually wiped off. Very few actually get wiped off because there is not sufficient administrative money left to warrant such action and everything is just left in a heap. As a consequence, thousands of taxpayers are left with higher tax commitments than they might otherwise have because of the failure of the Government to recognise a situation of loss.

Another matter raised during the Senate Estimates processes was the industry statement in relation to depreciation. There are quite a number of situations that clearly the Government had not envisaged. We certainly hope that taxpayers will not be denied legitimate tax deductions as a result of the pooling arrangements and circumstances where an asset as part of the pool is sold during the financial year.

I also draw attention to matters which have been canvassed by the Tax Institute of Australia. Firstly, it draws attention to certain imprecise impressions on taxation in the booklet that accompanied that industry statement, that is that the new rules apply from 1 July 1991. While that in itself was not an incorrect statement, the application of broad-banding of the rates and pooling is to all taxpayers who have a substituted accounting period. That substituted period can quite easily commence before 1 July 1991 but is in lieu of the period 1 July 1991 to 30 June 1992.

The booklet also makes no reference to the comment which was made in the Treasurer's statement of 12 March 1991 that taxpayers exercising the option to self-assess depreciation rates will be required to annotate their tax returns to that effect. In the view of the Tax Institute of Australia and in the view of any tax practitioners, not to include that statement in the depreciation booklet is likely to mislead taxpayers.

I think it is apparent to the Taxation Office, if not to the Government, that there are members of the tax liaison group who are presently seeking clarification through the Treasurer's office of the meaning of this term `effective life'. I do not think the Government has really thought this out. We hope that there will be amendments and we press the Minister in this chamber at the present time, Senator Button, who has a major interest in this area, to ensure that amendments are made to the depreciation booklet and the matters are clarified when the legislation is presented to the Senate. We await the outcome of those submissions and those discussions.

I now ask the Minister about the status of the Government's Budget decision last year to repeal, as an economy and as a cost-saving measure, the hardship provisions that apply to small taxpayers who are unable to meet their tax debts.

The Ombudsman has the administrative responsibility of the Hardship Relief Board under section 265 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. At a recent hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration inquiry into the Ombudsman, the Ombudsman made the remark that it was his belief that the Government would not be proceeding with that Budget cost-saving measure. As it was in the Budget and as the Senate does not have another tax Bill coming before it prior to the Budget session, other than the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I believe that the Government should give an account of what it intends to do in this area. Will the Board be abolished? Why should it be left to the Ombudsman to clarify the position to a Senate committee? Should not an announcement be made by the responsible Minister and, if there is going to be a change or a replacement, should it not be reflected in legislation?

I also draw attention to the question of the need for legislative change in relation to a number of issues which became very apparent arising from the audit of the Adsteam Group and unprecedented actions over matters involving the Patcorp decision. Will the Government consider a legislative amendment? When can the Senate expect a proper legislative base? One of those areas concerns a new interpretation and, secondly, the need to put in place legislatively a taxation practice which is inconsistent with taxation law.

One Australian Taxation Office practice involving nominee shareholdings currently works for the benefit of taxpayers, but there is no legislative base for that taxation practice. Such unlegislative practices are not desirable in this context of the certainty that I referred to earlier. There is a need to regulate Taxation Office practice. There is a need, in the interests of self-assessment, that there be certainty before the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to Appropriation Bill (No. 5). However, at the outset, let me say that the Australian Democrats concur with the remarks of Senator Watson to the effect that the independence of the Clerks needs to be guaranteed. They are, indeed, the guardians of this Senate, and they are entitled to express views which assist in performing that task.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the subject of Aussat Pty Ltd. Eight years and some countless hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money later, Aussat has managed to capture less than 2 per cent of Australia's total communications market. Because of its charter Aussat has been forced to cater to the unprofitable 2 per cent, the public sector utilities-the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and remote commercial television services.

If Aussat had been a commercial enterprise and not simply a matter of political expediency or political misjudgment, the A-series satellite would never have left station earth. Instead, some $600m of public funds have ended up unaccounted for in some black hole in outer space. At no stage in the history of Aussat was public pressure brought to bear for its establishment. It was a symbol of the Fraser Government's grand vision and the bureaucratic push to dish it up to Telecom Australia and Telecom unions. However, the taxpayers, through direct Government and Telecom equity and the continuing Commonwealth Bank leverage lease arrangements, have been paying for an expensive technology that has long been superseded by cheaper terrestrial telecommunications.

Although the Aussat debacle is the Commonwealth Government's equivalent of the Victorian Economic Development Council scandal, so far the taxpaying public has had no explanation, and no admission of fault or responsibility. By selling off Aussat to the new telecommunications carrier the Government thinks it can bury the true cost to the taxpayer of this piece of space junk.

The original bad planning cannot be laid at this Government's door but, in 1986, when the expensive B-series was planned, the Hawke Government could have pointed to the Fraser Liberal Government's folly of pursuing this and walked away with only a minor debt on its hands. It did not. The political juggernaut continued to roll and the Hawke Government compounded the mistake by pouring good money after bad.

Against all available expert advice, the second generation B-series satellites were commissioned and ordered at a cost of $440m to the Australian taxpayer. But that was back in 1986 when television stations changed hands for a ridiculous multiple of earnings and Kerry Packer sold the Channel 9 network to his mate, Perth businessman Alan Bond, for $1.2 billion. In the two years until the deal was signed in 1988, the Government did have time to reconsider its purchase with the introduction of new terrestrial developments, which Telecom had forecast since 1976 before the launch of the A-series.

The purchase of the B-series satellites, which are to be launched in 1992, was another exercise in grandiosity that pales into insignificance besides Christopher Skase's egotistical attempts to buy United Artists and Warwick Fairfax's privatisation vision for the Fairfax group. Nevertheless, the purchase of the B-series was in the same class as the devil-may-care, someone else will pay for it entrepeneurialism that has given Australia a bad name. Like Skase, like Fairfax, like Bond, the Australian Government expects someone else to foot the bill for its own imprudent extravagance. Having gift-wrapped Aussat in fibre cable, the Government has hopes of selling it to a willing new telecommunications carrier anxious to enter the Australian market.

The full extent of the Government's imprudence, bad management and lack of supervision should have become known earlier this week when the Department of Transport and Communications (DOTAC) answered questions the Australian Democrats put to the Senate Estimates Committee. Since the sale of Aussat is going to be the entry price for the new telecommunications carrier, it is only right and proper that Australian taxpayers know the true state of Aussat's finances. But we do not, and the answers we have received certainly do not enlighten us. So the big question now is: how much is the Australian taxpayer to keep paying after Aussat is sold?

Even after it is sold, the reasons why it failed are not going to go away. From its early beginnings, Aussat was given a strictly commercial charter. But its specific obligations were exclusively to public sector entities: the ABC, SBS and remote commercial television services. These community service obligations, one of the main reasons behind Australia acquiring its own national regional satellite, will still have to be funded by the public purse.

Unless the Government has other plans, privatised Aussat under new ownership will still be carrying these essential but non-commercially viable services. For how long will a foreign owned, multinational telecommunications conglomerate wear such Australian idiosyncrasies? For how long, I ask? No matter how many times the Australian Democrats have asked about Aussat's true financial situation to ascertain its viability, I believe we have been fobbed off.

Last year the Government persuaded Telecom to sell back its 25 per cent stake in Aussat for $25m, without even placing a value on its 100 per cent value. This is just absurd. Telecom Australia has invested $50m in Aussat over the course of the project. What happened to the other $25m? Does anyone care about this? The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has already stated he will sell Aussat free of debt. It remains unclear whether, in transferring debt, the Government has assumed responsibility for Aussat's entire loan-lease arrangements.

Does the Government continue paying the Hughes Corporation, which is building the B-series generation, or will the new owners continue to make outstanding payments on the second generation? Has the Government transferred all of Aussat's liabilities or just its debt? And at what point is the debt transferred?

These are not nitpicking questions. It is very important for us to know the answers, to enable us to determine how the cost of the second generation satellites is being apportioned between the public and Aussat's new owners. But that is precisely what the Government does not want us to know. Can we assume that the bid from the new telecommunications carrier will reflect the price paid for the satellites, or is the Government going to make its decisions based on a broader range of concerns other than strict commercial viability?

Aussat's assets were valued last year at $670m. Its total liabilities at the time were $590m. We do not know the extent of the liabilities incurred by Aussat in the past 12 months. When the British Telecom rival, Mercury, entered the British market-about three times larger than Australia's-it invested #1.1 billion during the first five years of its gradual introduction. If the new carrier licence fee were set to equate with Aussat's current liabilities of $600m-or maybe more, since the Government will not tell us the true debt level-the entry price would be too high when compared with the British experience. If the new carrier licence is less, as we can expect it to be given the Government's desperation, how is the debt going to be apportioned between the new carrier and the Australian taxpayer?

We are left wondering what the true value is of gaining entry into Australia's telecommunications market. The Government has been so busy covering its Aussat mistakes that that question remains unanswered.

If the B-series fails to launch first time from China in 1992, who bears the multimillion dollar cost-the new owners or the taxpayers? The Government is aware of the non-commercial viability of Aussat. In a desperate bid to provide a market for satellite capacity that is grossly uncompetitive against terrestrial networks, the Department of Transport and Communications is trying to sell the Government and the public the idea of offering a pay TV and a public mobile service licence. As it is, the public would not want to buy shares in Aussat, so the Government must do something to sweeten the sale.

Satellite pay TV failed in the United States in the early 1980s and is failing in the British market now, despite these markets being respectively 12 times and three times bigger than the Australian market. Australia, with two television networks in dire straits and a radio industry on the brink of insolvency, does not need another broadcaster.

Mobilesat is seen as the other great white hope to create a satellite market out of the bush. The target market for the Mobilesat telephone service is the non-urban, predominantly rural, fixed and mobile telephone market. It is expected to reach some 50,000 users Australia-wide within the first seven years of service. Yet, according to the Department of Transport and Communications, these 50,000 users are expected to generate network traffic of around 100 million minutes per year by the year 2000. That may be, if we count the sheep as users and we forget that there is a rural recession as well!

Aussat has advised DOTAC that the true cost of this service will be a `small percentage' of the cost of second generation satellites. But independent estimates of the cost of the Mobilesat satellite capacity range from $60m to $80m, plus the `up to $25m' for ground station equipment. This would place the so-called small per cent of the overall cost at around 20 per cent, which is hardly small and hardly insignificant.

Speaking again of the Australian taxpayer, as many of us have in this debate, the behaviour of the Commonwealth Bank in the Aussat affair requires some scrutiny. The satellites are owned by a $2 shelf company set up by the Commonwealth Bank and are leased back by Aussat, which is paid a management fee. It is an unusual financial structure when used by private enterprise and rather suspect when used by public authorities. Under what is called this leverage lease arrangement, both the banks and Aussat receive significant tax advantages. Since any money the Commonwealth Bank lends to Aussat has the Federal Treasurer's cast-iron guarantee, Aussat has acquired a AA credit rating despite gearing levels described by one credit ratings agency as `extremely high'. At one point, the Senate might be astounded to learn, the gearing ratio was actually 735 per cent.

The moral of this sad Aussat saga could well be that we should not mix government with grandiose entrepreneurial schemes, especially ones that carry acronyms or initials like Aussat, B-Series, VFT, MFP, VEDC, WA Inc, or anything with the word `space' in it, like `Spaceport' or Star Wars. There is a right way and a wrong way to run public sector utilities, whether grooming them for privatisation or not. This is definitely the wrong way, and someone certainly owes the Australian taxpayer an apology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to do something that should have been done some time ago. When in general business a report of a delegation of which I was a member had to be tabled, unfortunately I was not able to speak to that matter because of time constraints. So I take the opportunity today because it is important that I put on record my impressions of what was a very important parliamentary delegation that visited the USSR and Mongolia and Japan last year. As I was the only senator on that delegation, it is important that I make some points in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation, headed by Dr Charlesworth from the House of Representatives, visited the Soviet Union on 19 September last year. The other members of the delegation were the Rt Hon Ian Sinclair, who was deputy leader of the delegation; Ms Mary Crawford, the member for Forde; Mr Duncan Kerr, the member for Denison; and Mr Alasdair Webster, the member for Macquarie; and Jennifer Blood, from our Public Accounts Committee, was the secretary of the delegation.

The hospitality and the warmth that we received in every country and every area we visited was most overwhelming. The favourable impression that we all gained resulted from the spirit of friendship and openness that was afforded us, particularly by the people of the Soviet Union. That friendship, openness and courtesy filtered through all our discussions and everything we did while we were there.

It was also one of those delegations that was very harmonious. Not only did we gain a lot of information while we were there but we also got to know each other a lot better, and I think those friendships will continue during our terms in parliament.

The delegation was unique in that it was the first Australian parliamentary delegation ever to meet with elected Soviet representatives. I make that point because throughout our relations with most countries, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, from your associations with China, it is not very often that politicians have the opportunity to meet on a one-to-one basis with their opposite numbers.

It was rather special that we were allowed to do that at such a significant time in the history of the Soviet Union, when so many changes were taking place. We were very fortunate to visit the USSR Supreme Soviet and the Supreme Soviet of the Russian Federation while they were in session. Mr Acting Deputy President, it was very interesting to see the President of the Soviet sitting where you are sitting now and to find that Gorbachev was sitting on his own, far distant from any other members. I do not know whether there was anything particularly significant about that or whether it was just the way it was set up, but it seemed rather unusual.

Watching that parliament, one thing that impressed me was that it is really not much different from ours. The members were arguing at considerable length over a piece of paper. Of course, we did not understand what they were talking about, but when we made inquiries we found that what they really were arguing about was whose turn it was to speak and about the orders of the day. That went on for at least an hour. So it is not much different from this place sometimes, when we spend a lot of time talking about procedures rather than getting on with the job.

From the point of view of the people, rather differently from what happens here, in the press and in the electronic media the parliament obviously had the number one rating in what was going on there. All heads were glued to the mostly black-and-white television sets because parliament was sitting at the time when all those momentous events were occurring, and they still are, of course. All the headlines in the press were about perestroika and glasnost.

The visit we made to the Soviet Union was in two parts. The first part was spent in Moscow talking to the leaders and the second part was spent in the Soviet far east looking at what prospects there were for Australia to widen its influence into that area. It is the Soviet far east that has a greater potential trade-wise for Australia. Between travelling from Moscow to Vladivostok we spent some time in Mongolia, and I will discuss that a little later. The primary motivation which led us from Moscow to proceed through eastern Siberia across to the Soviet far east was to examine the prospects for greater economic cooperation between Australia and the Soviet Union. It also allowed the delegation to gain an impression of the views that provincial administrators held about the central Moscow Government. That was quite interesting. The major provinces in the Soviet far east are aligned with the Russian Federation, and it was interesting to gain their views about what was happening in Moscow.

The first thing that impresses people about the Soviet Union is the huge size of the place. It represents one-third of the world's land mass. One of its biggest drawbacks is the fact that the country's sheer geographical extent underpins many of the problems and certainly does not help in arriving at any easy solutions to those problems. Against that, there is the cultural diversity and the historical and religious backgrounds of the member states of the union. Coupled with the size of the place, these are presenting enormous problems. Since we left there in October, we have seen the problems that have occurred in the Balkan states, in Georgia and in all the other ethnic provinces of the Soviet Union.

To say that the Soviet economy was in turmoil would be an understatement. There are problems associated with the establishment of a market economy-a convertible currency, private land ownership, a banking system, a stock exchange, company legislation and trade practices protection. Those are things that we take for granted, although at the moment we do not seem to be handling a lot of them very well, but they are all new things that those states have to face up to. Wherever we went, and whether we spoke to a leading politician or a man in the street, people were totally committed to a market economy and they thought that was the answer to everything. I do not think it is going to be as simple as that; I am sure we all know that.

A lot of the members of our delegation asked how a market economy is going to work. Certainly there are some very sharp types around the back streets, and I think a black market economy has been operating there for quite some time. It is very efficient, as a matter of fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheap jeans.

—Yes, but not only cheap jeans, a packet of cigarettes was very good currency-particularly Marlboro cigarettes, as I will show. One night we travelled on the Trans-Siberian Railway from Vladivostok to a place called Khabarovsk so that we could fly out to Japan. We were told that we had to take some food with us so that we would not die of starvation on the 13-hour trip. When we had boarded the train and settled in-the train was not too bad by their standards-we made a request for some plastic cups. Much to our disgust, the answer was nyet. Were there any glasses-nyet. Was there anything we could put something in-nyet. But when my colleague from Tasmania, Duncan Kerr, happened to produce a packet of 20 Marlboro cigarettes, immediately the rather large blonde attendant disappeared and arrived back with 14 pewter glass-lined mugs. She proceeded to join us later in her best outfit, and the next morning we all got a cup of tea in our carriages. That is just an example of the black market.
—What would you have got for two packets?

—I would hate to think what we would have got for two packets of cigarettes. At the level of infrastructure, everything seems to be 40 or 50 years old, and getting older. There are transport problems: it was fascinating to see at railway stations heaps and heaps of mail stacked up on railway carriages. Nobody would know where it was going or where it was coming from. After I returned home, a postcard I sent to my mother arrived in February-which was not too bad, I guess, seeing that it was sent in September. That is just an example of the terrible problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we were in Vladivostok we wanted to phone our High Commission in Moscow. We had to book the call the day before, and we were told the next day that unfortunately the operator could not make contact. So we can understand why, if telecommunications are so bad, the problems facing the Soviet Union are being exacerbated by the basic things we take for granted in this country.

As you can imagine, with virtually only one train line running across the Soviet Union, the distribution of food, clothing and consumer goods is rather horrendous. We have all read about the queues that are everywhere, and I must say I can attest to that. In Moscow, people must have money because the biggest queues are outside the French perfume shops which let in only so many people at a time so that they are not crowded out.

The Soviet far east, where we spent a fair amount of time, certainly has a wealth of natural resources. I believe it is the place that has the greatest potential for cooperation between Australia and the Soviet Union. But to facilitate that, there are certainly massive improvements needed. For instance, transport is very basic. As I said, telecommunications are almost non-existent, although I did manage the other day to get a fax through to Vladivostok from my office in Hobart-which I had been trying to do for about three months. That has really restored my faith in the Soviet communications system somewhat.

The Soviet far east is endeavouring to encourage tourism. I think it is certainly a wonderful place to see. It is something different. It is unlike anything else in the world, but the hotel accommodation certainly leaves a lot to be desired. I have roughed it round the bush in a few places, and I can certainly describe the Soviet toilet facilities and cleaning facilities as basic, to say the least.

In fact, in Vladivostok, if we got hot water once a day we were very lucky. The water was turned off between 10 o'clock in the morning and 4 o'clock in the afternoon, and so when we turned our taps on in the afternoon most of the water that came out was rusty. There are a few stories I could tell about that-particularly about our leader-but this is neither the place nor the time to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are working around to telling us that this country is pretty good, are you not?

—For instance, Senator Button, in terms of a particular area that you know so well, a little bit of PVC piping would go a long way in the Soviet Union. I saw no evidence of that at all. If some enterprising exporter from Australia were able to get into the Soviet far east after he had been through all the problems of getting a visa, I am sure he would be able to set up a profitable joint venture promoting the sale of PVC piping. Certainly, I saw no evidence of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Nor did I see any evidence of retreaded tyres. That is an opportunity that Ian Sinclair and I saw as being one that could become very profitable. I do not think those people had even heard of retreaded tyres because most of the tyres we saw either had holes in them or were lying on the side of the road.

As I said, we were received warmly and hospitably everywhere we went. It was rather disturbing when we walked into a fruit market in Vladivostok. Vladivostok is a place the size of Canberra, but in the fruit market only two areas were open. The price of a kilogram of locally grown pears was about $A12.50. That sounds bad enough, but when we equate that with the wage structure that means that it costs about half a week's wages to buy a kilogram of pears. So it was not surprising that when a gentleman saw I had a packet of cigarettes he offered me a couple of pears for one cigarette. Then I was mobbed and offered a pomegranate for two cigarettes! So the black market certainly is alive and well.

Having read plenty of spy thrillers, and the types of things we read in newspapers, I expected that whilst we were in the Soviet Union censorship would be something that we would have to be careful of. Whilst I was told that one or two of the accompanying officials from the Soviet Union were KGB agents, nevertheless I had a video camera and I was able to film eight hours of video whilst I was away.

The only times I was asked not to video were at the Moscow Circus, the Mongolian Circus and when we were in the armoury under the Kremlin where all the jewels are kept. I can understand that because I am sure even Senator Button would be amazed by the amount of wealth that sits below the Kremlin. In fact, there was a bucketful of uncut jewels there and just one of those jewels would have paid for the $140m that the Soviets owe us for our wool. I suggested to them that they should do that, and of course I got the usual nyet, hands-off approach.

Even in Vladivostok, which is a closed city-and although they are saying now that it is open, it certainly is still a closed city-I was able to video whatever I wanted. There were plenty of naval establishments. No doubt we have already got plenty of film of that through our security service. There was no question of not filming or not taking photos of anything we wished to. I do not know why it is a closed city because, apart from the missile sites around the tops of the hills and a few army establishments, it looked no different from any other city I have been to.

There is great scope for development in the Soviet far east. We recommended that Austrade consider appointing a regional officer, based in Hong Kong, in order to promote Australia's commercial interests in Mongolia and in the far east. As part of that, we would see Austrade, in conjunction with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, producing a guide for doing business in the Soviet far east, because help would certainly be needed.

The bureaucracy there is unbelievable. Getting a visa is an example. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at one stage gave up in despair trying to get in there to get some work done; it just could not get visas. It is not that people are not wanted there, but that the whole bureaucratic system is such that, for some reason or other, the local chamber of commerce in Vladivostok has a finger in the pie and if you do not get on well with it, you do not get a visa. There is a problem with currency, but there is plenty of scope for joint ventures, even barter trade, and that is something the Government and those involved should look at.

Turning to Mongolia, it was the first time an Australian parliamentary delegation had visited that country. As in the Soviet Union, the visit was at a very important stage in Mongolia's history because in July last year the first democratic elections in the history of Mongolia took place under the supervision of international observers. During the week we were there, the country's first democratically elected government was being formed. So, naturally, in Mongolia most of our discussions focused on the political and economic reform process, the conduct and results of the election, and what had happened since.

Six parties and a number of Independents contested the elections for the Great People's Hural, with the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party-the Communist Party-gaining 61 per cent of the vote. The new standing legislature, the Small Hural, was then elected by a system of proportional representation, with one seat for each 2 per cent of the votes received in the elections of the Great Hural.

It was unique that the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, after having gained 61 per cent of the vote and being in a position to form a government in its own right, chose to form a multiparty government, with all four parties which gained seats in the Small Hural being elected. I do not think we should carry that idea forward to Australia, but perhaps there is some thought for us there. The Prime Minister, Mr Byambasuren, told us that he felt it was important because, by forming a multiparty government, he was able to gain the most talented members to contribute to what he saw as a very critical stage of the country's development. As a result, the Vice-President and Chairman of the Small Hural, Mr Gonchigdorj, was a member of the Social Democratic Party, which had not gained a very large proportion of the vote at all.

I was very impressed with the Mongolian Democratic Party. It is a little different from the one here. Its members principally are academics. I think they were the ones who really forced the election upon the country, and they were very impressive people. Mongolia is no different from the rest of the Soviet Union: there is certainly a great need to modernise the economy. But the fact that the six parties had joined together to form a multiparty government and that they were all committed to the introduction of a market economy was most heartening.

One of their biggest problems under this market economy strategy is going to be the redistribution of property as part of their economic restructuring. In the Gobi Desert we met the local mayor of Gobi, who was very enthusiastic. I tried to equate him to some of the local government mayors I have met, but he is in a class of his own. Honourable senators would be able to imagine the problems in a huge area such as the Gobi Desert, where there are nomadic farmers. By the way, they are fantastic farmers for what resources they have. How land will be allocated I just do not know, but as the Russians and the Mongolians say, `No problem'.

I meant to mention something about Vladivostok. As a result of discussions that Duncan Kerr and I had with a fishing cooperative in Vladivostok I am pleased to report that, after toing and froing, it seems that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is interested in a group of quite important fisheries research people coming out here. One of them, Dr Nosov, has done a lot of work in Tasmanian waters and around Australia. They are coming on a private visit very shortly, I believe.

As in the Soviet Union, the reception we had in Mongolia was unbelievable. The opportunities for trade there are absolutely enormous. The Mongolians have got every mineral that anyone could ever think of, and all still in the ground. They even have quite good resources of oil, which they are having difficulty getting out of the ground. Being a farmer I must say that I was very impressed that, even with their poor economic situation, the way they approach their agriculture and their land care is something that Australians could look at. They gain the maximum amount of production from what is best described as very harsh country.

I am pleased to say that the Australian Government through Mr Peter Sloan, who is on loan there, is helping in some small way. We did come up with some suggestions about how we could help. We suggested that an Australian agricultural trade mission delegation visit Mongolia and that Austrade give consideration, as with the far east, to trying to help to get into Mongolia some of our people who wish to help and have joint ventures. Simple things such as electric fencing, solar powered communications, windmills, portable shearing plants, things the Mongolians have never heard of: they are the sorts of things by which I believe we in Australia, at a very small cost, could really make their job a lot easier.

We were very impressed by Mongolia. I believe that while Mongolia, of all the places we visited in the Soviet Union, might have the hardest row to hoe, it has the necessary joint approach and will to succeed. I believe the Mongolians will succeed, although they will have to go through a lot of pain to do so.

We flew out of the Soviet far east into Japan. I suppose it can be best described as going out of a dark room into the light, because the Japanese were light years ahead of anything else we had seen in that area of the world. As I said earlier, the whole country-the Soviet Union, the far east and Mongolia-is 40 years behind anything I have ever seen before. Everything seems worn out and run down, but the people are still surviving. But to come into Japan was a culture shock although I had been there before. Everything is new beaut, up to date and all the rest that we know about the Japanese. We did have some very long discussions with the Japanese politicians and business people about where we are sitting now with trade. That was probably the primary focus of our visit there.

As we know, Japan's great paradox is the contrast between its industrial might as a free trader and its protectionist position on agricultural trade. We are very concerned about this. We took every opportunity to underline the inconsistencies and the inefficiency of this position. This is an example of the difference between Australia's attitude-where it is at the moment-and Japan's. In Tokyo, October was Import Now month. All the taxis and buses carried slogans. There were banners all around the town trying to get Japanese people to import. This shows why there is such a difference between Japan's balance of trade and ours.

I acknowledge not only the assistance provided by the three host countries and the staff of the Australian embassies but also the efforts of the Australian staff, whose administrative arrangements made our delegation so efficient. Everything went off without a hitch. I particularly thank Francesca Beddie, who accompanied our delegation through the USSR and Mongolia; Victor Samoilenko, Yvegenii Tregubov and Vladimir Ivanov, who travelled with us in the USSR-I will not say, `Pick the KGB agent' because I could not-and Dr Barsbold, Mrs Bulgan and Mr Suhee, who travelled with us in Mongolia. We had great assistance from Derek Brown in Japan, and Mr Ariga, Mrs Shimura and Mr Abe. They provided us with superb assistance and made our delegation very memorable. In fact, at the moment my colleague Alasdair Webster is copying onto tape a video account of our tour. I will present this to members of the delegation I expect during the next sitting round. I hope it gives them as much joy and as many memories of this very successfully delegation as it gave us. If anybody is interested I am sure we could make that video available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the package of Appropriation Bills for supplementary appropriations; that is the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation Bill (No. 5). The first matter-although I do not really wish to attend to it-is the comments made by Senator Coates in this chamber and elsewhere and his serious reflections on the integrity and professionalism of the Clerks of the Senate. I rise to express my concern that this type of attack does nothing for the integrity of this chamber and really does nothing for Senator Coates. When Senator Coates moved his notice of motion I indicated that this bully boy approach would hang over the heads of the Clerks of the Senate like a sword, as the notice was given just before a very long and extended break in the Senate. I am very pleased to see that Senator Coates has now withdrawn that notice of motion. Nevertheless, some of his comments last night and this morning confirm my view that his attack on the Clerk of the Senate and one of the senior Clerks is deplorable.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coates alleges that the Clerks have engaged in partisan activity. Frankly, if one wanted to question whether the Clerks act appropriately in this chamber or elsewhere, one would only need to look at what happened last night. In the adjournment debate last night, Senator Bishop attempted to correct some of the statements made by Senator Coates when speaking to the Appropriation Bills. What happened? The Deputy Clerk at the table gave advice to the President that Senator Bishop was not in order in defending the Clerks because the honourable senator was anticipating a debate or reflecting on a previous debate. The matter was very neatly and nicely handled by all concerned-the President and, indeed, Senator Bishop.

But we now have the matter before us, so we cannot avoid it, although I would have hoped that we could. The allegations are that the Clerk of the Senate and a Clerk Assistant have engaged in partisan activity. Quite frankly, that is groundless. The Clerks, as with academic researchers and other professionals, must have a certain freedom to develop a line of thought in written articles which can be used by political science students and all others who follow the work of our parliamentary institutions. The correct response for someone who disagrees with what they write is to submit an article in rebuttal. I ask Senator Coates whether he feels so insecure in his ability to do that that he will not submit articles to various journals in respect of what this Senate is all about.

I am concerned not only for the Clerk and the Clerk Assistant concerned, but I am also concerned about this institution, its integrity and why it exists. I know that a number of people say that the Senate ought to be abolished. That was the view of the Australian Labor Party for many years. It has now changed that view. But presumably Senator Coates is one who has a hankering for the unitary system rather than the bicameral system.

The Senate was established as a House of review and not as a party political House. This House was established by the founding fathers as a House to uphold the rights of the States. I am appalled that an honourable senator from one of the smaller States should so reflect on the functions of this chamber as to diminish its role in this regard.

The role of the Senate has been diminished over time. I have witnessed it during the 15 or 16 years that I have been here. I have witnessed the predominance of party discipline in this chamber, and that ought to be a matter of concern and note. Whoever notes it-whether it be the Clerks of the Senate in learned journals or myself on the political stump-does not matter. It is a question of what this chamber was intended to be and whether it is carrying out those functions, and I will refer to one of them.

We in this chamber have always prided ourselves as upholding the rights of individuals. I ask whether the rights of the individuals who are under attack by Senator Coates are being properly upheld. In my view, they do have the right to discuss in measured, appropriate terms in journal articles and elsewhere the questions relating to the functions and the functioning of this chamber or of the Parliament.

The Senate, through the President and the officials, has undertaken considerable initiatives in respect of various displays and seminars on the Constitution and other topics, which are very important for us to consider. Really, they cannot usefully comment on the work of the Senate by simply writing about how the Senate chairs are arranged, how the Senate table is arranged, what the Senate attendants are wearing or the Senate broadcast system and scrupulously ignoring any direct mention of honourable senators and their work. It is ludicrous to suggest that any meaningful article could be so written.

I have to admit that I am now one of the longest serving-I will not say oldest-members in this place. For some years, my colleagues have seen fit to appoint me as the Chairman of the Parliamentary Studies Fellowship Committee, which has the task of selecting a person to occupy an important study and research position in the Parliamentary Library. I have had a professional working relationship with both the Clerk and the Clerk Assistant mentioned by Senator Coates for many years and, in my long experience, I must say that their approach has been impeccably impartial and professional.

I have not always agreed with them or followed their parliamentary advice, but I have been grateful that they have operated under a system of independence from the Executive Government. I had a fear that Senator Coates was acting as a stalking-horse for Ministers. Now I do not think that is the case. I think he is somewhat on his own in the position that he takes at the present moment.

I had the feeling that there may have been something more behind it, given the new developments in the Senate committee system. Under the new system, legislative Bills have been referred to standing committees of the Senate, where Bills, Ministers and public servants responsible for the Bills have been put under the microscope. Senators, both members of the committees and others, have been able to quiz public servants to find out more about the meaning of clauses.

All round, the system is proving to be probably more successful than Ministers, I or anybody else had considered possible. I make an aside here. Senator Coates, when referring to a comment that I had made which was printed in the House Magazine, questioned this morning the veracity of what I had said in that journal. I said:

I can well remember the first meeting of one of these Committees where Senator Coates tried to put his approach to members of the Committee during a closed meeting while I chose to remain outside in the corridor. Fortunately, this particular Committee decided to permit a fairly open approach in dealing with witnesses and I and other Senators were able to question the public servants about the detail of legislation and, indeed, I obtained agreement from the Committee for an important amendment to the Bill under question.

I understood Senator Coates to say this morning-and it is a minor matter-that he was out in the corridor waiting with me. He must have been in a different corridor because I remember quite clearly that I, and indeed the Minister, Senator Button, were waiting out in the corridor to find out what the committee-of which Senator Childs was chairman-was going to do: was it going to allow the public servants to be questioned or what? Who knows? Senator Coates may have been responsible for what happened subsequently in that we were able to question the public servants and the Minister. I know that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats-I think Senator Coulter was involved-were quite adamant that we should be able to question the public servants. And, in the end, we were. Everybody was quite happy about the way the proceedings were conducted.

I return to the real issue. The Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk Assistant that Senator Coates has attacked are the people that ordinary senators rely on for advice as to what they can and cannot do. Also, they are not in a position to publicly defend themselves. The only message that I have received-and I have not discussed this with the Clerk-is a letter dated 11 February 1991 from the Clerk of the Senate. That puts the position into its proper perspective quite sufficiently and I would hope that will be the end of the matter. If it is not, and if there is a continuance of attacks on the paid officers of this Parliament, it will reflect on the integrity of this chamber as a whole.

I remind Senator Coates that if some people are writing in academic journals and so on about the functioning of the Parliament and this chamber, as to whether it is functioning as a party House or a House of review, those are very important matters. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a letter that I received, and which I understand the Party leaders and independent senators received, from the Clerk of the Senate dated 11 February 1991.

The letter read as follows-
11 February 1991
Senator B. Harradine
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Harradine

I am writing to each party leader and independent Senator concerning the notice of motion given by Senator Coates on the last day of sitting. On 16 January I wrote in similar terms to Mr President and the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

This notice makes a most serious and defamatory allegation against my colleague Peter O'Keeffe and me, namely, that we have published statements of a partisan nature, an allegation which impugns our professional integrity.

Immediately after the notice was given I wrote to Senator Coates expressing surprise that he had not sought to discuss with me his apparent concerns before giving the notice, and inviting him to discuss the matter with me. I have repeated that invitation but it has not been accepted.

The only basis of the allegation contained in the notice is a reference to two articles written by Peter O'Keeffe and me in parliamentary journals and a report of my answers to some questions put to me by a journalist concerning the procedures for consideration of bills in committees.

There is nothing in these items to justify the allegation of partisanship. A statement with which a Senator may disagree is not for that reason a partisan statement. My article and the press report give a favourable account of the new procedures for referral of bills to committees, but it can hardly be partisan to be supportive of procedures which were unanimously recommended by an all-party Senate committee and which were adopted by the Senate without opposition. Contrary to the assertion in the notice, those items do not contain any ``criticism of certain Senators''. They refer to differences of view among Senators, but offer no critique or evaluation of those different views. The press report contains a great deal of commentary by the journalist in addition to my answers, but I am not responsible for that commentary. The characterisation in the notice of Peter O'Keeffe's article as being ``in praise of a former Senator'' is absurd. That article is a study of the way in which a Senator can use a private Senator's bill to deal with a difficult and sensitive issue. It is no more ``in praise of a former Senator'' than a previous article by Peter O'Keeffe referring to the role of the Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee was in praise of Senator Cooney.
The serious allegation of partisanship is therefore not justified by the items referred to in the notice.

The articles in question are not different in kind from other articles written by other clerks on parliamentary matters over many years. Such articles frequently contain analysis, critique or evaluation of parliamentary matters, but never partisanship. In fact, articles written by clerks in the past were far more robust in commenting upon proceedings in the Senate than I or my colleagues have ever been. In an article written in 1970 the then Deputy-Clerk, Roy Bullock, referred in the following terms to the practice of the then government backbenchers of clogging the general business section of the Notice Paper with their own items of business:

``This situation was not good. It denigrated the Senate as an institution, frustrated a vigorous Opposition, and was completely out of keeping with the new order of things under proportional representation, and the need to streamline Parliamentary procedures.''
Such writings did not lead to any notices of motion in the Senate, or, indeed, to any adverse comment at all.
If the articles in question are regarded as objectionable, then virtually nothing can be written by any officer.

As you would be aware, my colleagues and I advise all Senators without regard to their political affiliations. Frequently we give advice which may not suit the political convenience of one or other of the parties in the Senate. Hitherto that very proper situation has not led to any allegation of partisanship. I trust that we are not now coming to a situation in which advice that accords with one party's objectives is regarded as good advice but advice to the contrary is considered partisan.

If the notice of motion remains on the Notice Paper undebated, as is normal with general business notices of motion, that may be taken as an indication that the allegation is not regarded as important.
Regardless of any other action in relation to the notice, I ask that this letter be incorporated in Hansard as a refutation of the allegation in the notice.
I have forwarded copies of this letter to Mr President and the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
Yours sincerely,
(Harry Evans)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a large number of matters in this debate on the Appropriation Bills. I refer the Senate to the report of Estimates Committee B of May 1991. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Changes to Explanatory Notes-AIDAB

During questioning under program element 5.2.2 relating to a UNFPA aid project to strengthen the technical capacity of the Centre for Population Studies in the Ministry of Labour in Vietnam, the Committee was informed that the money defined in the Explanatory Notes as being for this particular project had subsequently been diverted to a different UNFPA project in Papua New Guinea and that AIDAB had been aware of this funding change since late February.

The Committee regards this situation as unsatisfactory and advises AIDAB that when significant variations to Explanatory Notes occur, replacement pages indicating these variations should be provided to the Committee in advance of the public hearings.

That is a very significant statement by Estimates Committee B. We as parliamentarians, besides all of the functions I have referred to, have an audit and control function, and we must exercise that function. In order for us to exercise that function of care of public moneys we have to be told the facts, and we have to be told them in good time to enable us to examine them and research them.

The matter we now have before us-the funding of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) project in Papua New Guinea-will give rise to vigorous questions amongst many groups and individuals who do not share my views. The fact is that it now appears that the proposal is to fund a UNFPA program of population control in Papua New Guinea under a PNG strengthening maternal care and family planning services project.

An amount of money will go to assist in purchasing drugs and contraceptive devices. It has been ascertained from further questioning that has occurred since the Estimates Committee hearing-the answers to which were tabled yesterday-that the project documentation from the UNFPA indicates that the drug injectable depo-provera will account for 58.5 per cent of total expenditure on birth control supplies. Information from the bulk procurement office of the UNFPA in New York indicates that this will be directed to about 63 per cent of the people targeted. In other words, depo-provera will be used in 63 per cent of the female target group for which this program is designed.

I need not remind the Senate of the great concerns that have been expressed, largely through feminist groupings-of which, I admit, I am not a member-but also amongst a large number of other groups. A study was undertaken of depoprovera by the Food and Drug Administration in the United States using persons who were also agreed upon by Upjohn Pty Ltd, the manufacturer of the drug. That study showed that, because of the considerable ill effects that the drug had on women as well as the dangers to their health, the Food and Drug Administration would not approve of the drug as a contraceptive. That is still the position in the United States of America.
In Australia, the MIMS Annual 1990, which has just been published, states:
The use of Depo-Provera for contraception is not an approved indication and such use is investigational since there are unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication.

What do we do with our aid money? We say, `Bung it off to Papua New Guinea. After all, they are only ex-colonials. The poor women up there as they line up for their other injections would not know what this is'. In my view, this is tantamount to cultural colonialism. The question-and I raise it now so that the Government can have another look at this before the Committee of the Whole debate takes place-is: if this drug is not officially approved for contraception in Australia, why are we now paying for the drug to be purchased and used in a program developed by UNFPA in Papua New Guinea?

I know that it is being said, and will be said, that the World Health Organisation has approved the drug for that purpose. Approval was pressed upon the WHO through UNFPA and the human reproduction program, both of which have questionable track records in these particular areas. The fact remains that the drug is very much opposed by a broad range of people in Australia and the United States. It is not approved for contraception purposes in Australia.

It is interesting to note-and I will go into this in detail in the Committee of the Whole-that we have been asked in the Estimates Committee to look at a program of maternal health care. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the part of the MIMS report which deals with the contraindications of depo-provera so that the official documentation is contained below what I have said.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
Contraindications
1. Thrombophlebitis, thromboembolic disorders, cerebral apoplexy or patients with a past history of these conditions.
2. Markedly impaired liver functions.
3. Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding.
4. Undiagnosed urinary tract bleeding.
5. Undiagnosed breast pathology.
6. Missed abortion.
7. Known sensitivity to medroxyprogesterone acetate.
8. Use in pregnancy. (Category D)
Animal studies have shown that high doses of progestogens can cause masculinisation of the female fetus.
9. Severe uncontrolled hypertension.
Warnings

1. The physician should be alert to the earliest manifestations of thrombotic disorders (thrombophlebitis, cerebrovascular disorders, pulmonary embolism, and retinal thrombosis). Should any of these occur or be suspected, the drug should be discontinued immediately.

2. Discontinue medication pending examination if there is sudden partial or complete loss of vision, or if there is a sudden onset of proptosis, diplopia or migraine. If examination reveals papilloedema, or retinal vascular lesions, medication should be withdrawn.
3. Following repeated injections, amenorrhoea and infertility may persist for periods of up to 18 months and occasionally longer.
4. In all situations where cessation of therapy is warranted, the physician should be aware of the slow elimination of the depot formulation.

5. Clinical suppression of adrenocorticoid function has not been observed at low dose levels, however, at the high doses used in the treatment of cancer, corticoid-like activity has been reported. Animal studies show that medroxyprogesterone acetate possesses adrenocorticoid activity.
6. Anaphylactic and anaphylactoid reactions have occasionally been reported in patients treated with Depo-Provera.

7. The following laboratory tests may be affected by the use of Depo-Provera: gonadotrophin levels; plasma progesterone levels; urinary pregnanediol levels; plasma testosterone levels (in the male); plasma oestrogen levels (in the female); plasma cortisol levels; glucose tolerance test; metyrapone test.
Precautions
1. The use of Depo-Provera for contraception is not an approved indication and such use is investigational since there are unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication.
2. The pretreatment physical examination should include special reference to breast and pelvic organs, as well as Papanicolaou smear.

3. Because this drug may cause some degree of fluid retention, conditions which might be influenced by this factor, such as epilepsy, migraine, asthma, or cardiac or renal dysfunction, require careful observation.

4. Breakthrough bleeding is likely to occur in patients being treated for endometriosis. No other hormonal intervention is recommended for managing this bleeding. Nonfunctional causes should also be borne in mind and in cases of undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, adequate diagnostic measures are indicated.

5. A decrease in glucose tolerance has been observed in some patients on progestogens. The mechanism of this decrease is obscure. For this reason, diabetic patients should be carefully observed while receiving progestogen therapy.
6. Patients who have a history of mental depression should be carefully observed and the drug discontinued if the depression recurs to a serious degree.
7. The age of the patient constitutes no absolute limiting factor although treatment with progestins may mask the onset of the climacteric.
8. The pathologist should be advised of progestin therapy when relevant specimens are submitted.
9. Gluteal infiltration and abscess formation may occur with intramuscular administration. See Dosage and Administration.

10. Certain endocrine and possible liver function tests may be affected by treatment with Depo-Provera. Therefore, if such tests are abnormal in a patient taking Depo-Provera, it is recommended that they be repeated after the drug has been withdraw.
Depo-Provera is not to be used as a test for pregnancy or where pregnancy is suspected.
Adverse Reactions
The following events listed in order of seriousness rather than frequency of occurrence, have been associated with the use of progestogens including medroxyprogesterone.
1. Anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid-like reactions.
2. Thromboembolic disease. Thrombophlebitis and pulmonary embolism.
3. Central nervous system. Nervousness, insomnia, somnolence, fatigue, depression, dizziness, headache and tremor.

4. Gluteal infiltration and abscess formation. This reaction appears to be related to the volume of agent administered and the highest frequency of this complication occurs with large volumes, ie. greater than 2.5 mL.
5. Skin and mucous membranes. Urticaria, pruritus, rash, acne, hirsutism, alopecia and sweating.
6. Gastrointestinal. Nausea.
7. Breast. Tenderness and galactorrhoea.
8. Cervix. Changes in erosion and secretions.
9. Miscellaneous. Hyperpyrexia, Cushing's syndrome, weight gain.

10. Moderate elevation of blood pressure, transient elevations of alkaline phosphatase and/or serum transaminase activities, elevations of serum calcium and potassium levels, and increase in white cell and platelet counts.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No.2) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91, Australia is in the middle of a recession that we are told we had to have, a recession which was engineered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), he tells us, for the purpose of cutting back imports into this country. SPEECH.PARA: We have already seen the case of the cruising yacht purchased by Qantas Airways Ltd, but not from an Australian builder. That, if nothing else, shows that the Offshore? What for? program is a sham.

The Government has been wholly incapable of explaining where that money went. It is seven months since I first tabled those documents in Parliament. What has happened? What public information have we received? What charges have been laid? What Government documents have been tabled in the Senate? None. Nothing. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: One of those suppliers was Boral Concrete, which at that stage was owed over $23,000 in overdue debts. This memorandum identifies one contractor, who in May was owed $16,800. I have yet to confirm it, but I believe it is the same contractor who 10 months later was still owed $60,000. It seems that this dividend may have been paid when the mill was broke or in the process of losing money. We must know how much was owed to the mill at the time the parent company paid the dividend. One of those related companies, I suspect, is Scotswood Street Pty Ltd, the ultimate holding company which, I am told, paid a dividend to its shareholders in the last six months of 1989. Senator Richardson continued:

That statement, with due respect to the Minister for Social Security-I know that the Minister did not prepare the statement, so I intend to let him off the hook a little-is arrant nonsense. When the sawmill went into receivership some 10 months later, the statement, the report as to the affairs of the company, showed it had a deficiency of assets to liabilities of $1,658,000. By a quirk of law, if a preference is paid to one creditor over other creditors it can be recovered under certain circumstances provided a liquidator has been appointed.
