The fall of 0.2 per cent in the March quarter CPI has produced, as everybody except probably people in the Opposition now knows, an annual inflation rate of 4.9 per cent. These are the facts which I want to refer Senator Sherry to. It is the lowest annual rate since December 1972.
—When?

—Since December 1972, and the lowest quarter rate since December 1963. I welcome the endorsement of this fact by both the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer. They welcomed this fact. As I heard them on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, they were not making the yahoo noises coming from the Opposition senators because, however great their deficiencies-and they are enormous-sometimes they are able to grasp a fact.

ANSWER.PARA: The 4.9 per cent annual rate of inflation now makes Australia a low inflation economy compared with many of our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development competitors. The OECD average inflation rate is 6.7 per cent. We now have an inflation rate lower than that of the United Kingdom, Canada, Italy and Sweden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Low inflation, high recession.
—Two of those countries-the United Kingdom and Canada-have a recession of the same order as ours.
—They don't have the unemployment.

—They have greater unemployment, old son! Now that their goddess Margaret Thatcher has gone, Opposition members do not come in here worshipping Mr Major with quite the same enthusiasm. The fact is that we have a lower inflation rate than the United Kingdom, Canada, Italy and Sweden; it is below the OECD average. This is very positive for Australia's future economic performance. We can now look forward to a period of sustained low inflationary growth. Today's inflation figure also confirms that Australia will maintain its attraction as a low labour cost location for manufacturing industry.
—Cut it out. They wouldn't touch you with a barge pole.

—I tell Senator Bos- well that the most recent edition of the Economist in London-not the Queensland banana growers' gazette-demonstrates this fact very well. Manufacturing labour costs, counting both wages and on-costs in Australia, are shown as the fifth lowest in a group of 20 major industrialised economies. I hope that Senator Boswell will take that information back to his constituency in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's rapid improvement in its ability to export complex manufactured goods, even into a recessed world economy, will be given an extra and well-timed boost. The inflation rate is also good news for businesses which have traditionally faced a higher cost of capital, as they have in all Anglo-Saxon countries, relative to our newly emerging competitors in the Asian region. I thank Senator Sherry for his question and for his astuteness and concern about the condition of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the Minister's great facility with figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, I refer him to the ABS estimates of unemployment levels in Australia. Has an estimate been made of the number of Australians forced to make do in part time work and who are therefore excluded from the unemployment figures, but who, in these recessionary times, really want, need, and are actively looking for full time jobs?

—These figures, in part, are reflected in the participation rate, about which a number of comments have been made. From my own experience, I am very concerned about the short time which is being worked in a number of manufacturing establishments that I have visited. I concede that that is an additional burden, following on from the downturn in the Australian economy, which, in a sense, adds to the ABS unemployment figures in terms of take-home earnings of a lot of employees. That is a difficulty. I am glad that Senator Michael Baume did not ask his question in terms of getting perpetual joy out of the unemployment figures in the way that some people ask questions about the unemployment issue.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his expression of concern, but I asked whether an estimate had been made. In passing, I must say that I cannot see how on earth part time workers would be reflected in the participation rate. If the Minister could help me on that matter, I would be most grateful. If no estimate has been made, for the sake of the young Australians who are now in a disastrous situation, will the Government find out how many of the 289,200 teenage part time workers, who make up almost half the total number of teenagers at work-giving, by the way, the lowest percentage ever recorded of full time workers-really want full time jobs and so represent a huge level of hidden full time unemployment on top of the present official figure of 25.8 per cent?

—I do not know why Senator Baume is asking me for the figures; he gave them to me himself in his supplementary question. What Senator Baume is asking for is something well beyond the scope of the ABS and he knows that. He is asking me for an attitudinal survey about the aspirations of people who are in part time work. That is beyond the capacity of the ABS.
—Are they seeking full time work?
—Anybody who is seeking full time work becomes a participant in the work force for those statistics. That is what I said earlier regarding the participation rate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister explain to the Senate why the Government has decided to provide financial support to the company Network Automation which is developing products conforming to new government standards, as reported in the Australian Financial Review last week?
—Another Kodak.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has a little giggle and refers to Kodak. Why does he not go down and have a look at what Kodak is doing instead of making such a mindless, giggling interjection? All these macho men on the other side are going to fix up all these issues with one stroke of the pen; they will legislate in the first week to fix the world's problems. That is what we are promised by the macho men in the Opposition. Most of them have been in politics about three weeks and they come up here and make these sorts of promises. They are amateur, hobby farmer politicians.

ANSWER.PARA: In the field of information technology, it has been traditional for all the major suppliers to provide systems that follow standards unique to the supplier company with the result that it is difficult for different brands of computers to work together. With the strong, worldwide support of users, including governments in Australia, the United States of America and the United Kingdom-Senator Hill would not do that; he would not offer any support-open standards have been developed to replace the older proprietary standards.

Important amongst these standards is the government open systems interconnection profile, known as GOSIP, which is now available for use in Australia and which will be a mandatory part of specifications in purchasing by Commonwealth agencies from 1 August 1991. I must say that Senator Bolkus is one of those to be congratulated on pursuing this question vigorously through the Government.

The growing adoption of open systems standards is a watershed in the information technology industry. Opposition senators should listen to this because in about 10 years time when they catch up with these movements in technology they will be able to ask questions about it at Estimates committees. That is something to think about for the future. Australian companies stand to benefit from the opening up of new markets provided they can meet demanding international criteria. The major information technology markets insist on advanced products with high reliability proven by operation. That is where the Government's national procurement development program (NPDP) comes in. The national procurement development program offers financial support for the trialling and demonstration of new products in the government agency.

This environment provides companies with the opportunity to develop new product lines consistent with user requirements. It also gives government agencies the chance to adopt the latest technologies with lower risk. It is encouraging to see companies such as Network Automation, which is the company Senator Crowley asked me about, making use of the NPDP to address an emerging market opportunity. That company has received a grant in respect of the NPDP. Although recently established, Network Automation has demonstrated its technological capability and has already made arrangements for overseas distribution of the fast packet switching systems, which will be trialled in the South Australian Justice Department under that program. Senator Crowley, as a South Australian senator, will be aware of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister comment on whether his answer has implications for patents, and the consequences to Australian companies as a result of those patents?
—I do not think so. Largely, when one is dealing with software it is such a fast-moving market that patents are not necessarily applicable.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to an article which appears in today's Australian Financial Review entitled `Final Countdown for Cape York Space Base'. Is it true that the Soviet Government is unlikely to retain its interest in the spaceport beyond the end of this year? As I know-because I have asked questions of him about this matter before-that the Minister would maintain contact with Queensland Premier Wayne Goss because of the joint land use study into Cape York, I ask: is it also true that the Queensland Government, in response to this Soviet anxiety, has hastily drawn up Aboriginal land rights legislation to also, coincidentally, be enacted by the end of this year and that that legislation contains a deal with the Cape York Land Council to drop its opposition to the spaceport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The joint land use study is being sponsored by the Australian Federal Government and the Queensland Government. There have always been concerns about two issues in respect of the spaceport: the environmental issue, which essentially leads to the land use study; and the Aboriginal issue.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as Soviet interest in the pro- ject is concerned, I do not know whether that report is correct. I think it may have emanated from somebody in Queensland who perhaps has an interest in the spaceport. But I saw the Soviet Ambassador only recently and had a brief discussion with him about this matter and I did not get that indication from him. I am not able to answer that part of the question relating to legislation, or proposed legislation, in the Queensland Parliament, but I will get an answer for the honourable senator as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice that the Government is flirting with public investment in the very fast train project via tax concessions to the consortium. Would the Minister at this stage rule out similar concessions for the spaceport consortium should one actually get its act together?

—The answer to that question is yes, and it has always been so. Right from the beginning of any consideration of the spaceport proposal it was said that it had to be a commercial activity not financed by government. The position has not changed in that regard. In so far as the honourable senator referred to our `flirting' with the very fast train proposal, we are very serious about these things; we do not `flirt'.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS FOR MEAT WORKERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Are people at Wodonga, Wangaratta and surrounding areas presently being refused social security benefits because they are said to belong to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, an organisation whose members are involved in a dispute with Wodonga Meats, or because they are allegedly engaged in industrial action? If so, what inquiries have been made by the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, or his delegates, to establish the basis of this refusal and, in particular, have those people who have been denied a pension been interviewed in each instance before a decision has been made against him or her? What procedure, if any, does the Department use to establish the facts necessary to bring subsection 116 (5) into operation? Does the Department ever make a decision to deny a pension based on hearsay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be no secret that there has been industrial action at Wodonga Meats for quite some time now. I am advised that that action has been going on for about 18 months. At present, that industrial action has taken the form of a reaction to the dismissal of a number of union delegates and some further steps have been taken by other employees who, themselves, have now been given notices of dismissal.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, they are all members of the Australasian Meat Employees Union. Of course, they would not be refused benefit because of their union membership but, rather, because of the Social Security Act which does preclude payment of unemployment benefit to members of a union involved in industrial action. The members of the Meat Employees Union who have been employed at Wodonga Meats and who have applied for unemployment benefit have had their claims rejected. Of course, that industrial action is still proceeding.

The Department has obtained information from both the employer and individuals as they have come in to make their claims in relation to the reason for the unemployment. There has been no necessity, in the view of the Department, to interview any of the people concerned, because we are getting claim forms setting out the position as well as information from the employer.

In deciding whether or not to apply that section of the Act which does preclude payment to people engaged in industrial action, the Department would normally seek information from the claimant, the union, the employer and perhaps the Department of Industrial Relations, if it was felt necessary, or even the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. So on this occasion the Department thinks that it has got plenty of evidence, which does not appear, I might say, to be disputed. So it has not seen fit to conduct interviews. That does not mean that we take decisions on hearsay. We believe that there is enough evidence.

Obviously, the spouses of striking workers may be eligible for unemployment benefit. Indeed, some have applied and been successful. Others might be eligible for special benefit. Again, some have applied and been successful. Otherwise, there is not much joy for those meat workers in making unemployment benefit claims. Senator Cooney might recall that Senator Grimes tried to amend this section of the Act in a number of ways in 1983-84, and that attempt failed. I am not sure if we will have another go; it might not be worth the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the report in today's Age newspaper that Senator Button is terribly worried about the likely surge in long term unemployment next year and the associated social problems. Does the Minister agree with this assessment? I ask the Minister how he now feels about what he told the Senate on 5 October 1983 when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I might say that the Labor Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. It recognises its responsibilities in this area and if it fails over the years to meet the problem of unemployment it will not be elected again, and it will not deserve to be.
Does he now agree that, on the basis of the present situation and Senator Button's prediction, not only will the Government not be elected again but will not deserve to be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button informs me that the view ascribed to him by Senator Alston was not his view but rather the view of someone talking to him. I have not actually seen the report in the Age, so I do not know any more about it than that. But I always accept the word of my leader.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of remarks that I made on 5 October 1983, I think jobs were the main reason that Labor was elected. I think jobs were the main reason that we were re-elected three times after that. The reason that jobs were able to get us elected again and again is the 1.5 million jobs that have been created during the time of the Hawke Labor Government. In recent times, obviously, unemployment has jumped. That is neither good for those who are unemployed or their families nor a help to the government in power at the time. Nonetheless, the downturn, the recession, is only short term; unemployment will pick up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment will pick up?

—Employment will pick up. At the next election, we will happily debate with the Opposition who is better to run Australia. I have no doubt that the Australian people will make the same decision as they have made the last four times in a row.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The first part of the Minister's answer to the second part of my question suggested that somehow the quotation related to his claims in relation to employment, whereas in fact it clearly quoted the Minister as saying that the Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. Does he resile from what he said then, that the Government will stand or fall by its record on unemployment-not employment growth-and, if it fails on that test, it does not deserve to be elected? If they were merely weasel words, can he explain what has happened in the interim?

—I am not sure that Senator Alston wants me to explain during Question Time what has happened from October 1983 up until now. That might take a few more minutes. Unemployment was certainly an issue. I did not resile from that in the words that I just gave; I said that jobs were the issue. Jobs were the issue in 1983-a lack of them. In subsequent elections, the growth in their numbers was a very big factor in Labor's re-election. Obviously, the number of jobs will be a factor in the next election. There is no question that we will all be debating the issue of jobs ad nauseam, so I am not weaseling or wimping out of anything. I would have thought that my remarks were relatively clear.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given industry demands for greater uniformity in government regulation of occupational health and safety, and given also the growing recognition at forums such as the recent Premiers Conference that national uniformity is a necessary prerequisite for enhancing micro-economic reform through improved productivity in all sectors of industry, I ask the Minister: what progress is being made towards implementing national uniformity in the area of occupational health and safety? Can the Minister also indicate how Australia compares with other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, especially those, such as the United States of America and the European Community, with similar cultural and business environments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can tell Senator Beahan that, as one can see from the submissions that various sectors of industry have made to the review of occupational health and safety in Australia, industry has quite clearly made forthright calls for greater uniformity in occupational health and safety law in this country. Many of the submissions made by employer groups have been based on experiences that they or their constituent affiliates have had in the United States or the European Community. In the United States, for example, national standards have been mandatory since Congress in 1970 passed the Occupational Safety and Health Act. That Act requires the United States National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health to take action on behalf of all workers in the United States to ensure that there is a minimum standard of safe working conditions in that country.

ANSWER.PARA: In the European Community, uniformity in occupational health and safety regulations will be achieved by the end of 1992 with the closer integration of that Community. The main motive behind this push for national uniformity-without in any way denigrating the socially just nature of many of these reforms-is an economic one. It is recognised by companies that it is certainly more efficient, in particular for national companies or companies thinking of investment in more than one State, to have a common set of standards for occupational health and safety that must be observed. I will give two classic examples. There is obviously a need to have a common coding standard for chemicals in use rather than, in a country such as Australia, six different standards, one for each State. In the certificating of plant and equipment from a safety point of view, there is also a real need to see that the standards between States are the same.

The Ministers for Labour Advisory Council, which consists of all of the State and Territory Ministers plus me, has reaffirmed its determination to set national uniform standards for occupational health and safety in Australia. The debate there is about what level of standard should apply. We certainly do not want to see national standards arise which are at the lowest common denominator. We want to see national standards arise which reflect the need for uniformity and also observe a level of reasonableness and fairness in protecting workers from injury or disease at work.

From the Commonwealth's point of view-and I am sure Senator Beahan shares these sentiments-we wish to see that common standard in Australia arise quickly. That relates to what the Premiers have said at previous Premiers Conferences about micro-economic reform and the need to speed that up by getting standards in other areas of industry as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) assessment of the tragic unemployment levels in Australia and I ask: is it a fact that the real level of unemployment is closer to 20 per cent rather than the official 10 per cent if allowance is made for all the artificial devices used by the Government to hide the real job shortage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The real level, as Senator Walters puts it to me, does not become real just because Peter Reith says it is. That is what he and John Hewson have said.
—What do you say?

—I say that the rate of unemployment as fixed or determined by the ABS is the rate of unemployment. In addition to that, I concede that there are additional burdens imposed on people as a result of short-time work and things of that kind. But to come up with a figure of 20 per cent from a whole range of factors such as that is an extraordinary exercise of the imagination.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sorry to introduce a literary reference in this place but it reminds me of Glendower in Henry IV, where he says, `I can summon spirits from the vasty deep' to which Hotspur replies, `Yes, but will they come?'. That is what Opposition senators are trying to do. They are trying to summon figures from the vasty deep to characterise a tragic problem as much worse than it is and, ultimately, to try to get their backsides on the government benches, by summoning these sorts of figures from the deep.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I find it tragic that the Minister jokes about this, and I can assure him that we are not summoning figures from the vasty deep. I ask him: is it a fact that, if a person works for just one hour a week, whether paid or unpaid, that person is excluded from the Government's unemployment figures as a result of that so-called work? If the Minister does acknowledge that the Government has some devious exclusion plans, can he tell us what the unemployment figure really is?

—I have already said, in the earlier part of my answer, that the statistician determines the numbers and the methodology, as he has always done. I resent the misrepresentation by Senator Walters that I tried to turn a tragic situation into a joke. What I did, and it is something which I have done for the last few years, is recognise that Opposition senators are a joke. The joke is over there. That is a very serious problem which at times makes me sad and at times provides me with a sense of light relief.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the report Immigration and its Labour Market Impact in the Northern Territory written by Dr John Taylor of the Australian National University for the Bureau of Immigration Research and recently released? If so, has the Minister's attention been directed to the case study on the Darwin trade development zone and labour immigration? Can the Minister inform the Senate what legislative changes have been made, partly as a result of underpayments to Chinese workers by textile and clothing companies operating out of the Darwin trade development zone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report entitled Immigration and its Labour Market Impact in the Northern Territory which has been published and which was reported on, I thought very fairly, in the Australian today. The report by Dr John Taylor is critical of the Trade Development Zone Authority. The damning words deserve quoting here. The report says:

ANSWER.PARA: Given the fact that part of (its) task was to assist in sponsoring visa applications and provide the main point of contact with prospective employers, the Zone Authority's facilitating role appears to have consisted not so much as turning a blind eye to company activities but simply not bothering to ask appropriate questions in the first place.
I am pleased that that has now been published as an objective finding. It is certainly what we said in government at the time when we asked that the trade development zone clean up its act.

One will recall that back then Chinese guest workers were brought into Australia, kept in barracks, paid a rate well under the award and not given their legal entitlements. In some cases there was innuendo that they would be deported in disgrace back to China if they spoke at all to unions. I know that some of them had clandestine meetings with unions in order to discover what their rights were, and later unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions made representations on their behalf. Later they were told that even if they were paid something in terms of their proper legal entitlement, that would be taken off them by the agents when they returned to the People's Republic of China.

The Department of Industrial Relations at that time investigated the particular case of Hengyang Darwin and Hengyang Holdings. Seventy workers were employed by both those companies. We found that underpayments of wages and superannuation totalled $684,000. Of that amount we have recovered $220,000 for wages and superannuation payments. We believe that there is more to be recovered, but what is a sad fact is that a substantial amount of the due and proper legal entitlement of these people will not be recovered in the events that have followed since.

One of the problems with this trade development zone has now been remedied legislatively with the aid of the Australian Democrats in changing the Federal Industrial Relations Act late last year. There is now a requirement that there be kept in a standard format proper time and wages records. In the investigations we found that no proper records were kept by the employers and therefore we were not able to pin down exactly what the amount of money owing was. Where people are non-union members they can now at law, as a result of the legislative changes last year, obtain back pay when they have been underpaid. That is a further improvement that has been made in the Act.

I think that the final improvement we have made is quite significant, too. If it is now found that workers have not had superannuation funds-the right employer superannuation contribution-lodged on their behalf, the amount of contribution can be recovered and lodged for them, plus what that amount would have earned had it been lodged at the proper time. With the program by my Department to disseminate this information to employers more widely and with this report turning a spotlight on the trade development zone, an example will be made and information will now be supplied to prevent this sort of practice growing further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister for Social Security explain why, in the year to April 1991, the rise in unemployment beneficiaries in my home State of Victoria has been more than three times greater than the rise in the Minister's own home State of New South Wales, which has a Liberal Government?
—I am responsible for the payment of unemployment benefit, not for economic management. That question should be directed to the appropriate Minister.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of the leading example being set for Australian industry by the carpet wool industry? Does the Minister agree that the carpet wool industry has properly adopted the Government's stated objectives of adding value to Australia's wool, competing aggressively, imaginatively and flexibly on the open world market, and reducing Australia's reliance on imported raw materials? What action will the Minister take to inform others of this industry's value to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Bell asked this question. I am a real rap for the carpet industry.
—Because you are generally on the carpet.
—Not as a result of any of the blows that have been inflicted here, I can assure Senator Panizza.
—He means standing on it.

—Standing on the carpet or standing on Senator Crichton-Browne, as I have to do from time to time. I am very grateful to Senator Bell for this question. I have consistently pointed to the carpet industry as being a successful part of the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. It is certainly one sector of the textiles, clothing and footwear industry which has taken the restructuring message to heart.

ANSWER.PARA: The carpet industry to which Senator Bell referred was one of the first industry bodies to write me a letter following the March industry statement, accepting the challenge-as it put it-of restructuring in its industry and saying that it totally accepted it and would take it up. The carpet industry has seen a quite spectacular growth in exports recently. For example, in the six months to December 1990, compared with the six months to December 1989, exports in this industry more than doubled. In fact, there was an increase of 84 per cent in exports. Of all the grants made by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority prior to the March statement, 21 per cent went to carpet manufacturers whose production represents 7 per cent of the total output of the textiles, clothing and footwear industry.

I believe this is a testimony to how seriously this industry is taken and has to be taken. I also believe that part of that success can be attributed to the close relationship which has now developed between the carpet wool growers and the processors, the carpet manufacturers, in recent years. Under the protection of a fixed floor price plan for wool, for example, or under the high manufacturing protection in some industries, the relationship between suppliers of primary products and producers of manufactured products in this country was very bad. There was a lot of waste and a lot of uncoordination of productive effort.

About 64 per cent of all wool processed to yarn or fabric in Australia is processed by the carpet industry. Until recently most of that wool-about $100m-worth a year-was imported. The development of the local carpet wool industry has helped to replace these imports and to enhance the value of the exports of finished carpet. The wool tax decision in October last year-that is, exempting coarser wools of 32 microns and above from the market support component of the wool tax for two years-took these factors into account. I am sure that my colleague Mr Kerin as responsible Minister will give very careful consideration to all these factors once again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Government received advice from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on its political advertising legislation which includes: that development of the legislation is impermissible under the covenant; that the most serious effect of this ban relates to its impact on the accessibility of information for the blind and other sight impaired Australians, who presently number 110,000, and the more than one million Australians who are functionally illiterate; that a ban on political advertising in the electronic media is likely to have a discriminatory impact on their right to take part in public affairs; and that the distinction between free speech and bought speech is neither sustainable nor helpful in the context of ascertaining our international legal obligations? And does he agree with that advice?

—In terms of advice that the Government has received on our proposal, I have made it clear a couple of times-in fact, in answer to Senator Olsen's question yesterday-that we have acted on the advice of our legal advisers and the Attorney-General's Department in formulating and presenting the legislation. Senator Olsen asks whether we have had advice from the Human Rights Commission on the legislation. I said yesterday that when the Human Rights Commission developed its comments on our proposal, it was doing just that-on the proposal and not on the legislation. I also said that discussions with the Human Rights Commissioner are an ongoing process of consultation with the Commission. In response to Senator Olsen's question I also added that that consultation is ongoing and that, as such, it would be inappropriate to table the Commissioner's advice. I have nothing further to add.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given the Minister's refusal to table the advice from the Human Rights Commission, can he explain why, by hiding this advice, he is clearly putting party political considerations before such a basic democratic right as freedom of expression and speech?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is hardly a supplementary question but, then again, it is not surprising that Senator Olsen would raise a matter such as this. I have made it quite clear that the advice we are getting is part of the consultative process; I have said that from the start. I have also made it very clear that the Government has acted on the very clear advice of our legal advisers in the Attorney-General's Department.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Olsen made some allegation about party political motivations and whatever. I have also made it very clear that the Government's motivation in this area is to respond to a very growing and real problem in our community. It is a problem that Senator Olsen recognised in a press statement that he put out on the weekend about the Government's disclosure Bill. When putting out that press statement, it was very clear that Senator Olsen attempted, in a low level party political way, to mislead the Australian public.

We, on this side of the Parliament, are concerned about something that those opposite are not concerned about; and that is to ensure that the costs of campaigning are reduced to a level where we do not have a continuation of inquiries into the relationship between the corporate sector and government, so that in the future people such as Tony Eggleton cannot say that donors get easier access to Prime Ministers and so that we do not have a continuation of a system in which people such as Commissioner Roden, in the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales, can say:
So long as substantial donations can be made to political parties or candidates without disclosure, they can be used to purchase influence.

The only way to remove that sort of problem from our political system is to do two things. One is to reduce the need of parties for campaign funds. The only effective way to do that is what we are doing here-this has been done elsewhere throughout the world-and that is put a ban on paid advertising. Secondly, we can introduce disclosure legislation.

Senator Olsen mentions party political motivation. I read his press statement on the weekend. I notice that it was about the Government's disclosure Bill. He called it a trick; he said that it was not absolute disclosure. We, on this side, made it very clear at the start that we would be surprised were the Opposition to stick with its expressed position supporting our disclosure legislation; I will still be surprised. It will be even more surprising because of the sorts of things that Senator Olsen has been saying. In his press statement Senator Olsen said:
. . . there is absolutely no mention of unions' disclosure of the compulsory millions of dollars in affiliation fees and other donations which they pass on to the ALP each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chapman asked me a question yesterday in which he asserted that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) ignores Australian women composers. The ABC has provided me with the following information in response to Senator Chapman's question. The arts programming policy for Radio National and ABC FM is to increase the number of contemporary women represented as creative artists, which includes composers. The policy is constrained, however, by the limited amount of relevant material actually recorded and available for broadcasting. The ABC understands that all arts commissioning editors are aware of the need to seek out and encourage women to write special features and to record women's music wherever possible in live broadcasts.

The second, to be released in July, is a recording of three Australian violin concertos, including Margaret Sutherland's violin concerto. Discussions are also taking place with a view to releasing an all women composers disc of orchestral, chamber or instrumental music.

With regard to Musica Nova, the ABC coordinated the festival in Brisbane and was responsible for the commissioning of six Australian composers. The composers were chosen to showcase Queensland work on the basis of artistic criteria relating to the general theme of the festival-an exploration of recent attitudes to modernism. The individuals and organisations which were invited to perform made their own choices of composers, constrained only by the requirement that Australian works programmed should concentrate on Queensland composers, and that the work of four visiting composers be included if possible. The ABC selected and sponsored the overseas composers, one of whom was Sophia Gubaidulina.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 15 May, from Senator Short:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to section 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Government's economic policies, which have led to the most severe recession since the Great Depression, and its total inability to pursue the policies necessary to restore hope and economic growth to the Australian community.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Government's economic policies, which have led to the most severe recession since the Great Depression, and its total inability to pursue the policies necessary to restore hope and economic growth to the Australian community.

In doing so, I welcome Senator Button as I see that he will follow me in this debate. It is a great surprise to see Senator Button join in this debate. To my recollection, it is the first time that Senator Button has participated in an economic debate of this nature in the life of this present Parliament. I can only take that as an indication that, at long last, the Government is realising the seriousness of the dramatic downturn that is occurring in the Australian economy at great cost and hardship to virtually every Australian-hardship that has been caused, without any doubt at all, by the failure of this Government and its inability to pursue responsible policies to put our great nation on the right path for the 1990s and into the next century.

Yesterday was the fifth anniversary of `banana republic' statement day. The Senate will recall that on that day, 14 May 1986, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said some very serious and very sensible things. In an interview on the John Laws radio program he was asked what would happen if we did not get out of the economic hole we were in at that time-a hole, I must point out, that had already been dug by that Government, of which Mr Keating had been Treasurer for over three years at that stage. When he was asked what would happen if we did not get out of the economic hole, he said:

. . . The fall-back solution is inevitable because you can't fund $12 billion a year [current account deficit] in perpetuity every year, and then the interest on the year before that, and the interest on the year before that. The only thing to do is slow the growth to a canter. Once you slow the growth under 3 per cent, unemployment starts to rise again . . . Then you have gone. You are a Banana Republic.

The Treasurer was right in what he said at that time. So what have his policies, which were designed to avoid this very situation, produced? The short answer is that they have produced precisely what the Treasurer said in 1986 must not be produced. At that time he said that if we did not get out of the economic hole we were in then-a hole that had been dug by the Treasurer himself-we would have to close the economy down. I will quote the Treasurer precisely. In those circumstances, he said:
You cut all growth to zero, you stop all the imports growing and unemployment starts rising again, and profits fall apart . . .

We need to cut through all of the Treasurer's mindless rhetoric of recent years-such as his famous statement of the 1988 or 1989 Budget, `This Budget brings home the bacon'; his infamous, `This is a beautiful set of figures' statement; his `We've pursued fiscal rectitude' statement; his `We've fundamentally restructured the economy' statement; and his unbelievable statement made in the last Budget Speech only eight or nine months ago when he had the audacity to say:
Australia has negotiated a difficult transition over the past 12 months-from an economy where spending and growth were overblown to an economy with lower activity and fewer imports.
He continued:
Tonight I am able to report that we are emerging from this phase in fundamentally better shape having succeeded in this transition.
Further on he said:
The faith the Australian people exhibited in the Government at the election-
the election in March of last year, two days before which he said that under no circumstances were we going to let any recession happen-
is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth without a catastrophic collapse.
This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.
In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
He said that the Government had had its trust put in it by the Australian people. He also said:
Tonight's Budget-
that is, the last Budget, the Budget of eight or nine months ago-
is just about that.

That is, about trust. Cutting through all of that rhetoric, that absolutely grossly misleading attempt to fool the Australian people into believing that the hardship that was being induced was not there, what do we find? We find that today, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 844,000 people are out of work-the highest figure ever recorded by the Bureau. That is 9.9 per cent of the work force; more than 10 per cent in five of the six Australian States-the only exception being the Liberal State of New South Wales.

The figure of 9.9 per cent-which compares with the figure of 7.9 per cent at the time of the banana republic statement-includes youth unemployment at a criminal 27 per cent. In reality, the unemployment level in Australia is much higher than those figures. The Commonwealth Employment Service has more than one million people seeking jobs-12.4 per cent of the work force. If we add people who are working fewer than 15 hours a week or fewer hours than they wish, the unemployment figure is almost 20 per cent.

Today, my colleague Senator Alston quoted a statement made in 1983 by Senator Richardson, which I think and hope will come back to haunt him-although he is pretty hard to haunt-that the Government was elected to get unemployment down and that if it does not do that it does not deserve to govern. That is absolutely right. That is the situation that has existed since then.

So much for the Treasurer's beautiful unemployment figures; so much for a current account deficit still running at an annual rate of $16 billion to $18 billion a year; so much for our ever escalating foreign debt, now in excess of $150 billion compared with $93 billion on the day that the banana republic statement was made and compared with $7 billion only 10 years ago; so much for interest payments on that debt, now requiring more than 20c in every dollar of export earnings, one-quarter higher than it was just five years ago; so much for our bankruptcy rate, up 52 per cent over the last year; so much for real interest rates, running at some 10 per cent, the highest in the Western world, and crippling business and households alike; and so much for a massive deterioration in the Government's budgetary position and the budgetary position of the public sector in Australia as a whole, again brought about essentially by the policies of the Government.

The bottom line of all of this is a fall in the nation's production in four of the last five quarters to December 1990 and almost certainly again in the March quarter 1991. In other words, we are in the worst recession since the 1930s-the worst recession for 60 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The March 1990 quarter was the highest.
—It is the only quarter in the last five where the Government has had a positive figure.
—Don't come in here telling fibs.
—Senator Button will have his chance in a minute.
—Would you like a copy of this morning's Age?

—Yes, does Senator Button want a copy of today's Age? Senator Button had to make a statement. These are the facts of the grim reality of our economic situation. These are the facts that prompted the last Hawke Government Finance Minister, Senator Walsh, to say last week that Australia is arguably not still in a recession, but a depression. Views such as these have been voiced increasingly by those at the coalface in the business community. The Business Council of Australia found, in a survey only two days ago, that three-quarters of all the respondents expected further sharp falls in both employment and investment over the next 12 months following the dramatic falls, particularly in employment, that have occurred in the past 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Comments have been made by business leaders. Two days ago the Coles-Myer Finance Director said that the economy has not yet bottomed. Philip Brass of Pacific Dunlop Ltd, one of the major companies in this nation, said that he expected no change in the very low demand for buildings, plant and equipment with the level of economic activity down 8 to 10 per cent on the same period last year and the potential for several months of further decline. Ian Webber from Mayne Nickless said that the company is still experiencing extremely difficult trading conditions and he would not want to suggest any sign of relief.

Even Senator Button's own Department's Construction Forecasting Committee is predicting a deeper slump in construction activity than occurred in the 1970s, and lasting until 1993-94. Also, that Committee has expressed concern at the signs that the investment climate is still not favourable for major projects which are internationally mobile. That is also a very conservative statement. Two days ago the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) found, in a survey of 168 executives, that 94 per cent of those executives thought current trading conditions were poor, very poor, or depressed, and 90 per cent found the investment climate to be the same. Ian Spicer, the Executive Director of the CAI, says that business confidence is unbelievably low. He says that the business community is angry about the cavalier way in which the Government has decided to cure our economic problems, irrespective of the hardship that it will cause for industry.

The coalition welcomes today's fall in the inflation rate as measured by the consumer price index (CPI). It is a welcome figure; it provides welcome relief from the continuing bad economic news. But it is the least that could be expected from an economy that has been so brutally bludgeoned for so long by the Hawke Government. I put it to Senator Button-and I hope that he will respond to this in the manner in which it is put-that the trick now is to ensure that, when the economy finally claws its way out of protracted recession, it does not drag the CPI back up with it. The Treasurer's recent comment that beating inflation was `like snapping a stick' indicates that the Government has no real idea of just what is required to achieve a sustainable low inflation environment. That is also apparent from the fact that the Treasurer conspicuously turned his back on the inflation problem until he opportunistically picked it up as his latest pet issue a few months ago because he saw the inflation rate falling due to the recession-induced impact. He thought that he would get a bit of political mileage out it in his continuing run for the prime ministership.

How much less painful the path to lower inflation could have been if the Treasurer had adopted monetary policy for its proper role-that is, the role of fighting inflation-from the start. He should regard today's drop in the CPI as a very lucky break. To keep on that lower inflation path, the Treasurer must now recognise his past mistakes. The Government now needs to lock in lower inflation over the longer term and salvage one lasting benefit from the unnecessary destruction of our productive base and the hurt to millions of Australians that the Treasurer has caused. The Government should announce immediately a clear and coherent anti-inflationary strategy. It should clearly articulate the costs of inflation and quantify these where possible. It should give an unequivocal commitment that inflation will be a priority for the Government over the rest of its term.

As the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said today, the Government should target an inflation figure of nought to 2 per cent over the remainder of its term of office, and it should give the Reserve Bank greater independence and a charter to tackle inflation as its sole objective. The coalition is working on plans to do just that when it returns to government. Together with a clear and believable anti-inflationary strategy the Government must also get serious about the structural reform which it trumpets but from which emerges virtually no results. Only if it puts in place the correct structural policies will the creation of a lasting, sustainable, internationally competitive low inflation environment be achievable.

The coalition has offered the Government the hand of bipartisanship to achieve this. The Government will have, and knows it will have, our full support to implement a comprehensive program of structural change, including, most importantly, genuine enterprise bargaining and reform of the labour market, land transport, coastal shipping, the waterfront and telecommunications, if it seriously embraces privatisation and the other public sector reforms, including reshaping the tax system by the introduction of a broadly based goods and services tax.

All the indications, tragically for the Australian economy and the Australian people, are, however, that these reforms will not be forthcoming from the Government. Why? It is because the Government and the Treasurer in particular refuse to accept the blame where it fairly and squarely lies-at its own feet, at the feet, quite clearly, of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer. This deep and unnecessary recession that we are now having is Hawke-led and Keating-driven, but the Government blindly refuses to accept this.

Yesterday the Prime Minister and the Treasurer blamed everyone but themselves for our present situation. The Treasurer kept blaming consumers for spending too much in 1988 and 1989. He blamed the banks. He said it was the banks' fault because asset inflation took off and gross domestic product was squandered. He blamed the employers, saying that they were trying to throw 15 per cent wage increases to employees if only they would take it. But the daddy of them all was that he claimed that the recent deterioration in the terms of trade had been the main cause of his problem.

Yesterday the Treasurer really went over the top on that. He said that with halfway decent terms of trade it would be `game, set and match' for the economy in the 1990s. Let us look at this heroic assertion which the Treasurer has been throwing around for some time and which is even getting some credence with the economic commentators. It is an absolute nonsense. It is correct that the terms of trade are a relevant factor influencing our economic performance but they are by no means the primary influence. But even if they were, what do the figures show? They show that in the March quarter of 1989 Australia's terms of trade reached a 1980s high. Although they have since fallen by 11.7 per cent from that 1980s peak, they are still higher than at any time between the June 1985 quarter and the March 1988 quarter. The period from March 1988 until very recently was a period of better than average terms of trade. To hear the Treasurer bleat, one would think that the terms of trade had done him wrong. That is absolutely not true. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a graph demonstrating these facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Treasurer, who has deliberately, to use his own words, `pulled the levers' to engineer the recession-as Senator Peter Walsh rightly says, arguably a depression-said in March 1990, two days before the Federal election, that we were not going to have that recession, but only eight months later we had to have it. SPEECH.PARA: This has occurred because of blind ambitions on the part of certain members of the Government, notably the Treasurer. It has arisen because of the Government's inability to pursue consistent policies to have the right objectives for economic policy, namely, an eye on the ball in getting inflation down. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this urgency motion. I am surprised at Senator Short's suggestion that I should come in here on every occasion that he moves one of these motions and recycles the same material. Senator Short's speech was an incantation of difficulties with current economic indicators, from which he seems to obtain great joy.
—Not at all.

—Yes, he does. That is not the Government's position at all. I suppose one of the greatest things in historical terms which hurts Senator Short, or ought to if he has any sensitivity at all, is that we had a Treasurer who was able to make the banana republic statement. SPEECH.PARA: When asked whether a Liberal government of the future, if there is one, would have the courage to do these things which they have never had the courage to do in the past, Mr McLachlan says, as President Bush said, `Read my lips'. I do not know whether the government will have the courage, and this is a nice question for the Opposition. The Opposition has got itself into the unfortunate position of having its principal policy statements made by a leader who spends half his press conferences trying to prove that he is not a yuppie, and by people like Mr McLachlan whose attitude to politics is one of crass amateurism.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the sort of speech we would expect from Senator Faulkner.
—The honourable senator knows what I am talking about. He knows the words of Waltzing Matilda:

SPEECH.PARA: Up came the squatter mounted on his thoroughbred;
Down came the troopers-one, two and three.

That is what Ian McLachlan is all about. In relation to all these issues that Senator Short mentions, Mr McLachlan is here, as he says, to do a few things and then retire gracefully, as his lifestyle has always dictated. As they say in South Australia, as Senator Teague knows, `You can always tell a McLachlan. There are lots of them here, but you can't tell them anything'. The approach to this issue which I want to deal with as simply as possible is to say that, in spite of all Senator Short's windy rhetoric, this Government concedes the depth of the current recession and we concede the very severe impact that the current recession is having on many people. I also wish in my remarks to stress the cyclical and short term nature of this recession and look at the overall fundamentals of the Australian economy, the expectations regarding an improvement of these conditions, and the structural improvements on the supply side of the economy.

There has been a lot of discussion as to whether the current recession has bottomed out, as they say, and whether there is likely to be an immediate or short term upturn in the Australian economy. In that respect, I think that today's inflation rate will be a helpful signal. I can best summarise these issues by referring to an article by Alan Wood, Economics Editor of the Australian newspaper, on 14 May when he looked at the indicators in the Australian economy. In that article he described some people as talking about the indicators as `straws in the wind', and quoted the Business Council of Australia survey, to which Senator Short referred. That survey stated:
Overall, the results suggest that the slump in domestic activity has slowed and may be near bottom.

TALK.START.PARA: —The slump has slowed.

—In other words, it is still going down. The slump has slowed.

—It rather sounds as if you did not understand it.

—It may be near bottom. I tell Senator Short that I do understand the language. Alan Wood made another reference to the highly regarded Dunn and Bradstreet survey of business expectations and said that the track record of that survey had been good; it covered a large sample of firms. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Its latest survey, for the second quarter of 1991, seems to suggest that the trough of recession has been reached.
Mr Wood then referred to Dr Duncan Ironmonger, who prepared a comment based on the survey. Dr Ironmonger stated:
It is still too early to put firm dates on when the actual levels of business sales will start to rise. However, if interest rates and inflation continue to fall-
I must remind honourable senators that falls in interest rates were the largest component, apart from transport equipment, in the consumer price index fall-
we can expect rising sales in September quarter 1991 and the levels of employment and profits starting to rise in the first quarter of 1992.
Alan Wood went on to say:
This is the most optimistic private survey . . . but Dr Ironmonger is not alone in his view.

Mr Wood then referred to the stock market indicators and said that, although economists were sometimes suspicious of the stock market, it had quite often been right. I mention those things because I want to emphasise that it is no good my coming in here as a government spokesman and saying that there is any joy for us, as honourable senators know, in the circumstances of this recession. I have said on numerous occasions that as a government we, together with the wide sectors of the economics profession, clearly misread some of the indicators, or lagged indicators as they were last year.

Indeed, if one seeks alternative advice from the Opposition on this sort of thing, one finds that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was saying much the same thing in many statements. For example, in February of this year he made the point:
I don't see any particular month's figures as a trigger one way or other in relation to monetary policy. I would say though that monetary policy has already eased quite significantly.

Dr Hewson went on to talk about interest rates falling as the economy slowed down and said that he considered that was an official judgment that had to be made. He made some speculative observations in June 1990 when he said:
The Prime Minister is wrong to say is that . . . inflation will fall to 6 per cent in the 12 months to June 1991.
That was about the Budget forecast. In fact, the inflation rate will be below the Budget forecast. He also said:
. . . the Prime Minister simply appears to be out of touch with both domestic and international thinking on inflation.

The figure on inflation is getting out of touch with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Our inflation rate is lower than that of many of our trading partners in Europe and North America.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is their economic growth rate? They have positive economic growth.

—I do not have those figures here, but they are not high. The United States of America and Canada are in a severe recession. The United Kingdom (UK) is in a severe recession and has much higher inflation and much higher unemployment than we do.
—They have not had recession for the last 18 months as we have.
—Senator Short can make those sorts of interjections. I am just trying to choke him with a few facts, which is not a bad thing.
—Well, get your figures right.

—They are right: unemployment and inflation are higher in the UK; the UK economy is in deep recession. Year after year Senator Short would walk in here telling me what a great lady Margaret Thatcher was and telling about all those wonderful things that those opposite would do, but would never have had the guts to do. She was a folk hero. But now they have forgotten all about her because there has been a deep recession in the United Kingdom, as there is in North America. Senator Short cannot have it all possible ways in here, not with my responding to him as he invited me to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put this in perspective. Of course the policy induced aspect of the recession is of severe concern to the Government. But many other factors have been affecting the problem in Australia. These are not present in Britain, the United Kingdom or Canada. Firstly, there is the impact of the rural recession here, which is very large and largely associated with international commodity prices and inability to gain market access. Secondly, of course, there are the corporate collapses from the excesses of the 1980s, which were well under way before the recession. I think everybody in this country misread the effects of the 1987 stock market crash on this country. Those corporate collapses have led to all sorts of extraordinary behaviour, as I said at Question Time, by the banks and financial institutions, which have not been as supportive of the productive sector of the Australian economy as they were of the Alan Bonds of this world during the 1980s. The current recessionary circumstances have to be seen in that context.
Throughout all this period, the Opposition, which is a legitimate function for an Opposition, has persistently drawn attention to one major factor, and that is unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Foreign debt; balance of payments problem; productivity.

—Senator Kemp, who rusted out in a right wing think-tank earlier in his life, comes up here and introduces a few old statistics into the argument by way of interjection. Day after day the burden of the Opposition's questioning has been about unemployment.
—It is much more than unemployment; you know that.

—No, I said, `The burden' of the Opposition's questions. Senator Short swans in here about one in every third Question Time. He accuses me of not being in the chamber to answer his idiotic speeches, but he comes in here only about one in every third Question Time. It takes him two days to prepare a question. He then comes in here and asks it on the third day. That is the problem which Senator Short has, but let me--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult for me to follow an argument with this continual discussion. It is interrupting the flow of what I think Opposition senators should be aware of and learn. Even death is a learning experience, and when I confront honourable senators opposite, I am very conscious of that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking forward, this recession will end and improvements in the Australian economy will appear. The performance of Australian industry gives me great confidence that Australia will be well placed to meet the challenges of the 1990s. When one asks the Opposition about these issues and about its economic stance-as I showed using quotations from Dr Hewson and others-one sees that it offers very little alternative except this rhetoric which Dr Hewson engaged in again today. When asked how he would fix all this, he answered:

We will introduce a comprehensive program of structural change, more genuine enterprise bargaining, reform of the labour market, land transport, coastal shipping, the waterfront, telecommunications, privatisation, other public sectors reform, including the reshaping of the tax system and so on.

That is the rhetoric pattern of the Opposition which, in all its 30 years in government, never addressed any of these issues. Was waterfront reform or transport reform ever heard of when the Liberals were in office? Why was it not heard of? Because the Opposition cushioned manufacturers with high tariffs. If a company were trading in Malaysia it just came up here to see Malcolm Fraser and it got a special quota. Manufacturers got high tariffs and were protected from the outside world. The Opposition now comes back and talks to us about international competitiveness. All these issues are on the agenda, not because those opposite put them there but because we did. We have made huge structural changes in the Australian economy which were never attempted in the past. Low inflation will underpin the improvements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like what?

—We have a structural fiscal surplus; a strong growth in merchandise exports-something that those opposite never had-a good share of business fixed investment; a healthier profit share; a much more rational tax system; and, in terms of structural change, huge increases in skilled retention rates, labour market training programs and all these things, which did not exist before. In a difficult period of adjustment, these things are very important.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brownhill interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying that those things are very important when one has inherited a basically structurally weak economy presided over by the limp-wristed conservatives in this country for donkey's years. When one has that sort of economy and embarks on a program of structural change, of course one runs into difficulties. Enormous structural change has taken place in this economy.

SPEECH.PARA: In this context, there is a very real danger that the Opposition will oversell to the community the economic problems which we face. The other real danger is that it will oversell its capacity to deal with them. This debate is being broadcast; I have to tell the people of Australia that the Opposition's capacity to deal with these issues is almost minimal, and it should know that. All this silly stuff that some of the more macho Opposition spokesmen go on with is not in itself a solution, when the macro-economic issues to which I have referred are not being dealt with in any different way by the Opposition in the statements that have been made .

Of course, the 1980s has been a difficult decade as a result of changes in the environment. Tariffs have come down in an environment of uncertainty. There have been volatile exchange rates as a result of the decision to float the dollar. There has been some indifference towards and bad structural relationships between the financial and manufacturing sectors. There has been a bad situation for Australia in terms of world markets for its rural products. All these difficulties have been with us. In spite of that, there has been strong growth in structural improvements of the Australian economy. These have been recognised elsewhere. They provide the underlying strength for recovery, which will lead us away from the misery index put forward by the Liberals, a party buoyant with gloom because it is dedicated to our catastrophe in the interests of its political advancement.

The Opposition has displayed these qualities in Question Time today and throughout this debate in the remarks of Senator Short. I would not get too buoyant with gloom; we will get out of this difficult period in time. When we do get out of it, we will get out of it in much better shape than anything we have seen in the last 40 years in this country.

Certainly, Australia is now in a critical position and people at the bottom of the ladder are paying for it. Twenty-seven per cent youth unemployment speaks for itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened in vain for any measures that the Opposition would be prepared to support which would address, as a matter of intervention in our economy, the difficult situation that we are in-measures which would get people back to work today, tomorrow or next week, enliven our economy and enable our manufacturing sector to compete overseas to increase our exports. Just a little while ago, a second reading attachment to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 was circulated suggesting three measures: initiating a further one per cent drop in interest rates; assisting State governments to eliminate payroll tax; and providing accelerated depreciation allowances for productive equipment in the manufacturing sector.

I was amazed and disgusted when I was told that the coalition parties would not be able to support the second reading amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) that the Australian Democrats are putting forward. The clear implication is that the Opposition, as much as the Government, is prepared to abdicate its responsibility to intervene in the market to ensure that the economy produces employment and the social and economic goods that satisfy people's needs. Opposition senators are prepared to leave their responsibility adrift in the sea of the market. The market, without values and without vision, is supposed to allow us to achieve our national objective at will.

We now have approximately one million unemployed-a figure which is up 60 per cent from last year. Bankruptcies are up by 53 per cent. These figures alone indicate the difficult situation that Australia finds itself in. We also know how we got there. We know that it was the concern of the Government to bring down the foreign debt to achieve a better balance of payments-in other words, to contain imports. The only solution that people who subscribe to the market ideology could think of was to bring down economic activity as a whole-once again, to crack a nut with a sledge-hammer. Would it not have been much better to contain imports by carefully targeted intervention methods-by increasing, for example, import duty on luxury imports and by requiring entrepreneurs to be subjected to the same loan restrictions as public utilities? Let us not forget that 65 per cent of our foreign debt was incurred by private entrepreneurs seeking loans for mostly non-productive paper takeovers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of Australian assets.

—Of Australian assets, as Senator Coulter advises. Let us look at some of the measures that are now available to the Government and the Opposition if they would care to support them. Certainly the Democrats would support the Government if the Government chose to do something about people who are now without jobs. I have already mentioned interest rates. Public pressure seems to be so strong that I would venture to say that within two or three weeks we will see another drop of one per cent in interest rates. But what about payroll tax? In all States around Australia, payroll tax is being levied on employers: it is a direct cost to employment. The Australian Democrats propose that one of the priorities of the Federal Government should be to assist State governments over time to phase out payroll tax and it should start doing so right now.

SPEECH.PARA: The manufacturing sector has been asking for accelerated depreciation allowances. We would support that proposal and call on the Government to initiate it, particularly in those sectors of the economy which are able to increase their export performance. I am adverting here to the environmental technology sector, which I mentioned yesterday in the debate on the Appropriation Bills. The proposal is being put forward as a worthwhile strategy by Dr John Stocker of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and has been endorsed by our Ambassador for the Environment. Many other sectors-for instance, the tourism industry-would equally repay some of the investment and assistance which has been provided by the Government in removing impediments and developing infrastructure, which is particularly important and critical in those sectors.

We believe that exports should be increased quickly. We believe that a 5 per cent bounty offered on new exports only would be an incentive that would repay the investment many times over. In the last year, $2,800m worth of new investments would have meant a bounty of $140m. This could easily have been doubled with a further expenditure of $140m. Alternatively, the Government could consider a tax break on, say, 50 per cent of income derived from new additional exports. This is one measure that Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries with which we are competing are using to gear up their exports to bring goods into Australian cities and to sell to Australian consumers.

We believe that the Government should introduce a research and development guarantee. It is quite clear that the $30 billion that private enterprise has derived in Australia from the operations of the accord over the last six to seven years has not been used for investment. The investment by Australian companies has been marginal at best. If private enterprise is not capable of doing it, maybe the public sector or the Government should take some action to ensure that research and development pursues a path that will lead to our becoming the clever, the active and, ultimately, the just country. In the current situation, we would favour increased expenditure on transport, housing, education and research.

I should also mention briefly the community work program which the Democrats are now putting forward, which would enable people who are on unemployment benefits to carry out work organised by local government: to carry out projects, for instance, for the conservation of public parks, land care and other environmentally important areas; and to carry out work for elderly people, in child-care centres, in community health centres and in other such areas. It would mean that they would need to derive some payment on an hourly basis in addition to their unemployment benefits which would lift the total remuneration to the award level of wages. This would have clear implications for social security legislation, but this should not be above us.

I am glad that Senator Kemp is in the Senate at the moment. He has started a fashion of looking at other parties' policies. I have taken the liberty today of looking at the Australian Labor Party platform for 1988. Under employment, education and training, in paragraph 3 of the introduction, we read the following:

The achievement of high and sustained economic growth is central to the fight against unemployment and poverty. Improving Australia's education and training systems is a central part of the task of achieving our full employment objective.

I believe that the Government and its Ministers would do well to read this paragraph again and to take some action, as I have outlined before, as proposed by the Democrats. Senator Kemp also asked, as he does continually, `Where is the money coming from?'. I could give him a number of examples which were published in the alternative Budget.

I could continue with this list. Indeed, I am well aware that Senator Kemp perpetrated yesterday some lies about our taxation policies in the area of capital gains and wealth taxes. I suggest that Senator Kemp keep to the facts when he looks at our policies and when he publicises--
