SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating an urgency motion which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government's economic policies, which have led to the most severe recession since the Great Depression, and its total inability to pursue the policies necessary to restore hope and economic growth to the Australian community.

I regret to have to tell the Senate and the Australian community that all the indicators are pointing towards frightening prospects for our economy. Senator Button, who is often given to refreshing bursts of candour, has already admitted that the worst is yet to come. This country is in dire straits. In February this year, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development reported that Australia was the worst performing economy among the 10 major industrialised economies in the world. In October 1990, Australia ranked seventh out of the 10, but by January 1991 it was ranked last-even behind New Zealand. We are all part of the same world environment, but Australia is handling the current conditions worse than any other industrialised country. We are in the recession which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that we had to have and which he generated because of a completely inappropriate economic policy mix.

In addition to this, the effects of the severe rural recession have not yet flowed on to the cities. The National Farmers Federation is predicting the worst period for agriculture since the 1890s. When the multiplier effect of this really hits the secondary industries and services, business bankruptcies, which are already at record levels, will continue to soar, and the unemployment level, which is currently standing at 10 per cent, will go even higher. Living standards are continuing to fall, and this will accelerate when the effects of the current trade recession in the United States of America and Japan push the Australian economy down even further-a situation which Senator Button chose to ignore today, assuring us that we will come out of all of this very soon.

Make no mistake: we are currently in a very deep recession, and it is the result of the disastrous economic policies of the Hawke-Keating Government. When the effects of the world downturn are added to this, Australia could be pushed into a full-blown depression. How have we got into this mess? Over the last eight years the Hawke Government has made a number of fundamental errors in its direction of economic policy. It should have been getting the policy settings right to solve the underlying economic problem: our failure to produce sufficient goods and services.

The top priority of the Hawke Government over the last eight years should have been to boost productivity. Instead, it has focused on demand management and on discouraging expenditure through a regime of high interest rates. Interest rates have been kept too high for too long. There are people in the Federal Government who recognise this. Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, is one of them. Only this morning he is reported as saying that `lower interest rates are better than high interest rates'.

The Federal Government's policy mix has been one of massive overkill. The Treasurer might rant and rave about banks and businesses but, when his policies were to keep interest rates high in the first place, it was really his fault that these businesses were pushed to breaking point. In February, the Treasurer admitted that the recession might have further to run and he was uncertain when recovery would emerge. But in February he assured Australia that it would not be before too long. He said that the Government's existing policies were on track and soon the economy would turn around.

What are the policy objectives of the Government at this time? It used to be to contain external debt and the current account deficit but now the Treasurer says that inflation is at the top of the agenda. One suspects that it is at the top of the agenda only because it is easier to achieve a lower inflation rate after one has hit the economy with the high interest rate sledge-hammer for so long.

Australia is now going backwards. Out in the suburbs and down on the farms people are feeling the pain. Living standards have declined dramatically and the people most affected are the most defenceless-the young, the unskilled and the unemployed. Adult unemployment in April reached the appalling figure of 844,000 people or 9.9 per cent of the work force, but youth unemployment is at 25.8 per cent or more than one in four. For the youth of Australia, the Great Depression has already arrived with a quarter of them officially without a job and without much prospect of getting one in the near future.

Do the people in the Government, who have been insulated in this city for eight years, have any idea of the feeling of hopelessness and despair amongst good kids who, through no fault of their own, face enforced idleness? These kids must wonder why they tried so hard at school to become part of the clever country when, at the end of the process, they graduate to nothing with no prospects but enforced idleness.

The unemployment figures are the ones which we are told about. These are the official figures supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Who are these unemployed? You are counted amongst the unemployed if you do not work at all. If you happen to do one hour's unpaid work a week, you are no longer listed as unemployed. You get no pay but you are considered to be employed part time.

If you do work experience for no pay, you are not unemployed either; you are employed part time. If you work on the family farm for one hour for no pay, you are not unemployed; you are employed part time. If you help in the family business for one hour with no pay, you are not unemployed; you are employed part time. No-one knows what the real unemployment figure is because of this strange ruling by the Department. Especially, no-one knows the real unemployment figure for young people because these are the people who are likely to be doing one hour of unpaid work in work experience, on family farms or in businesses which put them into this part time unemployment bracket.

Even the bodgie official figures are really only just the beginning. It has been predicted that unemployment will top the post-war high of 10.3 per cent. Jobs have been disappearing at an unprecedented rate since January and there has been an alarming increase in the number of job seekers, which has added the record number of 66,900 to the ranks of the unemployed.

I wonder how much comfort it is to the unemployed to be told by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the human toll of unemployment is a necessary part of restructuring the economy and that they are necessary statistics in the Government's plan to move to a much lower inflation rate. What does the Government propose to do about this? What does it say?

The Treasurer talks about getting the ship back on course but he has been saying that ever since he became the Treasurer. All that the Treasurer can ever do is blame someone else. It used to be the former coalition government which caused all the evils of the Hawke Government's mismanagement. Then it was business, the banks, even the public because they spent too much, the importers-anyone except the Government or the trade unions. When confronted with the latest unemployment figures, what did the Treasurer say:
This recession is deeper than official policy would have had it be.

Let us have a look at some of the real underlying causes. Unions have a case to answer when they hold this country to ransom for wage increases that employers cannot afford. What is the result of that? The employers go out of business and the employees join the ranks of the unemployed.

Then there are the accords: marks I, II, III, IV, V and now VI, which has been firmly rejected by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. This is systematically being used by the unions to threaten companies with a $12 a week across-the-board wage rise which cannot be condoned or afforded at this time of deep recession. Employers were able to take some heart recently when the umpire, the Industrial Relations Commission, rejected the latest accord mark VI, only to face the reality of union persistence with the accord wage and superannuation rises.

I will take just one example. This week in Newcastle, the floating dock run by Forgacs Dockyard Newcastle Pty Ltd was forced by strike action and other coercive tactics to agree to part of the accord claim for $12 a week across-the-board wage rise. The company had no choice. The ships were tied up and were going to remain tied up until the claim was agreed to. When the company did agree to the claim, the unions decided to strike until Thursday. Today, the news is that Mr Stephen Forgacs is considering leaving the business. His problems are numerous. Ships are behind schedule and, in the case of one ship, the strike is costing him $15,000 a day.

Let us have a look at some of the work practices in this particular industry. The unions allocate workers from a 50-man A-list roster on a rotational basis. Mr Forgacs has no control over who works on his dock. Many of the workers are totally unsuitable but they have to be paid because they are on the list. This is happening at a time of recession when we have unemployment at almost 10 per cent.

Another one of his problems is gross overstaffing. Every blasting pot and every dock arm in Forgacs is manned by three men; in Japan, this equipment is traditionally manned by one person. There is also no provision in the award for shift work, so penalties rates apply for any work done outside the hours of 7.30 a.m. to 4 p.m.. Not only is Forgacs losing credibility and money through the delay on the HMAS Tobruk refit, but also three contracts for the repair of ships have been lost in the past week at a cost of a couple of million dollars to the dockyard.

This is just the beginning. This is clearly a systematic campaign being launched by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to enforce the accord mark VI despite the Industrial Relations Commission and regardless of the recession, of economic strife in this country, of escalating unemployment and of the demise of businesses through inability to pay claims. This Government has got it all terribly wrong, as the example I have just given of Forgacs floating dock illustrates.

In its fourth term in 1990, the Government belatedly discovered the so-called micro-economic reform agenda. Senator Button claimed today that the Government had done a lot in this area but it is doing too little, too late. The Government is consistently hampered in real workplace reform by the self-interest of trade unions keen on protecting a whole lot of comfortable and inefficient work practices and benefits which they have built up over the years.

What is needed in Australia is genuine productivity based workplace reform where workers and management sit down and work out a package of work practices and benefits which will not only deliver a higher standard of living for the worker, but also enable the company to stay in business. This is possible. Already, there have been a number of celebrated cases where, despite the opposition of trade unions and the industrial relations club, employers and employees have broken out of the system and formed their own productivity agreements which have delivered both higher profits and higher wages.

These cases have been landmarks in Australian industrial relations history: Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd; the SPC Ltd fruit cannery; Robe River where 400 per cent productivity increases were reported; and, of course, Mudginberri abattoirs in the Northern Territory where an agreement was hammered out to save the company. This was done against union opposition. These types of agreements are not new.

When I was a student of industrial relations at Sydney University 25 years ago we studied cases like this which were occurring at that time in Europe and the United States. One model example of workplace cooperation and mutual benefit even occurred around the turn of the century at the Tartar steel mill in Jamshedpur in India. It seems to have taken a long time for these ideas to flow through to the workplace in Australia.

But such practices are essential if we are to solve the basic underlying problem facing the Australian economy-the problem of low productivity. This is the key, because if there is genuine workplace reform which boosts productivity the country can move to a position where it produces more than it consumes and where it exports more than it imports. The effect of such a turnaround would be lower overseas debt, lower long term inflation, lower interest rates and lower levels of unemployment: all of the economic indicators would start to head in the right direction, as they have done for many years in economies such as Japan and Germany, which have high levels of productivity.

The key to creating this situation in Australia is to have genuine enterprise agreements based on productivity. The Government has made a tentative start down this road, but it must urgently introduce policies to free up the workplace if it is to restore hope and economic growth to the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today on behalf of the Government to oppose this motion about the economy which has been moved by the Opposition. I think it is a product of the thinking of the Liberal Party tactics committee which-knowing that the inflation figures would come out today, that we would see the price level in Australia plummet and that it would be bad news for the Opposition-got together and worked out how it could distract public attention from this historic indicator, this landmark figure, on the inflation front. So it came up with this pathetic motion this afternoon in an effort to distract attention from the landmark inflation figures which have been released today which show the lowest rate of price inflation in our economy for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the people who, throughout the 1970s and the early 1980s, said that their cornerstone policy was to fight inflation first. These are the people who went to the electorate time and time again saying that they would fight inflation first and who were booted out of office with inflation and consumer prices in the double digit range at 11 1/2 per cent.

I am as concerned as anybody about the unemployment figures which were released last week. Understandably, there has been a great deal of focus on those figures. They are of great concern and it is understandable that people are concerned about them because many people have lost their livelihoods and, certainly, it is an uncomfortable time for many Australian families. I am concerned that the 9.9 per cent unemployment rate which was released last week is almost up to the levels of 1982-83 when we saw an unemployment rate of 10.3 per cent recorded in Australia.

As I pointed out yesterday, the figures which were released last week are a little unusual in that at the same time as the unemployment rate was recorded as having risen, there was also a measured increase in the number of people working in Australia-a very unusual result at a time of recession in this country. It is one that is also clouded somewhat by the figures which have been released by the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd on the number of advertisements for employment which have appeared in metropolitan daily newspapers. Those figures show that, for the first time in some months, in the month of April-the very month when unemployment rose to a measured 9.9 per cent-there was an increase in the number of job advertisements which appeared in Australian newspapers.

It is very interesting indeed to note that in April the nation as a whole recorded a 3 per cent rise in the number of employment advertisements compared with March. It is also very interesting to note that, despite the rhetoric of those opposite about the so-called economic competence of the Government of New South Wales, in fact the rise in the number of job advertisements which was measured in the Daily Telegraph and the Sydney Morning Herald-the two newspapers sampled in that State-was lower than the national increase for the month of April. In fact, four of the Labor States-those which are being attacked repeatedly by the Opposition-actually had percentage increases in the number of employment advertisements which appeared in their metropolitan newspapers which were well ahead of the increase for the State of New South Wales in April.

Today's high unemployment figures reflect past policies; they do not reflect policies which are in operation today because there are long time lags associated with economic policy and long time lags between when a policy is changed and when the effect actually shows up through investment or production or shows up in the labour force. In fact, the unemployment figures now reflect the policies which were in place at the beginning of 1990, not the policies which were in place at the beginning of this year.

The Opposition is 12 months late in calling for a change of policy because there have been adjustments to policy throughout that period. Of course, at the beginning of 1990 we had very high interest rates-18 per cent was the official cash interest rate in our economy. We had a very tight fiscal policy and last financial year there was a Budget surplus of over $8,000m. So two very tight policies were working together. The reason for that-which has been ignored by the Opposition today-was to bring down the demand for imports in the Australian economy. That is a problem we have had: our production has not been keeping up with the total level of spending in the community and there has been a spill-over into imports. Those tight policies were engineered in order to in fact reduce the demand for imports.

I am very pleased to note that in the nine months to March this year the deficit on our overseas current account was $13.4 billion, compared with a deficit for the same period last year of some $17.6 billion. So there has been quite a remarkable improvement in that current account deficit. The reduction in imports has been proceeding apace and the recorded deficit of $13.4 billion compares very favourably, I believe, with the Budget forecast of $18 billion for this financial year.

Interest rates have been cut on a number of occasions. As I have pointed out, they were running at 18 per cent in January last year but in February last year we mooted a change. Dr Hewson said that this was electioneering; that we were in fact easing interest rates because an election was on. But those reductions were very timely and, since then, there have been a number of reductions following on from that. Official cash interest rates are now not 18 per cent, but 11 1/2 per cent in the Australian economy. So those rates have been cut by over one-third in that 15-month period.

This should help boost activity in the Australian economy-for example, activity in the form of new housing and new dwelling construction. New housing starts should increase in this coming financial year. I cite a forecast from the chief economist of the Commonwealth Bank-Australia's largest home lender-who last week went on the record as saying that he expected there to be 122,000 housing commencements in the current financial year and 134,000 in the next financial year. So an increase is being forecast by Australia's largest home lender.

It is interesting to hear the rhetoric from the people opposite who keep claiming that this is the worst recession since the 1930s. When one looks at the housing industry one can see that that is clearly not the case. In fact, it is very easy to identify that in the Australian economy in 1982-83 in the recession which was engineered by Mr Howard there were only 105,000 housing starts. In this current financial year the Commonwealth Bank is saying that there will be 122,000. That is one clear statistic which nails the Liberal lie that we are currently in the worst recession since the 1930s.

I also point out that fiscal policy has been relaxed, along with interest rate policy. There have been two rounds of tax cuts, as Senator Jones well knows, in order to help to keep down gross wage claims in the Australian community and to remunerate employees by boosting their after tax disposable incomes. Those rounds have taken wage pressures away from business and have helped business to keep its costs down. That is one of the key reasons why today we have the very impressive result of a negative consumer price index figure being recorded for the March quarter 1990-91.

Before today the consumer price index was at an annual rate of 6.9 per cent. With the introduction of the figure for the March quarter this year, the March figure last year-1.7 per cent-is removed and replaced by a negative figure of minus 0.2 per cent today. We have two percentage points coming off the consumer price index, bringing it down to 4.9 per cent. That will certainly help take the pressure off the family budget; it will help keep living costs down. It will do that despite the claims made this afternoon by those opposite.

We now have the lowest price increase rate in Australia for many years. Two of the key factors contributing to that, as I have pointed out, have been the reduction in interest rates under this Government and the reduction in the pressure on wages as a result of the tax cuts designed to remunerate workers by giving them higher after tax incomes rather than encouraging them to demand larger gross wage rises.

While I am discussing the inflation rate, it is important to note that the Budget last year forecast a 7 per cent inflation rate up to June this year. We have already had a 4.9 per cent inflation rate to the March quarter. Very importantly, Australia is becoming more competitive compared with its overseas trading partners. If one looks at the industrialised countries of the world, represented through the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development based in Paris, the average inflation rate up to February for those countries was 6.6 per cent. Australia has an inflation rate of 4.9 per cent, which is well below 6.6 per cent. The trend in the rest of the world is for accelerating inflation; the trend in Australia is for decelerating inflation. We are on target to improve the competitiveness of Australian firms; to boost the price advantage of Australian exports. That will be a boost for local business and will certainly help other Australian firms compete better with imports.

I continue looking at the consumer price index and remind the Senate of the forecasts for inflation for the rest of this year that have been made by private sector economists. Before the figure came out today, Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd was forecasting a 3.5 per cent rate of inflation by December; Westpac Banking Corporation, a 4.5 per cent rate; Bain and Co., a 4 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent rate; and the ANZ Bank business indicators released this week said the rate will possibly be below 4 per cent. The ANZ Bank business indicators may be right, in view of the figure that has come out today. The private sector certainly sees falling inflation.

When the June quarter figure comes out we have the prospect of the figure for the June quarter last year of 1.6 per cent being removed from the index. If we get an inflation figure for the June quarter of, say, one per cent-in other words, a long way ahead of today's figure-even that figure will reduce the annual rate of price increases in the Australian community from 4.9 per cent to 4.3 per cent. I remind the Senate that the Budget forecast for the period until June was not for 4.3 per cent inflation but for 7 per cent inflation-a far cry from the record of the Liberal Party.

When those opposite left office there was double digit inflation, despite claiming that their priority would be to fight inflation. What they will do, if they ever get into government, is bring in a broad-based consumption tax. That is their so-called panacea for Australia's economic problems. They will tax everything in the Australian economy, except the price of fuel. That is the only exclusion that I have heard from those opposite.

If a 12 1/2 per cent consumption tax is introduced by the Liberal Party-if it ever gets into government-it will boost the inflation rate by 5 percentage points. Instead of having today's rate of 4.9 per cent, we would have a rate verging on double digit figures-to which the Liberal Party is highly accustomed. A 15 per cent consumption tax, which is even more plausible on my calculations, would lift the inflation rate even more.

Two of the great areas of consumption spending in the Australian economy are food and clothing. Both areas are substantially free from tax at the present time. There is no wholesale tax on 99 per cent of food items; there is no wholesale tax on the great majority-probably 100 per cent-of clothing items in this country. We will find if there is a 15 per cent tax brought in by the Liberal Party-food being tax exempt at the moment-that the price of food will rise by 15 per cent in the Australian community. As a result of that, there will either be a blow-out in the family food budget, as people have to budget for an extra 15 per cent on their supermarket bills, or, more likely, people will substitute cheaper foods for more expensive foods. The reality is that people will go for cheaper foods rather than the traditional foods they purchase. Items such as red meat and fish will be in the firing line. People will substitute items such as baked beans, sausages, soups and minced meat for commodities such as fish and red meat, which are traditional staples in the Australian diet.

The reality is that under the Liberal Party, while we would see food and clothing prices going up by around 15 per cent-in other words, the extent of the tax that it would bring in-at the very same time, the price of luxury goods in the Australian community would be reduced. At the present time, diamonds, jewellery, furs and expensive cars are all taxed at a 30 per cent sales tax rate by the Hawke Labor Government. Yachts are taxed at 20 per cent. Under the proposal of the Liberal Party, all of those items will be taxed at the general rate-which will probably be 15 per cent. I do not know how the Liberal Party can justify making the prices of luxuries cheaper but making the price of food and clothing more expensive.

What concerns me is that most luxury goods sold in the Australian economy are imported. The Opposition will be making luxuries cheaper, thus giving a further boost to imports. That will worsen the balance of payments. I cannot fathom why it is trying to make luxuries cheaper when it is totally counterproductive in terms of economic policy to make food and clothing more expensive and imported luxury goods cheaper. A stimulus to spending on luxuries will be given by the Liberal Party in Australia if it brought in a broad based consumption tax.

We allowed the entry of foreign banks and freed up the financial system. I can go through any number of areas where this Government has said, `We are now going to be competitive in world terms as far as our financial system is concerned'. TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief, as there are only a few moments remaining for this debate. Senator Kemp in his speech confused the issue of an inheritance tax with death duties, and I think it is important that that difference be explained. A death duty, which is not in our policy, is a duty which is levied against the estate of a deceased person and has first priority against that estate before the remaining part of the estate is distributed. An inheritance tax, which is part of our policy, is a tax that is levied in the hands of the receiver of part of that estate in relation to the size of the inheritance and the other assets held by that person.

SPEECH.PARA: A person may well die and leave a very large estate distributed among a number of people and, if the amount in the hands of the recipient is sufficiently small, no tax whatever is levied. That is the difference between an inheritance tax and a death duty. I repeat that a death duty is not part of our policy. An inheritance tax is part of our policy, and we will defend an inheritance tax as just and equitable, in the same way as income tax levies against those with large incomes. Part of that income may well come by way of inheritance, and it should appropriately be taxed in the same way as income is taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation of my earlier remarks, I draw the Senate's attention to the situation which is currently being experienced at the Ravenshoe sawmill and the particular hardship, both financial and emotional, which is being suffered by many people in and around that town in north Queensland. Before the Senate adjourned at 12.45 p.m. today, I was highlighting an absurdity which has arisen as a result of this Government's inaction. That absurdity is, however, also very tragic.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a legal impediment to the recovery of preferences under the corporations legislation or under the Companies Code. Basically, if a creditor in a company which has become insolvent is paid in preference to other creditors, a liquidator can recover that money and make it available for all the creditors to share equally. Unfortunately, that payment has to have occurred both when the company was insolvent and within six months of the appointment of the liquidator. Regrettably, for over 12 months now this Government has sat on its hands whilst a receiver has administered the assets of the company.

The effect of that is really quite simple: any chance of recovering preferential payments made before the appointment of the receivers is now lost totally and utterly. In other words, the Commonwealth's negligence, its failure to act, and its failure to understand the importance of the matters in which it was dabbling, may well have cost creditors in this mill thousands and thousands of dollars. The Commonwealth's failure to appoint a liquidator has meant that the claims of the creditors for recovery of that money can never proceed.

Ultimately, the Commonwealth has compounded its original financial ineptitude by further financial ineptitude. In other words, the Commonwealth not only sunk the money into the mill and did not look where it went-I highlighted it in my speech earlier on today-but also put money into a mill when it may in fact have already been insolvent 10 months before the receiver was appointed. It has been suggested-and I hope the Commonwealth will answer the queries I raised with respect to the dividend paid by the parent company-that in fact the parent company may have paid a dividend at a time not only when the mill may have been insolvent but also when that parent company owed $414,000 to the Ravenshoe mill. It is, in any sense of the word, a tragedy that so many honest hardworking people may have lost money as a result of an action such as this.

As I said earlier today, I sincerely hope that this dividend was not paid. But there is strong evidence to suggest-and many allegations have been raised, so I feel it is incumbent upon me to raise this matter here in the Senate-that in fact a dividend was paid and that the shareholders of the parent company may have been paid in priority to the Commonwealth and to other creditors of the mill. In other words, the money went out the back door. And again the Commonwealth did not know.

We can see the enormous financial ineptitude that this Government has put into practice in the administration and management of the loans and grants that it made under the assistance agreement to the mill in Ravenshoe-financial incompetence where it did not know the state of the company; it did not know that the company was experiencing severe difficulties in paying its debts. The Commonwealth did not know that the company had sold off assets to which the Commonwealth had a security which, under the terms of the Commonwealth's own agreement with the mill, were not supposed to be sold without the Commonwealth's permission. In fact, the Government and the Minister did not even know these assets had been sold until after the appointment of the receiver. So much for the monitoring of the mill, so much for this Government's concern for the taxpayers' dollar and so much for this Government's concern for the people of Ravenshoe.

This is the financial ineptitude that this Government has manifested-a financial ineptitude which this Government has compounded by its lack of action in appointing a liquidator, which has ultimately led to the fact that unsecured creditors face very little prospect indeed of recovering moneys which may have been available to them had the Commonwealth acted properly and with a sense of decency-or just acted simply intelligently. But this Government has not done that.

Of course, Ravenshoe is a microcosm of this Australian economy. For eight years now those opposite and their friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions-the faceless men who pull the strings above the amiable characters on the front bench-have been in command of this country's economy. These people, and nobody else, have caused the hardship, the suffering, the unemployment and the bankruptcy which so besets Australia's economy today. These are the people responsible. It is not the banks, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would like us to believe. That is a very convenient and a very simply fiction that the Treasurer uses to hide his incompetence, his inability to manage the economy of this country.

Numerous times today we have heard-we heard yesterday, too, from Senator Maguire-numerous dubious statistics about improvements in Australia's economy. When, on the Government's own figures, one in 10 Australians is out of work, that is not an improvement. When this country has interest rates twice those of its competitors in the United Kingdom, that is not an improvement. When this country faces the prospect of youth unemployment nationally being in excess of one in four, that is not an improvement. This Government-and I say it with a sense of tragedy-has destroyed, dashed, the hopes of a generation of young Australians. In some parts of this country over one in three young Australians-people under the age of 21-are out of work. That is not an economic phenomenon, some sort of fillip, some sort of thing that we should do to cut down the level of imports; that is purely and simply the result of the ineptitude of this Government-of Paul Keating and of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

Of course, Prime Minister Hawke has been at the head of this relentless machine which has ground down the hopes of so many young Australians; which has caused so much hardship; and which has led to exceedingly high levels of business failure, of bankruptcy, of divorce and marriage break-up. Prime Minister Hawke has been at the head of this machine and he must take some of the responsibility too.

As has been said-and I concur wholeheartedly-if Paul Keating does not have the decency to resign, then the Prime Minister ought to have the decency to sack him. It is unfortunate however that it might just work the other way around. Australian Labor Party members are saying that the Prime Minister ought to have the decency to resign. But on television the other night the Prime Minister said that he will not do it, even if they come knocking on the door. He will say, `No, I am not going to go'. He still thinks he is the best thing since sliced bread for this country. It may well be that the Treasurer, who ought to resign himself, will compel the Prime Minister to resign or be sacked.

Frankly, that is half of the solution, half of the problem gone. If we get rid of the Prime Minister we still have the Treasurer to go. For the last eight years both of these men, hand in hand, have inspired the recession which is destroying this country. Both of these men are as guilty as each other. Both of these men have on their hands the blood of a generation of young Australians whose hopes of work and prosperity and the possibility of advancement have gone out the window in this government engineered recession. For these reasons, history will be the judge of those opposite, and it will not judge them kindly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only a few isolated instances in this place when the behaviour of one honourable senator causes general disgust among his colleagues. One such incident started in the Senate last night and finished this morning. It was committed by Senator Coates. As Senator Watson said earlier today, to impugn the professional integrity of a truly professional person is perhaps the ultimate insult. I am only sorry that Senator Coates is not here. SPEECH.PARA: Knowing Senator Coates as well as I do-I am sure he will correct me if I am wrong-I guess he did not have the decency to inform the Clerks last night when he started his attack on them. In this place it is traditional that if one is going to personally attack the integrity of someone, he is informed of the fact so that he has the opportunity to hear and defend himself. Maybe Senator Coates's excuse for not bothering to inform the Clerks of his attack on them is that he knew they did not have, even if they had been present, the right to defend themselves.

Senator Coates used all the underhand intimidatory actions he could muster in his speech. One comment that he made-and I think it is a most important one-was that only Opposition senators would be supporting the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk Assistant; that all the support would come from us, not from his side of the chamber. Did he think that, by making those sorts of comments, he could either intimidate the Clerks into treating the Australian Democrats, the Independents and Opposition senators in a less equal way than Government senators, or did he think that those intimidatory comments would mean that the senators on this side of the chamber would not rise on that matter? If so, the tactics he has used are unacceptable and are not worthy of any member of this Senate.

I am well aware that all the support and defence of the Clerk and Clerk Assistant does not come from one side of the chamber as Senator Coates claimed. Many of his own colleagues have strongly supported the Clerks and have been thoroughly embarrassed by his stand. Senator Coates has not only objected to the Clerks' articles in The House Magazine, the Australian Associated Press report and The Parliamentarian as stated in his motion, but during the Estimates Committee A hearings he also objected to other articles written by the Clerks and their displays and seminars. He also objected to the pro-active advice being given to Opposition senators, although pro-active advice is given more to members of the Government. Indeed, there is nothing that Senator Coates did not complain about.

We must not forget the history of the Australian Labor Party because it explains the action taken here by Senator Coates. From 1919 to 1980 it was the written policy of the Labor Party to abolish the Senate. It was about 1980 at one of the Labor Party conferences that the decision was made to delete that from the written policy. I will quote Senator Gareth Evans at that time because I do think that it is important that we understand the full history. Senator Evans said of the written policy:

It is not popular with the people of Australia to have that up front in Labor's policy, so let us get it out of our policy. But we can still work very hard underneath for the ultimate abolition of the Senate. But because it is not a popular thing to have up front in our policy, we should delete it.

When Senator Evans came into this place he said that the best way to abolish the Senate was `to white-ant it from within'. Is it any wonder that Senator Coates objects to the Clerk and the Clerk Assistant of the Senate, whose main aim is to uphold and improve the functioning of the Senate? He said this morning that:
The basic problem is that those of whom I speak-
that is the Clerks-
are so proud of the Senate and all they believe it stands for, they so revere it, that they have allowed themselves continually to overstep the mark . . .

He went on to make many claims, ending up by saying that he believed they were `insufficiently dispassionate and disinterested'. It is the first time I have ever heard someone being criticised for being too interested in his or her job.

Senator Coates goes on to talk about democracy, a subject about which he and I have totally different views. I believe that the Senate, in particular, is the ultimate chamber in our democratic process. Ever since his Party has been in government, Senator Coates has been carrying out Senator Evans's directions to white-ant the Senate from within. He was opposed to the setting up of the system of the referral of Bills to Senate committees, and indeed visited our committee in an attempt to thwart its smooth running. He, as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, refused to allow the Opposition to elect a deputy chairman to that Committee until, in the last couple of weeks, he was finally forced to do so. I might add that every other legislative and general purpose committee of the Senate had a Government chairman and an Opposition deputy chairman. Senator Coates attempted to stop the Opposition taking its rightful role on that Senate Committee.

In August 1981, Senator Coates gave the Senate the benefit of his views of this chamber. In September 1982, he refused to address senators according to their correct titles and sought permission for Hansard to refer to senators as he chose to refer to them. I will quote from the Senate Hansard in August 1981. This is just a small selection of Senator Coates's views. He said:

I should say something of my attitude to the Senate, as a dedicated former member of the House of Representatives. If I must accept that this place exists, at least I can object to the Senate's powers and the way its supporters suggest not just that its powers are equal to those of the House of Representatives but that they are more than equal. This assertion of power is manifested in many ways, including subtle ways such as those I have mentioned before-for example, referring to it as the upper House rather than the second House. I suggest just that there is much forelock tugging here which is largely a result of the use of the title `Senator', a name style I find difficult to get used to although I suppose I will have to. The existence of such a continuously used title is one of the subtle ways in which this place wrongly asserts superiority over the House of Representatives where everyone is plain Mr, Mrs, Miss or Dr, or whatever. That was Senator Coates's view of the Senate. Because of his choice to not refer to senators by their correct titles in this place, he sought permission from the President to have his method of address used in the Hansard. The President at that time in December 1982 refused permission and said that the Hansard must correct his usage and address senators in the correct way. Senator Coates was then asked as an interjection by Senator Martyr:
How do you refer to yourself? Aren't you a senator?
Senator Coates's answer was:
I prefer not to use that title any more than I have to.

One can see that Senator Coates has no great love of the institution of the Senate and the chamber of which he is a member and in which he serves and represents the people of my State. Is it any wonder that Senator Coates is upset with any officer who upholds this chamber, defends and promotes it and who writes articles to educate the Australian people of its importance in how it protects the people of the various States.

I can understand Senator Coates's frustration, but to take it out on the Clerks in the bitter way he has today and last night is unbelievable. Frankly, I am not sure whether Senator Coates is aware of the danger of the road he is traversing, a road that, if carried to its limit, could make the Senate unworkable for the Government. It must be remembered that, unlike in the House of Representatives, the Government does not have the control by the numbers in the Senate. It is because of this that Senator Coates does not have the luxury of going down that road.

I am trying to be as impartial and unemotional as I can be in this debate, because I know that if I were to become too emotional on this subject-and I feel very emotional about it-I might unfortunately offend some members of the Australian Labor Party in such a way that they would feel obligated to come into the Parliament and defend their colleague just because he is their colleague. SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that Senator Coates has now put his case in support of this notice of motion, because at last we are able to see precisely what he is on about. This notice of motion has been sitting on the Notice Paper of the Senate, causing many of us grave concern and causing us to wonder when we would get an opportunity to hear what Senator Coates had to say in support of the notice of motion and to analyse whether there was any merit in it or not.

I say sincerely to Senator Coates that he is standing too close to the trees. He is so close to the political party fighting which goes on, not only in the Parliament but also outside Parliament, that he is seeing the activities of the Clerk and a Clerk Assistant of the Senate too closely. He is drawing invalid conclusions about their activities. I had forgotten that Senator Coates was a former member of the House of Representatives until Senator Walters just spoke, and I had forgotten about the matters which Senator Walters referred to. Perhaps that is why Senator Coates is so close to the trees that he is unable to see the forest.

For example, to suggest that former Senator McGauran or Senator Cooney would in some way be able to achieve some political advantage, either within their own Party or at an election, by being able to quote in some way or other the words of an article written by a Clerk of this Parliament is, I suggest, absolute nonsense. I refer to one of the articles which Senator Coates complained about, which was published in The Parliamentarian. It was about former Senator McGauran. I suggest to Senator Coates that, if he looks at the article, he will see that the problem is the way it has been presented by the editors of the magazine. The way The Parliamentarian wrote it up might have presented to those who read The Parliamentarian a different viewpoint, but that is not the author's fault. I have some views about that magazine too, but the style of the magazine is not controlled by the author of the article. One has to say that The Parliamentarian, which is issued in this place, is, in any event, what one might call an arcane journal. Who else reads it other than the people in this place? In fact, many of the people in this place do not read it in any event.

If we look at one of the other articles about which Senator Coates has complained, we find that it was published in a journal entitled The Table which is a journal of the Society of the Clerks-at-the-table in Commonwealth parliaments. How arcane a journal would that be? The only people who receive that journal would be Clerks in Commonwealth parliaments around the world. To my mind, to attack an article in that journal indicates the state of mind of Senator Coates in relation to this matter. He has given it far more publicity than it could ever have achieved. Why? I shall come to some parts of that article.

I have to acknowledge an interest in relation to the article because, when I read it for the first time, I saw that it quoted some things that I had said at a somewhat small gathering of people. I welcome the opportunity to explain my case on this matter.

That is, the question of the notice of motion. I agree with Senator Coates in that regard and thank him for explaining his case on the matter, because it gives us a chance to analyse that case. He then went on:
All I ask is for those opposite to listen carefully to what I say, not what they think I might have said.

I say to him that I have attempted to do that. I have read the Hansard of last night. I shall read today's Hansard. My concern is with the clerkist hierarchy of this place running its own political agenda. Again, I emphasise that I use political in the broad sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because he doesn't like it.
