If one ties that in with the Government's proposed banning of political advertisements on television and radio, one can see what we might be confronted with.

I am concerned about democracy. Democracy is a precious institution. It is not robust and can be easily destroyed, especially by people who believe their cause is the best for their country. They are the people who destroy democracy-the people who absolutely fundamentally believe their cause is the only cause for their country and that no opposition should be listened to. Democracy needs to be protected at all levels. The thinking of a few government senators worries me and perhaps there are members of the House of Representatives-although I do not hear them-who also think along these lines.

It is a problem of all governments-not only governments of this country. Governments in other countries which claim to be democratic have criticised people who oppose the government's point of view. They believe that a government provides information to the people of the nation, whereas anyone else produces only propaganda. We have only to look at some of the parliaments around the world-indeed, around the Commonwealth-to see where the democratic institutional values have fallen by the wayside because they have not protected the institutions of democracy.

As I have said, those institutions need to be protected at all levels. If, on the one hand, Senate officers are blatantly party political, then of course criticisms of their activities would be entirely justified. But if, on the other hand, Senate officers are stifled in their zeal to promote their institution, we will be the poorer for it.

As things stand, Clerks need defending to enable them to fight the good fight in institutional terms. The day that this Senate, as an institution, and individual members of this Senate stop backing the efforts of their Clerks is the day that the institution will die. Finally, I return to something that Senator Coates said last night which caused me grave concern. I address it to all members of the Australian Labor Party in the Senate. He said:

Clearly, the Clerks are not short of supporters on the other side to speak for them and defend them. That raises a significant point: does it not make the Clerk, and the Opposition for that matter, stop and think, when all the support and defence comes from one side of the chamber?

It makes me stop and think. It causes me great concern that honourable senators from the Government side are not in here at the moment defending the Clerk, defending the institution of the Senate and defending democracy; because that is what I am on about-the defence of democracy.

In Australia, fortunately, we have a democracy which we have not had to battle for. It has been handed to us by some very intelligent people and we have managed to maintain it so far. But I am concerned that there are no Government senators in here speaking on this subject. I understand their difficulty because the matter has been raised by one of their colleagues, and another of their colleagues from the back bench will no doubt get up in due course and make some comments about it in this debate. But no-one from the Government side is in here defending this institution; no-one from the Government side is defending the Clerk and his assistants; and no-one from the Government side is in here defending democracy.

That is what we are talking about in this debate-democracy. If Senator Coates had his way this institution would be deprived of its constitutional powers and would not be worthwhile defending. The day that individual members of this Senate stop supporting the Clerks of this Senate in the promotion and defence of the Senate and stop supporting them for being loyal to the institution of the Senate is the day that this institution will die and, indeed, the day that the fears of Mr Peter O'Keeffe, as expressed in this article, will be realised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 and Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91. I recall, on first coming to this place, being absolutely confused by the debate on the Appropriation Bills. Somebody said, `Well, it's really an opportunity to get up and talk about anything that you want to talk about'. I suppose anybody who has been listening to the debate on the Appropriation Bills today would be equally confused because that is what happens in the context of debating these Bills. The purpose of the Bills, of course, is to allocate the moneys that the Government has chosen to direct to various government departments and, therefore, the debate is a very wide-ranging one indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I will do three discrete things in the time allotted to me. First, I will briefly address the issue that has captured the day somewhat, that issue being what we think about and how we react to the way in which our professional officers, the Clerk of the Senate and his staff, are rendering service. I do not object to Senator Coates having used his privilege-I think he has done it with principle-of being critical. I think it is his right to do so. I think he has been quite forthright and courageous in what he has done. The Australian Democrats do not agree with what Senator Coates has done; but we do not deny his right to do it.

I will be brief in my comments on behalf of the Australian Democrats in relation to this issue. I think that the Clerks, and those listening to the debate, need to be very clear about what our attitude is. We have no criticism whatsoever of the manner in which the Clerks of this place render their service. Indeed, we have nothing but gratitude, admiration and support for them. As a minor party holding the balance, we have to be on our feet frequently and address complex legislation with quite limited resources. We are very dependent upon the Clerks. Through their expertise, professionalism, discretion and loyalty, they render to us quite superb service.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing that.

—Of course you do. We have no criticism either of the way in which the Clerks are going about that in the chamber or what they have said elsewhere in professional journals. Secondly, I formally move an amendment on behalf of the Australian Democrats to the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 5), realising that it will be voted on at the end of the second reading debate. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate calls on the Government to increase economic activity and reduce unemployment by taking urgent action, including:
(a) initiating a further one per cent drop in interest rates;
(b) assisting State Governments to eliminate payroll tax; and
(c) providing accelerated depreciation allowances for productive equipment in the manufacturing section''.

On the appropriations, as I said earlier, the function of these Bills is to provide money, under various headings, so that the Government can go about its business. One of the things the Government does is administer justice in this country and fund that process. Indeed, it is difficult to imagine a more fundamental and important process in our community than the process of administering and providing for justice. I do not criticise those who are responsible for its administration. It is an imperfect process, like all of these processes.

The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is presently looking at the cost of justice in this country. Under that general heading, it is addressing itself indirectly, not only to the overall collective cost of justice but also to what it costs individuals when they become involved in the judicial process in their attempts to receive justice before courts. The cost to ordinary Australians of attempting to obtain justice is quite extraordinary and exorbitant. In acknowledgment of that, of course, there is a system called legal aid. Unfortunately, access to that aid is not available to all.

The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, under the reference examining the cost of justice, is looking into the fact that ordinary Australians, under certain circumstances, are often grossly disadvantaged in their attempts to obtain justice.

I must admit that I was not aware of the full implications of this set of circumstances. I am a fortunate Australian in many respects; I have never been before a court of law. I have never had to seek justice from a court of law. I have never had to bear the cost of that process. It has only been in the course of the last three years-in my pursuit of the banking issue-that I have realised just what an incredible and extraordinarily anomalous situation we have in the way in which we fund the process of justice in this country.

I have brought before the chamber the cases of many ordinary Australians in dispute with the banks and argued them vigorously. Of course, we are looking there at an extreme situation. We are looking at a situation where ordinary Australians-in fact, destitute Australians, by virtue of having been bankrupt on many occasions-are in dispute with institutions, which have unlimited resources and access to the best legal minds in the land and which, by their own admission, pursue a tactic of delay and deliberate obstruction. Ordinary Australians, who are often totally without financial resources, once they find themselves in the courts, find they do not have access to legal aid to pursue their cases in the courts.

On a number of occasions, when I have brought these cases before the chamber and asked questions, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate)-a man whom I respect greatly-has responded predictably and has said that the appropriate place to have these disputes resolved is in the courts. Try to get a bank before the courts and then try to win: one really has a challenge on one's hands-particularly if the bank has been advised, say, by Australia's leading law firm Allen, Allen and Hemsley, that where the bank is in dispute with clients it should, if at all possible, keep those clients out of the courts.

The leading law firm Allen, Allen and Hemsley advised Partnership Pacific Limited (PPL) and Westpac Banking Corporation in the famous Westpac documents. After a month's struggle, I eventually got those documents before the chamber and tabled. Presumably, the documents have been read at least by some honourable senators because they evoked considerable interest by the time I got the documents here. The letters from Allen, Allen and Hemsley to Partnership Pacific Limited refer to how to handle the massive litigation it could expect in relation to offshore foreign loans.

Allen, Allen and Hemsley says that its clients will be slow to commence action for a certain number of reasons: the breadth of exclusion clauses and the power of attorney which they are confronted with; the lack of knowledge and how damaging the PPL documents are; the lack of success of previous actions; and the high costs involved. In the Westpac letters, Allen, Allen and Hemsley advise Westpac's subsidiary PPL that it need have little fear as to the enormity of the impact of the potential litigation.

In conclusion 9, Allen, Allen and Hemsley detail the massive disadvantages in which clients will find themselves in relation to the banks. In putting forward a six-point strategy- `How to beat the judicial processes', if you like-it says, as the second most important point, `Avoid litigation at any reasonable cost'.

How do banks go about avoiding litigation; in other words, complying with the advice that Allen, Allen and Hemsley in this case gave to Partnership Pacific Ltd? They delay and obstruct to an extraordinary degree. I draw the attention of the Senate to the circumstances of the Aliprandi family. I tabled their case in this place two years ago. They are in dispute with Partnership Pacific Limited and, by sheer coincidence, in the court they are up against Allen, Allen and Hemsley. The Aliprandi family have lost their winery, which was the eighth largest winery in Australia. It was conservatively valued by Partnership Pacific when it financed them at $2.6m. The Aliprandis have lost the winery to the bank. In addition to that, they have lost the family pharmacy valued by the bank at $600,000 and their family home valued by the bank at $250,000.

They are trying to challenge what has happened to them. In fact, they are trying to do what the Minister for Justice said was the most appropriate thing for them to do-to take the banks to court. Remember that they are trying to take Partnership Pacific Ltd to court. Remember that the law firm representing Partnership Pacific Ltd is Allen, Allen and Hemsley.

The Aliprandis have attempted on 94 occasions to take Partnership Pacific Ltd to court. I have just read to honourable senators the advice from Allen, Allen and Hemsley in the Westpac letters to Partnership Pacific which said to avoid litigation at any reasonable cost. They do not say what a reasonable cost is, but certainly the Aliprandis have been prepared to wear the cost of 94 appearances before court, in their registered names, in their attempts to get Partnership Pacific before the courts. The cost of those attempts alone has been $40,000.

What are the Aliprandis confronted with in our judicial system today? They are confronted with a situation where they have lost their business worth $2.8m to Partnership Pacific. They have also lost their family pharmacy worth $600,000; their home worth $250,000; and $40,000 worth of legal fees which they borrowed in the form of personal loans and for which they are personal guarantors. They are broke. After 94 attempts, they still have not been able to get Partnership Pacific before the courts. Frankly, they have run out of money. The only thing they have not run out of is will and guts in their attempts to do what the Minister for Justice has said they should do, that is, to resolve their problems before the courts.

I am not the only one who is concerned about this. The banking industry Ombudsman and Sir Ninian Stephen, the Chairman of the Bank Ombudsman Advisory Council, in appearing before the banking inquiry in the past three or four days, made this very point. Sir Ninian Stephen agreed that the cost of justice was prohibitive for most people and that alternatives had to be found. In giving his evidence to the banking inquiry, he quoted a friend of his, a Chief Justice of a State Supreme Court-remembering that Sir Ninian was a Justice of the High Court of Australia-as saying that he, the Chief Justice, could not afford to litigate in his own court on his salary. What an extraordinary situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he ask for a salary increase?

—Senator Schacht interjects and asks whether he asked for a salary increase. In due course he may ask for a salary increase. I am sure that eventually he will be granted one. That tends to be what happens with Chief Justices. Nonetheless, the point is still well worth noting that here we have a former Justice of the High Court of Australia and now the Chairman of the Banking Ombudsman Advisory Council appearing before a banking inquiry, and he is saying straight out that the cost of justice is prohibitive. He also quotes a Chief Justice of the Supreme Court who says that he could not afford to litigate in his own court on his salary.

SPEECH.PARA: There is something wrong with the way in which the cost of justice is addressed in this country. Today I have written to the Minister for Justice drawing his attention to what I am putting before the chamber now, asking that he, like me, seek to appear before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs cost of justice inquiry in order to pursue this point that all Australians must have access to legal aid where they prove the necessity in order to get justice. Without that aid, they will not get justice; they cannot even approach the courts to seek it.

Unless we are prepared to acknowledge that, we simply will not be able to deliver justice to Australians, and we have an obligation to do so. Ordinary Australians will not be able to counter giants such as Allen, Allen and Hemsley in its advice to giants such as Westpac and its subsidiaries that are prepared to go to any reasonable cost; and for a bank, a reasonable cost could indeed be millions of dollars. They are advised to go to those sorts of costs to avoid litigation, let alone to see what the outcome of that litigation might be.

I have written to the Minister for Justice asking him to address this issue. I have written to Senator Schacht who is here in the chamber. He probably does not have my letter yet, but I am grateful to Senator Schacht that he registered. He was the only senator to respond to the Westpac letters. When I sent copies to every honourable senator, he was the only senator, besides my own colleagues, to acknowledge that he even received these controversial documents.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) sent the letters back. He was not even prepared to face the consequences of opening the envelope that contained the Westpac documents. The Treasurer responded to me over the signature of Senator McMullan who is in the chamber and said that it was not appropriate to interfere as a result of the Westpac letters which I advanced to him.

Senator Schacht was straight on to a significant dimension of those letters-and I am grateful that he was-which cited the fact a deliberate contrivance was being enunciated in these letters to obstruct justice. If honourable senators want an example of that obstruction and the level of it and the extent to which these people are prepared to go, look at the Aliprandi case. There have been 94 attempts to get this matter involving Partnership Pacific Ltd into a court.

Of course, there are other techniques that can be used by banks. Yesterday, I received a fax from a Mr Peter Blake, whose case I have also tabled before the Senate, amongst the 70-odd case studies that I have tabled in this place over the past 2 1/2 years. Mr Stephen Martin said that McLean has either got to put up or shut up. That is what he said two days after I gave him 3,000 pages of documents which he chose to disregard, despite the fact that, by his own admission to me, he had not even looked at them. Mr Blake's case was one that I have put before this place and it was one of the 70-plus cases that I have tabled here in the past 2 1/2 years.

Mr Blake, besides being in conflict with banks himself, is also, by virtue of the powers of attorney that he has acquired from other people who are in conflict with the banks, pursuing quite vigorously the interests of a number of other clients who are in dispute with banks. By way of a fax yesterday, he drew my attention to the fact that a Mr R.= O. Thomas, who is in dispute with Westpac Banking Corporation, was served a writ on 9 May 1991 to be heard by judge and jury and the serving of that writ precludes Mr Thomas from appearing, as scheduled, before the bank inquiry. He was intending to appear before the bank inquiry in order to elaborate, in a situation where his case was not sub judice, his dispute with Westpac. It is not an inconsiderable dispute for $1.25m, and the timing of the issuing of this writ is quite superb. He will now not be able to appear before the bank inquiry.

These are only two of literally hundreds, probably thousands, of cases of ordinary Australians finding themselves in this situation where they simply cannot get access to justice because they cannot get access to money to fund their appearance before the courts and, even if they could, they cannot even get before the courts. Hopefully, Madam Acting Deputy President, I will now have leave of the Senate to table the documents that I have been citing in relation to the Aliprandi circumstances. I previous circulated them to those who I thought were going to be the duty officers in the chamber at this time but, unfortunately, in the case of the Opposition I sent them to Senator Short. I do not know whether he has communicated his reaction. I have the indication from both the Opposition Whip and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) that there will be no objection. So I seek leave of the Senate to table the documents which substantiate what I have been saying in relation to the Aliprandi circumstances.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I will conclude my remarks there. Quite obviously, I believe that I had `put up' previously, but there were some people, including Mr Stephen Martin, chairman of the banking inquiry, who did not believe that I had put up adequate evidence yet, despite such evidence having reached 3,000 pages. I can assure honourable senators that I will be continuing to `put up' as time goes on and I certainly will not be taking the other alternative he offered me of shutting up. I thank the Senate for its forbearance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject I want to talk about in the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) is the allocation of taxpayers' moneys to the Department of Defence in relation to other departments, in particular its natural partner, that is, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, whose main task is to ensure that Australia's relations with countries not only in our region but globally remain positive. It is a very important task that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has and I do not think it gets enough of its share of the taxpayers' cake to carry out the job that it is entitled to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it quite unacceptable that as we debate the additional appropriations this year, the Government, with the support of the Liberal-National Party coalition, could easily find tens of millions of extra dollars to pay for the country's involvement in the Gulf war. But then it has to be nagged by outraged aid agencies and the public into coughing up more than a token sum for the innocent victims of that war, and now, of course, the unfortunate cyclone victims in Bangladesh.

Many people revelled for weeks in the media hype of war, fascinated by all the high-tech smart weapons which became everyday household words-names like Scud and Patriot missiles. Then, as the press recently observed, the world became over satiated with human misery and we simply switched off as the pictures from the Horn of Africa, Mozambique, Iraq and Bangladesh shifted in rapid succession across our television screens.

The total cost of Australia's participation in the Gulf war is currently estimated to be just over $96m. We readily found the money for that in an earlier special appropriations Bill in February this year. These costs are being met out of an additional appropriation on top of the existing military budget of $8.33 billion.

In response to the devastating impact on developing countries and the refugee situation after the war, the Government could only come up with a total of $16.2m to help with reconstruction, refugee work, environmental clean-up and so on-many jobs which remain outstanding in the wake of that war. This figure covered $11.2m channelled through the World Bank, plus $5m for emergency and refugee programs. The money was allocated without cutting back other parts of the ongoing Australian aid program, which is one good thing about it. But still the tally stands at $96m to $16m-a gross inequity; a shortfall of $80m which should be matched by the Government.

I realise that there are many other areas in Australian life too where there are great calls for redeployment of taxpayers' funding. But I do not think that we should so blithely go off to war and be prepared to spend $96m on that effort without taking equal responsibility for the clean-up afterwards of the devastation in both personal and environmental terms.

In response to the $400m appeal from the United Nations Secretary-General on 10 April, the Government could only respond with $1m, which it said was all it had left in the emergency assistance fund. This is an ironic contrast to the way in which money was found to pay for the war with additional funds voted through very quickly by both Houses of Parliament. The Gulf crisis has demonstrably contributed to increasing global poverty and environmental degradation, and not just in the region of Iraq and Kuwait.

For the record, at least 40 low and lower middle income developing countries are facing the equivalent of a natural disaster in the wake of the war. In terms of population, for what we term destitute countries with a population of 440 million people, or close to 10 per cent of all the world's people, the impact of the war exceeds one per cent of their gross national product (GNP) and for many the impact is considerably worse-for Yemen more than 10 per cent and for Jordan more than 25 per cent.

The total direct cost estimated by the United Kingdom Overseas Development Institute for low income countries is at least $US3.2 billion; when lower middle income countries are included, it is at least $US12 billion. Fourteen of these most seriously affected countries are low income African countries, which were already struggling before the crisis broke. They include Ethiopia, Sudan, Somalia and Mozambique, where the world food program estimates some 16 million people are facing critical food shortages. Overall, the World Bank estimates that the war cost the Third World $US38.14 billion.

The impact of the Gulf crisis on the Third World bears the hallmark of a natural disaster as defined by the United Nations (UN). The impact of the crisis exceeds one per cent of the GNP of the affected countries; and is externally generated with its origins beyond the control of domestic policy makers. Many of these countries are affected by increased oil prices. This in turn-through increased transport costs-causes higher prices for food and other goods.

While it is not easy to quantify the effect of fluctuating oil prices on developing countries, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development has estimated that, based on an oil price of $US25 a barrel, developing countries face an average price increase of 110 per cent in 1990. Bangladesh, for example, was estimated to need an additional $254.3m for crude oil imports plus another $317.9m for petroleum products. Fuel prices rose by 75 per cent in Sri Lanka, 94 per cent in the Philippines, and in Mozambique a 40 per cent price hike grounded aircraft ferrying emergency food to the Niassa province.

Increased oil prices also affect the cost of fertilisers and other products with high energy requirements. Foreign exchange earnings dropped through the loss of remittances from nationals working in the Gulf. About one million people fled Kuwait after the invasion, most of whom were migrant workers. Hundreds of thousands evacuated other Gulf countries and Iraq. In Bangladesh remittances make up one-third of foreign exchange earnings. In Sri Lanka, remittances from workers in the Gulf and Iraq alone constitute 47 per cent of foreign exchange.

These people work as labourers, technicians, domestics and service staff. Bangladeshis repatriated more than $203.4m each year from Kuwait and Iraq. About 150,000 Bangladeshis working in Iraq and Kuwait lost their jobs. In addition, Bangladesh lost about $1.4 billion in wages, savings and belongings left behind by citizens fleeing the war zone. Each expatriate working in the Middle East supports many more family members at home; between 10 and 15 family members are supported by each worker in the Middle East region and in other foreign regions as well. Remittances comprise 47 per cent of Sri Lanka's foreign exchange and, as Iraq purchased 20 per cent of all the country's low-grown tea, the fall in demand caused tea prices to decline and imposed severe hardship on more than half a million workers in Sri Lanka.

Yemen, which had two million people working in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, lost about $400m. In addition, Yemen was cut off from $600m in oil shipments and other aid from Iraq and Kuwait. Other countries affected by loss of remittances include Pakistan, India, Thailand and the Philippines. Furthermore, the bulk of resettlement costs is being borne by these countries which are already crippled by debt.

Returning migrants, many of whom are unskilled, are trying to find work in saturated job markets. In Sri Lanka they are expected to swell unemployment figures by as much as 25 per cent-hardly helpful in that war-torn country. Migrants are returning to towns, cities and villages where basic amenities are already stretched to breaking point. The social and emotional upheaval among their families and communities caused by their homecoming is tremendous.

Many developing countries have lost important export markets because of the war. The embargo on trade with Iraq and the loss of trade with Kuwait have been especially damaging. Bangladesh may have lost up to $300m worth of exports. Prices of imported goods rose in most developing countries because of increased shipping costs. The massive reduction in international travel affected tourism earnings and drastically reduced foreign exchange generated by tourism. The President of Egypt reckoned that his country lost $US100m in revenue from tourism.

In contrast to Egypt, its neighbour the Sudan has suffered terrible consequences because of its Government's stance on the Gulf war. No-one knows how many Sudanese were working in the Gulf, but maybe it was between 400,000 and 500,000. Given the estimate that between 10 and 15 people are dependent on any single migrant's remittance, about five million people out of 24 million people in the Sudan were dependent on the earnings sent home by those migrant workers, because they send home about 80 per cent of their salary and invest the remainder abroad.

There is a well-founded fear among poor nations that foreign aid to developing countries is being diverted to the Gulf. Multilateral bodies such as the International Monetary Fund have been about as positive to these needs as Australia has-that is, not very positive at all. Only the front-line states received special compensation, such as the United States decision to cancel Egypt's debt of $US7.1 billion.

Besides the damage to the economies of these countries, there was a lamentably slow response to the plight of the Kurdish refugees fleeing from Iraq to Turkey who died in their hundreds and thousands, while the Australian Government had to be prodded into granting more than a token sum in aid, in contrast to the alacrity with which we managed to find a large sum of extra money for the Department of Defence in February.

As for the overall cost of the Gulf war to the United States, the White House Budget Director, Richard Darman, said in early March that it would be at least $91 billion, comprising combat costs likely to be less than $41 billion and non-combat costs of about $49.4 billion. If foreign commitments of $70.8 billion were honoured, the United States would have to pick up less than $19 billion in costs.

The final cost to the United States Government would depend on how many of the munitions it used are replaced, how long United States troops stay in the Middle East, and the accuracy of the Pentagon's estimates which assumed higher fuel costs than the market delivered. Indeed, when foreign contributions, spin-off contracts for the reconstruction of Kuwait, a general boost to the economy and stable long term oil prices are taken into account, the United States could emerge from the conflict well in the black.

There is a graphic contrast between the cost of one missile used in the Gulf-maybe $1m-and the money now being spent on the victims of war. As with Australia, this situation in the United States contrasts unfavourably with the aid provided for the Kurdish refugees fleeing from the tyranny of Saddam Hussein after having been incited to rise against him. Australia's mean response to the plight of the Kurds was echoed with an even worse response to the victims of the cyclone in Bangladesh when the Australian Government could come up with only $250,000, until it was pushed to increase this to $2m, still a pathetic sum. If this Government can find an extra $96m to pay for the war, it can also find an equitable amount for the victims of the war, and the urgently needed environmental clean-up.

Perhaps the most savage irony was contained in a newspaper article last week to the effect that in the Middle East it was as if the war had never happened. Of course, the main casualties are always the most innocent-the women and children of the region. For them not a lot has changed, except in a negative direction in that things have got measurably worse. Everything was back to where it had been before the war, apart for the people whom we have conveniently forgotten, as we prefer to focus on the returning sailors from the Gulf and the trade opportunities in rebuilding Kuwait.

We must also remember the many, many families in the region who lost family members, and the women and children and other civilians who suffered enormous trauma with the nightly bombings. For them life will never be quite the same. But on the ground and on a day-to-day level, obviously nothing has improved; in fact, the conditions of such people are quite deplorable. There is still no fresh drinking water available on tap in Baghdad, for example. Therefore, the health problems in that region are manifesting themselves in a truly devastating way.

In conclusion, I repeat the call that I have made before: that the ratio of $96m : $16m for clean-up or repatriation or helping the refugees is totally unacceptable. There is a shortfall of $80m. We should be able to spend dollar for dollar. Whatever we are prepared to spend on the war, we should be prepared to spend on reconstruction after the war. I urge the Australian Government and all governments which were involved in the Gulf war to match their war budget with a peace budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to make a contribution to this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation Bill (No. 5) but I noticed last night that in the adjournment debate Senator Bronwyn Bishop made remarks along the lines that in the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee A I chose to make a cowardly attack on the officers of the Senate, namely, the Clerk and Assistant Clerks. I refute that completely. The questions I raised about the performance of the Clerks were raised in Estimates Committee A because the Clerk and his Assistant Clerks would have an opportunity to respond and to defend themselves in respect of any questions I or other members of the Estimates Committee chose to put to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who reads the transcript of Estimates Committee A will realise that the Clerk and his assistants responded quite openly to the range of questions that I put, Senator Coates put, and even Senator Bronwyn Bishop put to the Clerks about the performance of the running of the Department of the Senate. Senator Bishop's remarks last night were, I suspect, made in a lather of frothing at the mouth, as though she is trying to prove that she is some demented Marie Antoinette trying to eat her own cake. If she had read the transcript of the Estimates Committee's hearing in April, she would find that that was a totally unwarranted attack.

Senator Coates last night made a speech, which he continued this morning, in which he indicated why he had withdrawn his notice of motion on the activities of the Clerks. He chose the Appropriation debate to explain his position, which I think was a further extension of his remarks in Estimates Committee A on 16 April. Since then some Opposition members have turned somersaults on the back bench claiming that this is the end of democracy, the end of the Senate as we know it, and a terrible attack on the integrity of the Clerks or whatever.

I believe that the questions that Senator Coates and I raised with the Clerks in Estimates Committee A in April were reasonable. I shall deal initially with the question of political partisanship regarding an article that the Clerks had written. If people read the transcript of Estimates Committee A, they will find that neither I nor Senator Coates accused the Clerks of party political partisanship. We absolutely denied it. However, we did raise, and I certainly still raise, the matter of articles being written, no matter the forum, no matter how obtuse or remote, and no matter how small the circulation the magazines in which those articles appear may be. One article in the Parliamentarian written by Clerk Assistant O'Keeffe states:
There has been a supine acceptance of these standards by all but a small minority of men and women whom the electorate nominates as its political representatives and law-makers.

The quite reasonable question I asked of the Clerks in the Estimates Committee-not that that comment was party political between Labor, Liberal or Democrat, but it was a partisan comment on the qualities of various senators-was: who are the senators who are accused of being supine? Those senators could then stand up and make their case heard and argue the case. The senators Mr O'Keeffe might not have accused of being supine-he says that they would be the small minority-might also like to know who they are.

Once a person starts making pejorative comments in such a manner about a group of members of parliament, whether they are senators or members of the House of Representatives, that person has to expect that some members of the Parliament, including those in the Senate, may object to it, may choose to say, `I want to know why I have been called supine or why I could be included with those who are being called supine'. I think that is quite a reasonable question to ask. I want to make it quite clear that I accept the fact that, in the functioning of this Senate, the role of the Clerks, by its very nature, must be in favour of the Opposition and the minority parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!

—I am being quite clear about this. I believe that, in the very nature of the proper functioning of this Parliament with all the advantages the Government has with its advisers, the bureaucracy and the departmental officers and so on, regarding the drafting of Bills and the provision of advice, it is only natural that the Opposition and the minority parties represented in the Senate will have to rely on the advice of the Clerks who have expertise in the drafting of Bills, motions, amendments and so on. It is only natural that the Opposition will make more use of that advice than will members of the Government who have the assistance of the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Treasury and so on. I accept that that is a proper function.

SPEECH.PARA: I also accept that from time to time the officers of the Senate may actually advise a member of the Opposition and say to him or her, `Senator, we know that you have an interest in a particular area. There is a Bill coming up and we draw your attention to it. You might be interested in looking at these particular clauses'. I have no objection to that either, because I think that is a proper function.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pro-active, is it?

—If Senator Kemp wants to call that proactive, that is his right. I have no objection to his doing so in that sort of process. I have to say that if the Clerks came forward and said to the Opposition or any senator, `This is the way you will destroy the Government's Bill'-irrespective of whether that senator has any particular or genuine interest in the matter-that would be going a bit overboard. But I would always err on the side of generosity towards the function of the Clerks and the Department of the Senate in providing advice to the Opposition and to the minority parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue that Senator Coates and I raise is that when things are suggested, such as descriptions in general, without naming the senators involved and making a quality judgment about performance, it is not unreasonable that some senators may choose to get more information about that and make a comment about it in the forum of an Estimates committee or in the Senate itself. I do not think that in any way is a cowardly attack.

I said in the Senate Estimates Committee in a number of exchanges with the Clerk of the Senate that one thing that did disturb me about some of the articles-again, it is not a matter that one should die in the ditch for; if we have a difference of opinion between the Clerk and some senators, it will not be the end of democracy as we know it-is that a view is put that, irrespective of the senators who come through this place from time to time, there is some sort of permanent view about the way the Senate should operate and the determination of this is the repository of the Clerks.

I think that is described in one of the articles by the Clerk Assistant as the `clerkly parliamentary agenda'-a mouthful, and a description that is rather clumsily worded. It is quite clear that that means that the Clerks have a particular agenda, which is that they have a perception that this Senate should operate in a particular way. As I say, it is not a matter that one should die in the ditch for in the great debate about the way in which this country is run, but I take some objection to the idea that the people who are elected to this chamber can come and go but there is another group of people who say, `We really know how the Senate should operate'.

In times gone by, that has been called the divine right of kings, the permanent will. In every case, democracy has rejected those notions and said that, whatever the particular arrangement is, the elected representatives will ultimately decide the arrangement. It may well be that at some stage in the future the people of Australia in a democratic way will choose to abolish the Senate. That will not be the end of democracy; that will not be the end of pluralism in Australia. If the people choose to do that, that is democratic. Many countries in the Western world do not have a senate with the powers of this chamber-they have no senate at all-but we cannot go around saying that those countries are any less democratic than Australia is because they do not have a senate with the powers or the structure of ours or a view that there is a permanent aspect about the way the Senate should operate.

That is a philosophical debate. To me it is not a matter about which one should get overly excited and froth at the mouth as do Senator Bishop, Senator Austin Lewis and Senator Walters. I must say that having some of those people talk about democracy is a bit like Dracula talking about saving blood at the blood bank. They have not shown much interest, from my observation in my time in the Senate, of being great defenders or supporters of human rights issues around the place. They always seem to be talking about other issues.

One thing that does concern me a little-again, it is not a major point but I think it should be placed on the record-about the performance of the Clerks is that, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitution Affairs, some months ago we had a request from the Clerk Assistant in charge of committees that copies of the minutes of the Standing Committee be automatically provided to him for consideration. I understand that the Clerk Assistant made this request to all Senate committees. I make no bones about the fact that when that was put before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs I opposed it most strenuously. I do not believe that the minutes of a Senate committee are the property of anybody other than the members of the Senate committee.

I do not see any necessity for an officer of this Department to have access to those minutes, other than when the members of that Committee choose to make them available if they want to get some advice on a particular matter. That sort of centralism of administration is unwarranted. Of course, on a number of occasions, minutes of Senate standing committees contain sensitive information and information given in camera. In a couple of cases, such as the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, obviously if it is made available to anybody else it may be prejudicial. It may be a threat to activities of that organisation. The same applies in relation to the access of minutes of the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

That sort of approach by the Senate Clerks is unnecessary. I will always protect the privileges of the Senate committees to be in charge of their own business. If we ever move away from that, we run the risk of affecting the independence and standing of the standing committees of the Senate. I would have thought that Opposition members, who are always trumpeting views about the independence of the Senate, would agree with me on that point.

I also refer to that very unfortunate incident that has had some publicity; certainly in Estimates Committee A I raised the issue of the resignation of Leanne Craze, the Secretary of the National Crime Authority Committee. She made a number of allegations in a letter that has had some circulation. I understand that the Clerk of the Senate, as he outlined in the Estimates Committee, has arranged for an independent inquiry into those allegations. I do not know whether that independent inquiry has been completed. I do not know whether, when it is, the report will be made available to participants on either side of the allegations. I certainly hope that it is. I certainly hope that Leanne Craze, the union that represents her, Mr O'Keeffe and the union that represents him-I suspect it may be the same union-have a chance to look at that report.

Some of the allegations are quite serious. As I understand it, one of them was that the Clerk Assistant wanted the minutes of the National Crime Authority Committee provided to him without clearance from the Chairman of the Committee. I do not know whether that allegation has been substantiated. I hope that the independent inquiry being conducted deals with those matters.

I conclude with one final matter about the running of the Department of the Senate. In the additional information provided to us, there was an outline of an industrial democracy program for the Senate Department. Though it is only a small beginning, that is long overdue. The running and the morale of the Department of the Senate could be greatly improved if there were a much more transparent arrangement about the administration in the Department.

As a result of such incidents as the resignation of Leanne Craze, there is a lot of feeling around about the way the Department is run. I do not accept that all those allegations are true; some may be gossip. But certainly there are morale problems amongst the staff of the Senate Department.

I hope that the industrial democracy program, as outlined in the additional information for the Senate Estimates Committee, can be used to improve the morale and efficient operation of the Senate Department, not just for its senior members-that is, the Clerks-but also for the rest of the staff in the system. I recognise-as I think does every other senator-that we, as senators, need assistance not just from the Department's top level but from all its staff. If they are not happy with the way things are being run, we will not get the best assistance.

In conclusion, I certainly urge that the Senate Department give every priority to implementing that industrial democracy program. As it develops it can be expanded so that we have a department in which people participate in the decision-making process in a much more transparent way than I suspect they are at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a debate that has covered such diverse matters as this, it is obviously impossible to develop the usual role in summing up the second reading; I will not attempt to address all the points raised by various honourable senators. Of course, many of those matters will be pursued further during the committee stage, as they should be. Therefore, I will not go to that. I will spend most of my time referring to the two amendments. The substantial matters here before us are the second reading and the two proposed amendments to the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a brief preliminary comment to acknowledge some matters raised by Senator Watson concerning my area of responsibility. Senator Watson raised a number of questions. He indicated an interest in my views about that. They are not matters to which I intend to respond; I simply acknowledge that he raised them. In the main, those matters will be appropriately dealt with during the committee stage. Some of the others we may deal with elsewhere in debates about forthcoming taxation legislation, et cetera. I want to let him know that his remarks did not go unnoticed.

Principally, I will deal with the amendments before us today. There are two-one moved by the Opposition and one by the Australian Democrats. I will deal with them in that sequence. The Opposition, with this amendment, continues in its determination to be as pessimistic as possible on all occasions. It is a little unfortunate for it that this debate on the amendment should come forward on the day on which the Australian people have received some economic news that must be remarkably welcome to them. Certainly, in regard to inflation, it is the best news we have had for more than three years. It is news that goes beyond the significance of simply one quarter's good inflation figures, welcome as they are; this news has significant ramifications for the evolution of economic policy in Australia, for interest rates, for inflationary expectations and for the long term economic welfare of Australia. There is the potential for Australia to get on that non-inflationary growth path, which we have sought for 20 years.

In responding to this particular amendment one could rehash the two hours of debate conducted during the matter of urgency. I have absolutely no intention of doing that. Senator Button, when responding to that, made extensive reference to the structural changes achieved over the last eight years, the need to assess the economic record of any government over the eight years and the substantial pluses that need to be put on that balance sheet. He also acknowledged the significant problems of the current recession.

There have been structural changes put in place by the Government over the last eight years and outstanding news concerning inflation was received today confirming the expectation of pundits. The mere publication of figures does not change any objective economic circumstances; they reflect the knowledge that Australians have had that the pressure on the cost of living has declined dramatically over the last several months. I do not think it will continue to receive negative consumer price index figures. That is remarkable and unlikely to be repeated, but we will be on a low inflationary path. We may have broken that cycle of inflationary expectation that has been feeding on itself for so long.

To some extent, both these amendments carry with them a wish that somehow or other we could abolish the business or trade cycle, that we ought to pass a law to say that Australia will no longer be subject to the business and trade cycle that the mixed and private enterprise economies of the world have endured over the last decades and centuries. I want to turn briefly to some fundamentals in the economy, because they relate to both amendments, and address some particular remarks to them. I will express some surprise and perhaps put some counter arguments because I am advised that the Australian Democrats support the Opposition's amendment, given that I would have thought it flew entirely in the face of their economic policy.

Let us have a look at what has changed in the fundamentals over the last eight years that will give us the potential to create low inflationary growth for the 1990s. We do have a situation in which Australia's capital stock is substantially enhanced. This leads to increased capacity in the Australian economy that will enable us to come back on the growth path without the cost pressures that often flow with bottlenecks and a shortage of capacity. Notwithstanding that the levels of investment in plant and equipment have fallen from the record highs we enjoyed through the late 1980s, they still remain high. That continues to create enhanced capacity in our economy.

We have the continuing pattern of export growth and growth in export volumes, notwithstanding the significant problems in our primary export industries. Two of those industries that have carried our balance of payments over the years-wheat and wool-are facing a crisis, yet Australia continues to see an improvement in its current account position. To some extent it is reflected by the decline in imports. Because of the decline in demand with the recession, one must acknowledge that. It is also substantially affected by the continuing growth in export volumes.

The fourth fundamental that needs to be addressed in considering amendments such as these is the structural Budget surplus that has been created. On the best and most recent estimates the Budget is still in surplus for this year. More importantly, there is a structural surplus in place such that, when the particular cyclical effects of the moment wash through the economy, that surplus will be substantially restored. The fifth fundamental is the impact of micro-economic reform-that which went before 12 March, that which was outlined on 12 March and that which continues to take place.

I wanted to put something briefly on the record about those fundamentals before turning to the fiscal situation, because that is essentially what the amendment refers to. I will express some comments about the fiscal points of the amendment and then address the reasons why I would have thought the Democrats would be less likely to vote for it than I understand they are.

It is of course true that the Government surplus will be substantially less than that which was budgeted for. That is due overwhelmingly to the recession; neither of those points is arguable. We do have lower wages and employment, which have sliced about $2.8 billion from revenue, and higher unemployment, which has added about $400m to expenditure. Other factors have affected the surplus. One to which I will refer would be welcome. Others were inevitable and agreed, at least by government and Opposition. Some are certainly not caused by the Government.

The factor which was overwhelmingly welcomed by the Australian people and which has changed the level of the Budget surplus is the tax cuts. They have reduced receipts by $400m, have brought lower wages and have made a substantial contribution to the welcomed lower inflation outcome which we gained today. Other measures which have been supported in some instances by all parties and in others by at least the Government and the Opposition and which have had a significant impact on the surplus are the Gulf war and assistance to the wool industry. There are minor ones, but I use those as examples. We have had other instances where the Government's surplus has been significantly adversely affected by decisions of the Senate. I refer particularly to the rejection of the sale of the Pipeline Authority, which has reduced the surplus by $700m, and the disallowance of the assets test for family allowances. As I am advised, the best estimate of the Budget outcome for 1990-91 remains a surplus of around $1.7 billion.

I note that the Opposition's amendment expresses concern about the call on national savings which may be made by the public sector as a result of the loss of the Federal Government surplus, compensating for the demands of the State and local government sectors. Although it is always true that it is better to discharge public sector obligations at the lowest possible cost and with no borrowings if possible, it is hard to see that the economy is suffering from a significant crowding-out of private sector investment intentions by the public sector calls on the capital markets at the moment. As I have said, as the economy recovers, the surplus is expected to be restored. A lot can be said about that; most of it has been said in the matter of public importance. I simply want to put a few of those comments on the record in response to this amendment.

The fundamental political economic point is that any motion which proposes that during this recession we should retain the level of surplus at $8 billion and express great concern that the surplus has declined is a recipe for economic disaster. Policies to retain the surplus at $8 billion during the recession is a recipe for more recession and a recipe for a deeper and longer recession. If we were to proceed in that manner, it would significantly exacerbate the already serious problems that we have. It would be both irresponsible and dangerous and it would ignore the counter cyclical impact of what is called the automatic stabilisers. In economic terms it is a nonsensical proposal and in social and political terms it is a dangerous and unsatisfactory one. Therefore, the Government will not be supporting it and I urge the Senate to reject it.

I also want to say something about the Democrats' amendment. They called on the Government to increase economic activities and reduce unemployment by taking urgent action. There is nobody who would not like to see increased economic activity and reduced unemployment. The Democrats make three specific points, some of which may have some attraction but none of which would lead to quick changes in the unemployment situation. Some of the proposals are desirable. They may have beneficial long term consequences and they may achieve social outcomes that Australians would welcome. That is not to argue necessarily against them. Some of them may well follow from the inflation news we have had today. But we ought not pretend that any of them will lead to quick changes in the employment situation.

The first proposal is a further one per cent drop in interest rates. Nobody on the Government side is going to come in here and speculate about what changes may be made to interest rates. All I can say is that significantly falling inflation does create an opportunity or the room for interest rates to fall but it does mean that the cost of capital to Australians can be substantially reduced. That point has been made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is important that we maintain that pressure on inflation so that that option remains open. But appropriately it is not a matter about which the Senate should speculate and I certainly do not intend to do so beyond that.

The question of assisting the State governments to eliminate payroll tax is slightly more complicated. It is easy to argue that payroll tax is a tax on employment and, if we could in some manner raise that revenue otherwise, that would be more desirable. But, as Federal members of Parliament we have to acknowledge one thing: the States value this as one of their few independent sources of revenue. If we are going to assist State governments to eliminate payroll tax by proposing to give them tied or untied grants from the Federal Government, that certainly will not be welcomed by the States. It would not be acceptable to the States; they would not be likely to agree to it.

If we want to assist them to eliminate payroll tax, we have to talk about proposing to give the States a substantial alternative taxation source, which will generate revenues at least equal to the payroll tax and perhaps substantially more. There are no magic wands in public finance. We are talking about taxes on income or taxes on goods and services. One of those would need to go to the States to compensate them for loss of the payroll tax, and this motion does not indicate which it is. At this stage, I do not think that the consequences of part (b) have been considered, and the Senate ought not support it.

The question of accelerated depreciation allowances for one particular sort of equipment in one particular sector of the economy has significant superficial appeal, but three things need to be said about it: firstly, substantial progress has been made in the area of depreciation as a result of the 12 March statement; secondly, accelerated depreciation allowances will not necessarily increase employment, because it may well be that we are encouraging people to invest in labour saving, labour replacing equipment; and, thirdly, it may not generate growth, depending upon whether the distortions that such a narrowly targeted tax measure would generate would be more significant than the pluses. It may not be beneficial.

We still have a significant rate of investment in plant and equipment, as I said earlier. In fact, it is near a record level. It is not immediately clear that accelerated depreciation allowances, particularly when targeted in only a narrow area and for only specified sorts of equipment, will necessarily achieve that purpose. It is certainly going to cut across the objective of simplifying the tax system.

For those reasons, the Government is opposing both amendments. In light of the Democrats' stated economic policy, I am surprised that they will be supporting the proposed Opposition amendment. I hope that they will not do so. The Government will be opposing both of them, but obviously I welcome the support that everybody has given to the passage of the Bills themselves. It is a somewhat more fundamental question, which I appreciate. I commend the Bills to the chamber.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 9 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government agree with the former Labor Government's opposition to nuclear testing by France at Mururoa Atoll which, in 1974, led to Australia and New Zealand taking France to the International Court of Justice to stop underground testing of nuclear weapons at Mururoa.
(2) What is the Government's current position on French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll.
(3) What is the current position of the South Pacific Forum on French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll.
(4) Is the sale of Australian uranium to France damaging Australia's reputation with the member nations of the South Pacific Forum.

(5) Is there a conflict between the sale of Australian uranium to France and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Treaty which prohibits nuclear testing in that region and of which Australia is a signatory.

(6) Does the Government accept that a link exists between uranium and nuclear weapons and therefore between selling uranium and testing of nuclear weapons; if so, will the Minister recommend to Cabinet that Australia cease the mining and export of uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Successive Australian governments have opposed French nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll.

(2) Particularly disappointing is the fact that France continues this testing in spite of the well-known opposition of South Pacific states. As a matter of principle, Australia will continue to protest against each test that takes place in French Polynesia and to make its opposition known at the highest levels. The Government will, in addition, use other opportunities, at the United Nations and other international meetings, to draw attention to the opposition in our region to such tests. France maintains that the nuclear tests it carries out are ``absolutely safe'' and that this removes one legitimate basis for regional complaints. Scientific evidence suggests, however, that while there may be no immediate dangers of contamination as a result of the tests, the longer term risks are real. Australia welcomes the fact that France has recently adopted a more transparent attitude to its nuclear testing practices.
(3) The South Pacific Forum opposes French nuclear testing in French Polynesia, hence its position on the subject coincides with that of Australia.

(5) No. Australian uranium is supplied to France under bilateral safeguards agreements with France and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom). These include safeguards and peaceful non-explosive end use conditions which are fully consistent with Article IV of the Treaty of Rarotonga governing provision by any Party of nuclear material for peaceful purposes.

(6) The possibility of using uranium for the production of nuclear weapons has been clear to the international community for more than forty years. It has been the impetus for the establishment by the international community of an effective non-proliferation and safeguards regime, based on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. In support of international non-proliferation goals, the Government has put in place a stringent safeguards regime for Australian uranium exports to ensure that no Australian uranium is used for military or explosive purposes. These arrangements, which include a bilateral safeguards agreement with Australia and the application of IAEA safeguards, apply to both nuclear weapon states and non nuclear weapon states. Under Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements with France and Euratom, all Australian obligated uranium supplied to France is fully accounted for within the peaceful nuclear fuel cycle. The answer to the second part of the question is no.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Green Paper was prepared by a Task Force established within the International Division of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The direct costs attributed to this Task Force up to the time of issue of the Green Paper are estimated at $112,258.

Preparation of the White Paper is being undertaken by the Task Force over a six month period which includes a three month consultation period. The direct costs expected to be incurred by the Task Force during this further period are estimated at $168,557.
(3) and (4) The Green Paper builds upon and extends the National Policy on Languages (NPL). It considers:
* the Commonwealth's experience with the NPL and its programs, taking into account the May 1990 report on the NPL by the Australian Advisory Council on Languages and Multicultural Education;
* developments since the publication of the NPL in literacy and language research and development;
* State and Territory Government literacy and languages policies and programs;
* the changing skills requirements of the workplace.
The Green Paper maintains the same basic directions as the NPL but:
* gives greater emphasis to the need for literacy in English and the need to coordinate the growing number of literacy and language programs, particularly Commonwealth programs;
* deals with the education and training aspects of language policy and therefore does not cover in detail language services, which are the responsibility of other portfolios;

* strongly supports an increase in the provision and quality of language teaching provision, whether taught as mother tongue or a second language, and promises continued support for the Ethnic Schools Program (which was established as primarily a language maintenance program).

(5) In dealing with the need for greater English literacy provision for Aboriginal people and the need to record and maintain Aboriginal languages, the Green Paper envisages a process for developing detailed strategies in consultation with Aboriginal groups and (on educational issues) with education systems after release of the White Paper. It is expected that these consultations will identify a number of strategies for Commonwealth support to achieve these ends, including, at least in some States, bilingual education programs.

(6) Under the New Arrivals element of the (Schools) English as Second Language Program, the Commonwealth currently pays $2,446 towards intensive school based ESL tuition for any child of a non-English speaking background who enrols in such a course within six months of arrival in Australia (or, where a child is com- mencing in Year 1, within 18 months of arrival). In 1990, 21,908 children were supported under this program at a total cost of $51.003m.

Children who are ineligible for this funding or who continue to need ESL provision after completing an intensive ESL program may be assisted by Commonwealth funding made available under the General Support Element of the English as a Second Language Program which had an allocation of $46.120m in 1990. It is not anticipated that this level of funding will diminish while our immigration intake continues to have high numbers of children who do not have English as their mother tongue.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, supplementary question without notice, on 21 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Why the feasibility study undertaken this year by the ABS examined training hours by gender but did not examine training expenditure by gender.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Feasibility work undertaken for the Training Expenditure Survey (TES) indicated that collecting data on total training expenditure by type of expenditure and training hours by type of training was likely to be feasible but that collection of expenditure data by gender would provide a number of problems for employers. Consequently, it was decided to pilot the TES in 1989 excluding gender.

The experience from the TES was that the time spent by employers in providing the information required by the survey was already high when compared to other ABS surveys. Burden on the respondent can seriously affect not only the respondent rate but also the accuracy of the information provided. Employers, generally, do not collect data on expenditure by gender.
